It also draws an unjustified parallel between the physical longevity of a diamond and the success of a marriage, which is a false analogy.

sentence: If you put root beer in a square cup, does it become normal beer?
details: This question equivocates the word “root,” using it both as the name of a soda (root beer) and as the mathematical operation of taking a square root. By conflating container shape with a math function, it also draws a false analogy between physical vessels and algebraic operations.

sentence: If I punch myself and it hurts, am I strong or weak?
details: The question limits the answer to only two options (strong or weak) while ignoring other possibilities, such as normal sensitivity to pain or the difference between strength and pain response.

sentence: How many milligrams are in a telegram?
details: The question is based on the unfounded assumption that a telegram—a message—has a measurable mass in milligrams, which is a false premise.

sentence: Smokey has always told me Only I could prevent forest fires. I'm in Louisiana, and forests are burning in California. What the hell have I done???
details: The speaker starts from the unfounded premise that only they can prevent any forest fire (false premise) and then infers that their failure to act caused the fires in California (false cause), wrongly attributing distant events to their personal inaction.

sentence: If carbon turns into diamond when under high pressure, why doesn't my pencil turn into diamond when I'm doing a test?
details: The reasoning treats graphite in pencil ‘lead’ as if it were the same form of carbon that becomes diamond under extreme pressure (false analogy) and assumes without justification that any application of pressure to any carbon will produce diamonds, ignoring both material differences and the precise conditions required (false premise).

sentence: How much disk space do I need in order to save Christmas?
details: The question equivocates on “save”: in computing it means to write data to disk, whereas in common usage it means to rescue or preserve the holiday. It treats the figurative act of saving Christmas as if it were a literal data‐storage task (nominal fallacy) and rests on the unfounded premise that Christmas can be digitized and stored on a disk.

sentence: Why can I only feel the earth rotating when I'm very very drunk?
details: The question assumes (falsely) that one can ever feel the Earth’s rotation at all, making it a false premise. It also implies that being very drunk causes the sensation of rotation, which wrongly infers a causal link and represents a false cause fallacy.

sentence: I set 30 bags of chips on fire. I burned 18,000 calories in 1 sitting. Why am I still fat?
details: The argument conflates the physical act of burning chips with the metabolic process of burning body calories (equivocation on "burning calories"). This false premise assumes that destroying the chips reduces stored body fat, and it draws an invalid analogy between combustion of food and physiological energy expenditure.

sentence: If opium is a pain killer, why does it hurt my family so much?
details: The statement rests on the unfounded assumption (false premise) that being a pain killer precludes any harm. It misapplies the general rule that pain killers relieve pain without negative effects to this specific case, ignoring known risks like addiction and side effects (accident fallacy).

sentence: If scissors beats paper, why haven't we switched to a scissors-based currency?
details: This argument assumes that because scissors ‘beat’ paper in the game rock–paper–scissors, scissors must therefore be a superior medium of exchange. That is a false analogy—game rules don’t determine economic value—and it rests on the false premise that winning a game implies practical financial superiority.

sentence: Are Canadians nicer because they live closer to Santa Claus?
details: The claim attributes Canadians’ niceness to their proximity to Santa Claus without any evidence, exemplifying a false cause fallacy, and it rests on the unsupported assumption that Canadians actually live closer to Santa, which is a false premise.

sentence: With 31,500 calories per gallon, is gasoline the best bulking food?
details: This question assumes without justification that gasoline’s chemical energy is equivalent to nutritional energy and that consuming it is possible and beneficial. That is a false premise. It also improperly equates the high caloric density of fuel with the requirements for a safe, edible bulking food, a false analogy.

sentence: My girlfriend refuses to enter peoples' homes unless they invite her in. Is she a vampire?
details: The argument takes the form: if someone is a vampire then they must be invited in; she must be invited in, so she must be a vampire. This improperly reverses a one-way implication (improper transposition). It also infers identity from one shared trait (false analogy) and relies on the unfounded assumption that only vampires require an invitation (false premise).

sentence: If a watched pot never boils, will an unobservable pot boil infinitely quickly?
details: This question assumes without justification that observation causally slows boiling and that removing observation must therefore speed it up infinitely. That is a false cause (assuming observation is the direct causal factor) and a false analogy (equating non-observation with the exact opposite extreme). It also commits an inverse error by treating the negation of the premise as yielding the negation (or opposite magnitude) of the conclusion.

sentence: If water expands when you freeze it, why don't we keep freezing water over and over to again to fix the water shortage supply?
details: This reasoning assumes that physical expansion during freezing creates additional water supply. In reality, freezing only changes water’s volume, not its quantity, so no extra water is produced.

sentence: How long are the nights on the sun?
details: The question assumes that the sun experiences nights, but as a self-luminous star it does not have a day–night cycle, making the premise unfounded.

sentence: If boiling water gives me Steam, what should I boil to get Origin and Battle.NET?
details: This question hinges on the word ‘Steam,’ using its sense as water vapour to imply Valve’s gaming service—an equivocation. It then assumes boiling other substances would similarly yield other game platforms, a false analogy without valid basis.

sentence: If I brush my teeth for 28 minutes once a week instead of two minutes twice a week, will the effect still be the same?
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption that only total brushing time matters and frequency is irrelevant, which is a false premise. It also treats two brushing routines as directly comparable despite crucial differences (false analogy) and misapplies the general guideline about brushing frequency to an extreme one‐time case (accident fallacy).

sentence: If particles do not exist unless observed, why can't I close my eyes and walk through walls?
details: This question is based on the unfounded assumption that particles literally cease to exist when not consciously observed (false premise). It also equivocates on what counts as ‘observation,’ conflating scientific measurement with merely closing one’s eyes (equivocation). Finally, it treats walls as if they behave like quantum particles under observation, drawing an invalid parallel between microscopic quantum behavior and everyday macroscopic objects (false analogy).

sentence: Will I lose my cloud data if it rains?
details: This question equivocates on the term “cloud,” treating the metaphorical cloud in computing as if it were a meteorological cloud that can release rain. It rests on the false premise that physical weather conditions can directly affect remote data storage in servers.

sentence: Women in the US prefer men over 6 ft tall. Do women in Europe prefer men over 6 meters?
details: This question illegitimately generalizes a U.S. preference to a different population (Europe) while also conflating two measurement systems (feet vs meters). Treating a 6 ft threshold as if it were 6 m is a false analogy, rests on a false premise about comparable preferences, and equivocates by misusing the unit of measure.

sentence: If 1/2 hands are left hands, and I am born with 2 hands, there should be a 1/4 chance I get two left hands. How come double handedness isn't more common?
details: The argument assumes each hand independently has a 50% chance of being left-handed, but handedness is a trait of the person, not individual hands. This false premise (treating hands as independent units of handedness) leads to an incorrect probability. It also equivocates on “left hand” (a physical limb) versus “left-handed” (a person’s dominant side).

sentence: Is it safe to stare at the sun if I put sunscreen in my eyes?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that sunscreen designed for skin can safely protect the internal structures of the eye from intense solar radiation (false premise). It also implicitly treats sunscreen’s known efficacy on skin as directly analogous to eye protection, despite no valid basis for that parallel (false analogy).

sentence: If guns don't kill people, why does the military even bother with them?
details: The statement presents a false dilemma by implying there are only two options—that guns either kill people or have no purpose—while ignoring other military uses (e.g., deterrence, training, signaling). It also relies on a false premise that killing is the sole function of firearms, and it begs the question by assuming the very point under dispute (that guns kill people) as self-evident.

sentence: I always get sick in the airport. Do I have a terminal illness?
details: The word ‘terminal’ is used in two different senses: an airport terminal versus a fatal disease. This equivocation conflates getting sick in an airport terminal with having a terminal (incurable) illness.

sentence: Since the earth is the third planet from the sun does that mean we all live in third world countries?
details: The argument equivocates on the term ‘world’, treating the planet Earth and the socio‐economic concept of ‘Third World’ as if they were the same. It also draws an invalid analogy between planetary order (third planet) and economic classification (Third World countries).

sentence: It's 100% humidity outside, but I can breathe. Am I a fish?
details: The argument assumes as a premise that 100% humidity means you are submerged in water and thus only a fish could breathe there (false premise). It also equivocates between ‘humidity’ (water vapor in air) and being underwater, conflating two different contexts of ‘wetness.’

sentence: If phone batteries don't last long enough, why don't we raise the capacity from 100% to 200%+?
details: This reasoning assumes without justification that battery capacity can simply be doubled or more, ignoring technical, physical, and safety constraints. Thus it rests on a false premise.

sentence: If we just exploded the mother of all bombs, does that mean bombs will now go extinct?
details: The argument treats bombs as if they were living creatures that reproduce from a "mother," implying that destroying one central bomb would eliminate the entire species. This is a false analogy (equating inanimate bombs with biological organisms), based on a false premise (that bombs reproduce through a matriarchal line), and a fallacy of composition (assuming what applies to that one bomb must apply to all bombs).

sentence: If the U.S. uses Fahrenheit, and Fahrenheit uses bigger numbers than Celsius, is the U.S. not just contributing to global warming by not switching to Celsius?
details: The argument assumes that merely using a temperature scale with higher numeric readings causes global warming, attributing a causal link where none exists (false cause). It also equivocates the size of the numbers on the scale with actual temperature magnitude or environmental impact (equivocation).

sentence: Does NASA sell astronaut suits to the public? My girlfriend just told me she needs space, but I'm concerned she won't be able to breathe out there.
details: The argument equivocates on the word "space," confusing emotional space with outer space and thus drawing an invalid conclusion about needing breathing equipment.

sentence: If Olive Garden has unlimited breadsticks, why have they not taken steps to cure world hunger?
details: This argument rests on the unfounded assumption that unlimited breadsticks would enable a cure for world hunger (false premise), and improperly equates a restaurant’s promotional supply with solving a complex global issue (false analogy).

sentence: Since microwaving lasagna never quite heats up the center, if I cover myself in lasagna, would I be protected from a nuclear blast?
details: This argument assumes that because microwaved lasagna resists heating at its center (a specific cooking context), it would also block or absorb the extreme heat and radiation of a nuclear blast.  1. False analogy: It equates microwave cooking physics with nuclear explosion physics, though the heat sources, energy levels, and mechanisms differ completely.  2. Fallacy of composition: It generalises a property of a small lasagna portion (the cold center) to the entire lasagna layer shielding an entire human body against a blast.  3. False cause: It implies a causal protection effect from lasagna based solely on its behavior in a microwave, without any evidence linking lasagna cover to blast protection.

sentence: My Nana was told to reduce her sodium levels, should I start calling her Na?
details: This is a pun based on the chemical symbol Na for sodium, not an argument or inference that commits a logical fallacy.

sentence: Is it safe to go out during a thunderstorm if my mum says I'm grounded?
details: The question wrongly links two unrelated factors—parental grounding and physical safety in a storm—implying a causal connection where none exists (false cause) and assuming that grounding status affects lightning risk (false premise).

sentence: If people can't afford electricity, why don't they just grow more power plants?
details: The argument assumes the false premise that power plants can be “grown” like biological organisms, equivocating the term “grow” and drawing a faulty analogy between plants and power plant construction, which misunderstands how power plants are produced.

sentence: Why people are always talking about parallel universes but no one ever talks about perpendicular universes?
details: This question treats universes like geometric lines, assuming that because “parallel universes” is a valid concept one should analogously consider “perpendicular universes,” even though the analogy fails. That is a false analogy, and it also relies on the false premise that naming one geometric orientation necessitates the other.

sentence: If Curiosity killed the cat, why didn't NASA announce that they'd found life on Mars, and why did they kill it?
details: This statement equivocates on the term “Curiosity,” shifting from the proverb about a cat’s trait to NASA’s Mars rover. It also falsely infers causation (because the rover is named Curiosity, it must have killed Martian life) and rests on the unfounded premise that life on Mars existed and was ‘killed’ by NASA.

sentence: My microwave oven has started smoking every time I use it. How do I educate it about the dangers of lung cancer?
details: This sentence commits a false analogy by treating the microwave’s smoke (due to malfunction) as if it were human smoking that causes lung cancer, and then inferring it can be educated. It also rests on a false premise that an inanimate appliance can learn or suffer lung disease. Additionally, it equivocates on the term "smoking", conflating machine malfunction with tobacco use.

sentence: My programming teacher told me to use a loop to print 'Hello world' 10,000 times. My printer is running out of paper. Please send help.
details: The argument equivocates on the word “print,” treating it as literal paper printing rather than console output, and thus rests on the false premise that "print" necessarily means using a physical printer. This misinterpretation leads to the faulty conclusion that printing code must consume paper.

sentence: I just slipped and now have nasty cuts on my arms and legs. I heard that salt cures meat. How much salt do I apply to the open wounds in order for them to heal properly?
details: The argument assumes that because salt preserves or 'cures' meat, it will likewise heal open wounds. This is a false analogy—meat preservation and wound healing are not comparable contexts. It also rests on the false premise that salt has healing properties for injuries, and it infers a causal healing effect solely from an unrelated culinary application.

sentence: If we'd all stop calling cancer cancer, nobody would have cancer.
details: This argument assumes that merely renaming or refusing to call the disease 'cancer' would eliminate its existence. It commits the nominal fallacy by treating the term as if its usage causes the phenomenon, and also a false cause by implying that removing the label would remove the disease. The underlying premise that naming governs reality is unfounded, making it a false premise as well.

sentence: If a picture is worth one thousand words, how many is a picture of one word?
details: This question treats the metaphor 'a picture is worth a thousand words' as a literal quantifiable rule, misinterpreting a figurative expression as a literal statement. That is a nominal fallacy—applying a metaphor literally. It also resembles a false analogy by extending the metaphor without a valid basis.

sentence: If there is steel wool, why have I never seen a steel sheep in the wild?
details: This argument equivocates on the term 'wool': steel wool is a manufactured material made of fine steel strands, whereas sheep wool is an animal fibre. By treating the shared word as if it implied the same underlying entity, it commits equivocation. It also relies on a false analogy (assuming that because one kind of wool exists, a corresponding steel sheep must exist) and a fallacy of composition (assuming a property of the part applies to the whole).

sentence: If 4 out of 5 people suffer from constipation, does that mean the 5th one enjoys it?
details: The statement sets up a false dilemma by presenting only two outcomes—suffering or enjoyment—and ignores any neutral or unrelated possibilities. It also commits the inverse error by assuming that because most people suffer, anyone who does not must necessarily experience the opposite.

sentence: If you eat pasta and then eat antipasta, will you become hungry again?
details: The question assumes without justification that eating antipasta after pasta will necessarily make you hungry again, implying a causal link based solely on sequence (false cause) and resting on the unfounded premise that antipasta cannot satisfy hunger (false premise).

sentence: If Mozart has been decomposing so long, why can we still find his music?
details: The statement hinges on the word “decomposing” in two different senses: the physical decay of Mozart’s body versus the creation or preservation of his music. This equivocation creates a misleading apparent paradox.

sentence: I'm a scorpio. The ruling planet of scorpio is Pluto. Pluto is no longer a planet. Does that mean that I don't exist anymore?
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption that a zodiac sign’s existence depends on the astronomical classification of its so-called ruling planet (false premise). It also inverts the implication: just because Scorpio is associated with Pluto does not mean that losing planetary status negates the sign (inverse error). Moreover, it wrongly treats the reclassification as a causal factor for disappearance of the sign (false cause), and effectively assumes that if A→B then ¬A→¬B or B→A without justification (improper transposition).

sentence: I read that over 100,000 people die in Hospitals every year. Why haven't we shut down these death traps yet?
details: This argument commits a false premise by assuming that hospitals are inherently 'death traps' simply because deaths occur there, ignoring their life-saving function. It also commits a false cause fallacy by inferring that hospitals cause those deaths, conflating correlation (deaths occurring in hospitals) with causation (hospitals killing patients).

sentence: Since you are more likely to survive a car crash while drunk, why isn't NASCAR or F1 forcing their drivers to get hammered before a race for additional safety?
details: This argument assumes a correlation (drunk drivers surviving crashes more often) proves causation (intoxication improves safety), which is a false cause. It also relies on a false premise—that intoxication actually increases crash survival. Finally, it draws an improper analogy between everyday traffic accidents and professional racing conditions, disregarding the vast differences in context and risk factors.

sentence: When listening to music by the pool, how does it know to pause when you go underwater?
details: The question rests on a false premise that the music player or headphones 'know' when they go underwater and intentionally pause playback. In reality, the pause occurs because the Bluetooth signal is blocked by water, not due to any detection of immersion. This also represents a false cause by attributing intentional pausing to immersion, and a reversal of causality by implying the effect (pause) is directly caused by a sensing mechanism that doesn't exist.

sentence: Why do people keep telling me octopus have tentacles when they obviously have eightacles?
details: The speaker mistakenly interprets the word 'tentacle' as if its prefix 'ten-' literally indicates ten limbs, rather than being a conventional term for those appendages. This is a nominal fallacy (treating a name’s elements as a literal count), built on a false premise that biological terms must encode numeric counts, and it equivocates by using the prefix 'ten-' ambiguously.

sentence: How can people that are lactose intolerant survive in our Milky Way Galaxy?
details: The question presupposes without justification that lactose tolerance is necessary for human survival, which is an unfounded assumption.

sentence: I read that Turkey Downed a Russian Fighter Jet. Should we be worried about Turkeys gaining super intelligence and rising up against us before Thanksgiving?
details: The argument conflates Turkey the country with turkeys the birds (equivocation) and then treats one unrelated event as if it causally leads to birds developing super intelligence and staging an uprising (false cause).

sentence: If the impeachment goes ahead, how long will it take for the President to turn from an orange into a peach?
details: The question wrongly assumes impeachment can cause a literal transformation of the President’s skin or form from orange to peach (false cause), is based on an impossible metamorphosis (false premise), and treats what is typically a metaphorical description as if it were a literal process (nominal fallacy).

sentence: If Batman's parents died, how was he born?
details: The question relies on a false premise by implying Batman’s parents died before his birth, when in the story they died later in his childhood; it also equivocates on the timing of ‘died,’ causing the confusion.

sentence: Why don't people who are allergic to Pears just eat things in Ones or Threes?
details: The statement rests on an unfounded assumption that eating in specific numeric groupings could prevent allergic reactions (false premise) and implies a causal relationship between quantity grouping and allergy outcome without basis (false cause).

sentence: I've heard spring water is good for you. How do I get the water out?
details: The sentence confuses the two meanings of “spring” (the season) and “spring water” (water from an underground source), leading to a misleading interpretation and question.

sentence: My driving instructor told me I should drive with my hands at 10:00 and 2:00. How should I drive at other times of the day?
details: The phrase '10:00 and 2:00' is used ambiguously, referring both to clock times and to steering‐wheel hand positions (equivocation). It also takes a figurative guideline literally by treating the clock‐face metaphor as an instruction about actual times of day (nominal fallacy).

sentence: If I run a survey about apathy and nobody responds, can I still publish the results?
details: The question assumes there are survey results to publish despite having no responses; this unfounded assumption makes the premise false and undermines any resulting conclusion.

sentence: Why are men so much better at hiding pregnancies?
details: The question presupposes that men can become pregnant and conceal pregnancies, which is biologically impossible for cisgender men. This unfounded assumption leads to a flawed argument.

sentence: If jellyfish are 99% water. If I inject 1% of water into it. Will it turn into water?
details: The argument treats percentage composition as if you can simply add 1% to 99% to reach 100% water, ignoring changes in total mass. That is improper distribution/addition. It also rests on the false premise that such an injection would make the jellyfish pure water.

sentence: I planted six eggs a month ago. I've been watering them everyday. How long till I get eggplants
details: The speaker assumes without evidence that chicken eggs will behave like plant seeds and grow into eggplants (false premise). They also draw an invalid comparison between eggs and seeds, expecting one to function as the other (false analogy).

sentence: I saw a gif of a guy get hit by a car but I clicked 'save' before the car hit him, is he ok?
details: The speaker assumes that because they did not see the moment of impact (not B), the person must not have been hit (not A). This is the inverse error: from 'if A then B' concluding 'if not B then not A.' They also imply a causal link between clicking 'save' and preventing harm (false cause) and rest on an unfounded premise that observing the event is necessary for it to occur (false premise).

sentence: At what age do worms become snakes?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that worms metamorphose into snakes. Because worms and snakes are entirely different organisms with no developmental link, the premise is false.

sentence: Did the 1983 song 'The Safety Dance' lead to an overall reduction in dance related injuries and fatalities?
details: The claim assumes a causal link between hearing a pop song and changes in dance injury statistics without evidence. It rests on an unfounded premise that listening habits can directly influence accident rates (false premise) and confuses correlation or temporal coincidence with causation (false cause).

sentence: Do other herbs heal all wounds or is it just thyme?
details: This question frames healing as either happening for all herbs or only thyme, excluding any middle ground or other possibilities (false dilemma). It also assumes without evidence that any herb can heal all wounds (false premise).

sentence: If objects at rest stay at rest until acted on by an external force, how can I be expected to get out of bed by myself?
details: The argument rests on the incorrect assumption (false premise) that Newton’s law means no motion can begin without an external push, ignoring that internal muscular forces can initiate movement. It also equivocates on the term “external force,” conflating scientific usage with the everyday sense of another person pushing you. Finally, it draws a faulty analogy between an inanimate object and a living person with internal power sources.

sentence: I put on a straightjacket but still find men attractive, is it broken?
details: This statement equivocates on the word “straight,” conflating the psychiatric garment called a “straightjacket” with sexual orientation (equivocation). It also rests on the unfounded assumption that wearing such a jacket could alter one’s sexual attraction (false premise).

sentence: If nuclear winter from 100 atomic bombs would cause global temperature to fall by 1°C, why don't we just do that everytime global warming causes it to rise by 1°C?
details: The argument rests on an unfounded assumption that detonating 100 atomic bombs would reliably and precisely lower global temperatures by 1°C without catastrophic consequences (false premise). It also misleadingly treats nuclear winter as an equivalent countermeasure to global warming, ignoring vast differences in mechanisms and side effects (false analogy).

sentence: Would you be annihilated if you put pasta and antipasta in your mouth at the same time?
details: This question assumes without justification that combining pasta and antipasta in your mouth would lead to annihilation. That is a false premise. It also implies a causal link between eating these foods simultaneously and being destroyed, which is a false cause fallacy.

sentence: Is my data safe if everyone can see it?
details: The question rests on an unfounded assumption that public visibility guarantees safety (false premise) and wrongly infers a causal link between everyone seeing the data and its security (false cause).

sentence: If there's an Extra Small and an Extra Large, why is there no Extra Medium?
details: The argument assumes that because the qualifier 'Extra' can attach to 'Small' and 'Large', it must also attach to 'Medium' (false analogy), and rests on the unsupported premise that size-labeling rules apply uniformly to every size (false premise).

sentence: If Apple cares so much about the environmental impact of their computers, why does their OS use a trash bin while Microsoft uses a recycling bin?
details: The argument presumes without justification that an OS icon directly reflects a company's environmental commitment (false premise). It then draws an unwarranted parallel between icon design and real‐world recycling practices (false analogy), and it conflates the metaphorical 'trash bin' icon with literal disposal policy (equivocation).

sentence: When I make a fist, where does my hand go?
details: The question presupposes a false premise—that making a fist causes the hand to move elsewhere. In reality, “make a fist” is a figurative expression meaning to shape your hand. Interpreting it literally is a nominal fallacy, and it also hinges on equivocation of 'make/go' as implying spatial movement.

sentence: What are idiots going to grasp at, now that straws are banned?
details: This question hinges on the double meaning of “straws,” conflating the literal plastic implement (now banned) with the figurative idiom “grasp at straws.” That equivocation creates a misleading argument. It also rests on the unfounded assumption (false premise) that all “idiots” will inevitably latch onto something meaningless when deprived of straws.

sentence: How long can you live before dying?
details: This is a straightforward question about lifespan. There is no logical fallacy or hidden contradiction: living necessarily ends in dying, so the query simply asks for the duration of life.

sentence: Could another cold war stop global warming?
details: The question assumes without evidence that initiating a geopolitical conflict would halt climate change by reducing emissions. This posits a causal link where none is established (false cause) and relies on the unfounded premise that war is an effective climate solution.

sentence: If I intake helium rectally, will my farts sound funny?
details: This is a straightforward question about physical effects, not an argument built on premises leading to a conclusion. It does not involve any of the listed logical fallacies.

sentence: If a nuclear bomb explodes with the power of 100 suns, how much closer to the epicentre can I get if I'm covered in SPF50 sun cream?
details: The question wrongly assumes that SPF50 sunscreen, designed to block ultraviolet radiation from the sun, would similarly protect against the vastly more intense thermal, blast, and ionising radiation of a nuclear explosion (false analogy). It also relies on the unfounded premise that sunscreen can mitigate nuclear effects (false premise).

sentence: I put all new CO detectors in my house. And we're in Colorado, so they should be going off. Is it possible my house isn't really in CO?
details: The argument hinges on the ambiguous use of “CO”: CO detectors monitor carbon monoxide, but the speaker conflates CO with Colorado, mistakenly expecting alarm triggers due to location rather than gas presence.

sentence: Why is dust so deadly that people die when they bite it?
details: The question treats the idiom “bite the dust” (meaning to die) as a literal fact, assuming dust is inherently deadly. This is a nominal fallacy: a figurative expression is misinterpreted as literal. It also rests on a false premise that dust kills people when ingested.

sentence: How can the pen be mightier than the sword if actions speak louder than words?
details: This question treats two proverbs as if they cannot both hold true and offers no middle ground or nuance, creating a false dilemma. It also equivocates by conflating the metaphor of the pen (words) and the sword (actions) with literal weapons and deeds. Finally it commits a nominal fallacy by interpreting figurative expressions as if they were literal claims about physical objects.

sentence: Why does sound waste time traveling as a sinusoidal wave? Couldn't it save so much time traveling in a straight line?
details: The question rests on the false premise that sound moves along a sinusoidal spatial path rather than as pressure oscillations in the medium. It falsely analogizes the wave’s graphical shape to a physical trajectory and treats that figurative representation as literal (nominal fallacy).

sentence: Do magnets grow in magnetic fields?
details: The question assumes that magnets can “grow” like living organisms, which is an unfounded and invalid assumption. Magnets are inanimate objects and do not undergo growth, making this a false premise.

sentence: If I sit in the bath for 60-74 years will my skin become so wrinkled/prune-y that I can biologically be considered an old man?
details: This question treats water-induced skin wrinkling as equivalent to age-related changes (false analogy), assumes without basis that one could safely remain in a bath for decades (false premise), and implies that extended water exposure would cause one to become biologically old simply by wrinkling the skin (false cause).

sentence: How come 1 apple + 1 apple = 2 apples but 1 pile of snow + 1 pile of snow = 1 big pile of snow?
details: The argument assumes that the operation of addition applies identically to discrete countable objects (apples) and to aggregations of a continuous substance (piles of snow). This is a false analogy because apples and snow piles behave under different ‘addition’ rules, and a false premise since it presumes that two piles must remain two rather than merge into one larger pile.

sentence: If it takes light 8 minutes to get from the sun to the earth, then why do my eyes already hurt after only staring at the sun for a few minutes?
details: The argument assumes that because sunlight requires 8 minutes to travel from the Sun to Earth, any effect of that light (such as eye pain) should also be delayed by 8 minutes. This is a false premise (the onset of pain is not governed by the same transit delay) and relies on a flawed analogy between light‐travel time and physiological response time. It also conflates the spatial propagation delay with the temporal manifestation of pain (wrong direction).

sentence: If alcohol is a depressant, but I'm happier when I'm drunk, does that mean that sober me is TOO happy?
details: The argument hinges on treating “depressant” as meaning “makes you sad,” when pharmacologically it means “slows the central nervous system.” By equivocating on the term’s meaning, it creates a false premise that a depressant must reduce happiness, leading to the unwarranted conclusion about the sober self being “too happy.”

sentence: Apple has introduced 'Thunderbolt' and 'Lightning', will the next technology be 'Very Very Frightening'?
details: The argument assumes that because two product names share a thematic pattern (weather phenomena that rhyme), any future product name must follow the same pattern. This is a false analogy—superficial similarity in naming does not guarantee consistent future naming—and it rests on the false premise that past naming conventions rigidly determine future ones.

sentence: They say 70% of shelter dogs are euthanized. How do you euthanize 70% of a dog?
details: This question attacks the statistical claim by twisting the meaning of ‘70% of dogs’ (a proportion of a group) into the absurd idea of euthanizing 70% of each individual dog, equivocating between a population statistic and a fraction of a single animal.

sentence: In my country we have a moon. But I went to Spain and they also have a moon. How many countries have their own moons?
details: The argument rests on an unfounded assumption (false premise) that each country individually ‘owns’ or ‘has’ a moon, whereas there is only one Moon for the entire planet. It also equivocates on the verb ‘have,’ shifting from Earth owning the Moon to each country owning its own. Finally, it treats a property of the whole (Earth has a moon) as if it applied to every part (each country has a moon), which is a version of the fallacy of division (often labeled here as a fallacy of composition).

sentence: My local travel agent just talked me into buying a ticket to Vancouver BC, but now I'm a bit concerned about the trip... How do they send you that far back in time?
details: The speaker conflates 'Vancouver BC' (British Columbia) with 'BC' meaning 'Before Christ,' assuming the travel agent is offering time travel. This is an equivocation on the term 'BC,' leading to the false premise that one could be sent back in time.

sentence: I'm 28 and haven't got my period yet. My sister got it at 14. Does it takes longer if you are a man?
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption that all humans—including men—experience menstrual periods (false premise). It also misapplies the general rule about menstruation timing to a case (a man) where the rule does not apply (accident fallacy).

sentence: Every periodic table I've seen has sodium's chemical symbol listed as 'NA.' Why would a symbol be not applicable for this element?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that “NA” in periodic tables means “not applicable,” which is false. In reality, Na is the established chemical symbol for sodium. This also involves equivocation, as the same abbreviation “NA” is misleadingly interpreted with two different meanings.

sentence: I'm going to the lake this weekend. Will I be in danger of getting mauled by a water bear?
details: The question assumes without evidence that 'water bears' (tardigrades) are dangerous to humans, which is an unfounded or false premise. It also relies on a false analogy by treating microscopic tardigrades as if they were large, predatory bears capable of mauling.

sentence: I keep hearing people talk about the low key, but I can't find it. Is my keyboard defective?
details: The speaker takes the idiomatic phrase low key (meaning subtle or understated) as if it referred to an actual key on a keyboard. This is a nominal fallacy (treating a figurative expression as literal) and involves equivocation between the idiomatic and literal senses of “key.”

sentence: Since the nearest star is 4.37 light years away from Earth, do wishes take nine years to come true?
details: This argument treats wishes as if they were physical signals propagating at the speed of light (an analogy between light travel and wish fulfillment) without any justification, which is a false analogy. It also incorrectly infers a causal relationship between distance to a star and the timing of wish fulfillment, a false cause.

sentence: Where can I see the workers who plant the pins for Google Maps?
details: The question is built on the unfounded assumption that there are workers physically planting pins for Google Maps, which is not true.

sentence: Are there any letters past 'Z' or before 'A' that we haven't discovered yet?
details: The question merely inquires about the possibility of additional symbols beyond the established Latin alphabet. It does not assume a false dichotomy, rely on irrelevant premises, or commit any other logical misstep.

sentence: Do people who write experimental music also have to write lab reports on the outcomes? What journal does it get published to?
details: The question equivocates the term “experimental” in music with scientific experimentation, implying without basis that musical experiments require formal lab reports and peer-review journal publication, a false analogy between artistic practice and laboratory research.

sentence: There's an estimated 391000 different species of flowers on the Earth. If all they do is eat sunlight, how does the Sun still exist?
details: The phrase "eat sunlight" is a metaphor for photosynthesis, but the argument treats it as literal consumption of the Sun, as if plants deplete the Sun like food. This is a nominal fallacy (literal interpretation of a metaphor). It also relies on a false premise that eating sunlight would exhaust the Sun, and a false analogy equating plant photosynthesis with eating matter.

sentence: Can we achieve higher education by building taller schools?
details: The question treats the phrase 'higher education'—which figuratively means advanced learning—as if it referred to physical height of a building. This is a nominal fallacy (taking a metaphor literally) and an instance of equivocation on the word 'higher.'

sentence: If mp3s are music files, and mp4s are movie files, how are MP5s guns?
details: This statement equivocates on the label “MP5,” treating it as if it were simply the next file-format in a series (like MP3 and MP4) when in fact MP5 is the name of a submachine gun. It also commits a false analogy by inferring that sharing a naming pattern implies a shared category or function.

sentence: My nose is running and my feet smell. Was I built upside-down?
details: The argument equivocates on the verbs “running” and “smelling,” treating idiomatic descriptions of bodily functions as literal actions, and then draws a false analogy that the body must be inverted because the words appear swapped.

sentence: How do people speak Mandarin if it's a fruit?
details: This sentence equivocates on the word “Mandarin,” treating it simultaneously as a language and as a fruit (equivocation). It also rests on the false premise that because there is a fruit called mandarin, the language named Mandarin must be a fruit, which is unfounded.

sentence: If I put my hand over the end of my flashlight and allow only a little bit of light to escape between my fingers while I hold most of the light back inside the flashlight, how much longer will my batteries last?
details: The question assumes that blocking most of the light output will reduce the electrical load on the batteries and therefore extend their life. In reality, the battery drain is determined by the current through the bulb or LED, which remains essentially the same whether the light is allowed to escape or is simply blocked by your hand. Thus the premise that covering the light conserves battery power is unfounded.

sentence: If evolution is a random process, why does charmander always evolve into charmeleon?
details: This argument rests on the unfounded assumption that because mutations in evolution occur randomly, the entire evolutionary outcome must be random (false premise). It also generalizes a property of a part (mutations are random) to the whole process (evolution always yields unpredictable results), which is a fallacy of composition. Finally, it equivocates on the term “random,” conflating the randomness of mutation with the overall directionality provided by natural selection.

sentence: Top gear keeps showing cars that are over 100,000 pounds. Why are European cars so heavy?
details: This statement equivocates on the word 'pounds', conflating price (pounds sterling) with weight, then generalises from a small subset of expensive cars featured on a TV show to all European cars (fallacy of composition), based on the unsupported assumption that Top Gear only ever shows cars costing over 100,000 pounds (false premise).

sentence: If I keep switching from Geiko to Geiko, does my insurance keep dropping 15%?
details: The question assumes without justification that each switch will repeatedly trigger a 15% discount. That unfounded assumption is a false premise. It also treats the act of switching as automatically causing a rate drop each time, a form of false cause reasoning.

sentence: How many times zones are between the US and China? It seems like their New Year is always like two months after ours.
details: The speaker incorrectly assumes that the time zone difference between the US and China causes Chinese New Year to occur about two months later. In reality, Chinese New Year follows the lunar calendar and typically falls in late January or February, not because of time zones but due to calendar calculations. This combines an unfounded premise about zones dictating month shifts and a false causal link between time zones and the lunar‐calendar holiday.

sentence: I found this in my community. From what I've heard from other people, it's a weed called 'the devil's lettuce.' Is my garden cursed? Also, how can I stop it from spreading?
details: The argument assumes that because the plant is colloquially nicknamed “the devil’s lettuce,” it is literally cursed (nominal fallacy). This relies on an unfounded assumption that a name conveys supernatural effects (false premise) and implies a causal link between the nickname and a supposed curse without evidence (false cause).

sentence: If light travels fast, and I travel light, why the hell is my flight still delayed?
details: The word "light" is used equivocally to mean both electromagnetic radiation (which travels at c) and travelling with minimal luggage. This pun leads to a false analogy and non sequitur: assuming that because one travels "light" (little baggage) one would also travel at the speed of light, which is an invalid inference.

sentence: If I get killed, will I be dead for the rest of my life?
details: This question does not commit a logical fallacy. It simply asks a tautological question: once killed, one remains dead. There is no invalid premise or faulty inference.

sentence: If e=mc^2, and e≈2.71828, shouldn't we be able to reach the speed of light by using less of it?
details: The argument equivocates the symbol e in E=mc^2 (energy) with the mathematical constant e≈2.71828, which is a false premise. This misuse of terminology leads to the invalid conclusion that reducing 'e' would let one reach light speed.

sentence: Why don't celebrities buy their own autobiographies then skip to the back to see how they die so they could avoid it?
details: This reasoning assumes autobiographies predict the future (specifically the author’s death) and that merely reading that prediction would enable one to avoid it—an unfounded and impossible premise.

sentence: What caused Americans to evolve warmer body temperatures? 98.6 vs 37
details: The question rests on a false premise that Americans’ body temperature is inherently higher, when 98.6°F simply equals 37°C. It then draws an unfounded causal link (false cause) for evolution and equivocates by mixing temperature scales to imply a real physiological difference.

sentence: How long does a young SR-71 stay with its mother?
details: This question assumes that an SR-71 is a living creature with a mother, which is an unfounded premise since the SR-71 is a man-made aircraft and not born of a parent.

sentence: If a lightyear is how far light travels in one year, does that mean light slows down during leap years to account for the extra time?
details: The argument is based on the incorrect assumption that the definition of a light-year changes with the calendar year length (false premise) and equivocates on what ‘year’ means (calendar year versus the fixed astronomical interval), leading to the mistaken idea that light must slow down during leap years.

sentence: My father is legally blind. How do I file an appeal to get this ruling overturned so he can see again?
details: The argument treats 'legal blindness' as if it were a court ruling subject to appeal, but it is a medical/legal classification, making the premise false. It also equivocates on the term 'legal,' conflating regulatory definition with a judicial decision.

sentence: If our WiFi is 5GHz, why don't we run our CPUs over WiFi?
details: This statement equivocates on the term “GHz,” treating the radio‐frequency band of WiFi (5 GHz) as if it were the clock speed of a CPU. It falsely assumes that because both use the same unit (gigahertz), one can substitute WiFi frequency for processor speed, which is a misleading analogy.

sentence: Why can't I weigh Earth by putting my scale upside down?
details: The question is based on the incorrect assumption that flipping a scale changes its measurement of weight. In reality, a scale measures the gravitational force between the object and Earth regardless of its orientation. The premise that turning the scale upside down would alter the reading is false, so the conclusion drawn from it is invalid.

sentence: An X-ray of my leg showed that I was part man, part skeleton. Did the X-rays give me mutant powers?
details: The argument rests on a false premise that an X-ray image means one is literally part skeleton, and commits a false cause fallacy by assuming the act of taking X-rays granted mutant powers.

sentence: If I purposely put pennies around my house, forget about them and then find them, am I creating my own good luck and how long can I expect to be lucky?
details: The argument treats the act of finding pennies as the cause of good luck (post hoc fallacy) without evidence, and it rests on the unsupported assumption that one can generate luck by placing coins (false premise).

sentence: If humans descended from apes, how tall were these apes? How many humans lived on each ape?
details: This question is based on a false premise that human ancestors were living apes serving as hosts for modern humans. It equivocates on “descended from,” treating evolutionary lineage as immediate, physical cohabitation. It also uses a false analogy by comparing genetic descent to literal dependence, resulting in nonsensical queries about ape height and human‐per‐ape ratios.

sentence: If the speed of light in a vacuum is 299,800,000 m/s, can you help me work out what is it in other household appliances?
details: The question rests on the false premise that the speed of light will vary simply because it passes through different household appliances, whereas only the medium’s refractive index affects light speed. It also equivocates on “household appliances,” treating devices as if they were uniform optical media.

sentence: I just set up my new smart TV, but I'm still able to watch Keeping up with the Kardashians. Why isn't it working?
details: The speaker equivocates on the word "smart" in "smart TV," treating it as if it means "intellectually stimulating" rather than a network-enabled device. This leads to the false assumption (and a secondary false analogy) that a "smart" TV should only allow "smart" content and thus block shows deemed unintelligent.

sentence: I get that it's the number one killer of cats, but how did authorities manage to track Curiosity all the way to Mars?
details: The statement equivocates on the term "Curiosity," first treating it as a trait (the supposed cat killer) and then as the Mars rover, misleadingly conflating two distinct meanings.

sentence: How did Google get the sun to light up the entire planet at the same time for the Google Earth picture?
details: The question assumes as fact that the sun can illuminate every part of Earth simultaneously in one photograph. In reality, illumination varies with time and location, and Google Earth combines images taken at different times. The underlying premise is therefore false.

sentence: I cleared large rocks from a section of my yard, in preparation for making a garden in the spring. Should I do anything to keep the rocks from growing back in the meantime?
details: The question relies on the unfounded assumption that rocks can 'grow back,' but rocks are inorganic and do not grow or reproduce, making the premise false.

sentence: If one revolution on Earth lasts one year, how come the American revolution lasted 7 years?
details: This argument equivocates on the term “revolution,” using it first to mean Earth’s orbit around the Sun and then to mean a political uprising. It also improperly analogizes two different senses of the same word and treats a shared name as implying shared properties.

sentence: I cut onions but never cry, am I a sociopath?
details: This statement uses the word cry both as a physical tear response and as an emotional reaction, sets up a false analogy between tearing up and empathy, and rests on a false premise that failing to tear up when cutting onions implies sociopathy.

sentence: How long does it take for a wave to grow up and have baby waves?
details: The question treats waves as if they were living organisms that grow and reproduce, which is a false premise. It also draws an unwarranted analogy between waves and biological entities, and interprets a figurative idea (waves spawning other waves) as literal, a nominal fallacy.

sentence: Shouldn't undercooked meat be more expensive given how rare it is?
details: The argument conflates the culinary term “rare” (undercooked) with economic scarcity, implying that because something is called ‘rare’ it must be scarce and therefore expensive. This is equivocation on “rare.” It also wrongly analogizes dining terminology to market value (false analogy) and assumes without support that undercooked meat is actually scarce (false premise).

sentence: It's been hundreds of years. Why hasn't Machu Pichu evolved into Machu Pikachu yet?
details: The argument assumes without basis that Machu Picchu is a living entity capable of biological evolution (false premise), treats a ruin as if it shared attributes with living species to ‘evolve’ into Pikachu (false analogy), and misapplies the general rule of biological evolution to a non‐biological object (accident fallacy).

sentence: So if Schrodinger's cat is both alive and dead inside the box, and you check to see if it's alive, and it's not, did curiosity kill the cat?
details: The statement assumes that observing (checking) the cat caused its death simply because the cat is found dead after measurement. This is a false cause fallacy by conflating sequence with causation. It also reverses cause and effect by implying that curiosity killed the cat, whereas the cat could already have been dead before the observation.

sentence: Humans first appeared on Earth around 200000BC, but where did humans live before then?
details: The assertion that humans first appeared at a certain time conflicts with asking where they lived before that time, directly contradicting the initial premise.

sentence: I'm trying to teach my son how to spell 'racecar' but he keeps spelling it completely backwards. Is my son retarded?
details: The question assumes without evidence that a child’s difficulty reversing the spelling of a palindrome implies intellectual disability. That is a false premise. It also wrongly infers causation between a spelling mistake and mental retardation (false cause), and misapplies a general rule about abilities to a specific case where context (age, learning stage, familiarity with palindromes) matters (accident fallacy).

sentence: if i die in real life would i also die in my dreams
details: The question assumes an unfounded link between real‐life death and dream states, positing that dying physically must cause death in a dream (false premise). It also infers a causal relationship without evidence (false cause) and treats life and dreaming as directly analogous without justification (false analogy).

sentence: How can a footprint can last 13,000 years, but I can't get an avocado to last longer than 2 days?
details: The statement compares two entirely different processes—the geological fossilization of footprints versus the biological spoilage of fruit—and treats them as if they were directly comparable. This invalid analogy rests on an unfounded premise that the same principles should govern both phenomena.

sentence: If I set an oven to 350 degrees to cook a pie, will it leave 10 degrees of the pie uncooked?
details: The question equivocates the word “degree,” using it both as a temperature unit and as a measure of cooking completion. It rests on the false premise that cooking progress can be quantified in temperature degrees, and it falsely analogizes oven‐temperature degrees to degrees of doneness.

sentence: According to this info-graph, the average daily temperature on mercury is 427c, but apparently the boiling point of mercury is 357c, so why doesn't mercury boil away?
details: The argument equivocates on “mercury,” confusing the planet Mercury with the element mercury, and therefore rests on the false premise that the boiling point of the metal applies to the planet’s surface temperature.

sentence: My wife is in kidney failure and needs a transplant. How can I tell which of the plants in my garden are cis and which are trans?
details: The question rests on a false premise that garden plants can be classified as 'cis' or 'trans' in the same sense as a medical transplant or chemical stereochemistry. It equivocates on the prefixes 'cis-' and 'trans-' by applying them incorrectly, and by analogy assumes categories from organ transplantation or molecular isomerism map onto living plants without justification.

sentence: The factory reset function on my phone says it will return everything to how it was when it I got it, but my screen is still broken. Did I miss a step?
details: The term "everything" is used ambiguously to imply both software and hardware restoration (equivocation). This relies on the unfounded assumption that a software reset can repair a broken screen (false premise), and it treats the figurative promise of "everything" as a literal guarantee (nominal fallacy).

sentence: How come statues don't pet dogs?
details: The question assumes as a given that statues are capable of petting dogs. This is a false premise because statues are inanimate objects without agency or the ability to perform actions such as petting.

sentence: How do Manatees Reproduce if there are No Womanatees?
details: The question rests on the false premise that a manatee must be male and that no female counterpart (‘womanatee’) exists. It equivocates by treating the prefix “man” in “manatee” as equivalent to the human gender term, and it literalizes the species name (a nominal fallacy) rather than recognizing that ‘manatee’ is just the common name for both sexes.

sentence: I was told my old gameboy could be charged with batteries, but after brutally bludgeoning at least 10 people with it I still can't play Pokemon Yellow. Help!
details: The argument hinges on an equivocation of the word "batteries"—confusing electrical batteries with the legal/violent term battery—leading to the false premise that bludgeoning people would charge the device. It also falsely assumes a causal link between assault and device power (false cause).

sentence: If celery is 90% water, is the ocean 10% celery?
details: The argument reverses the original implication (celery → water) to water → celery (improper transposition) and assumes that what holds for a part (celery contains water) must hold for the whole (the ocean contains celery), which is a fallacy of composition. It also treats two dissimilar subjects as equivalent without valid basis (false analogy).

sentence: As you grow older, do your calf muscles become cow muscles?
details: The question equivocates on the word 'calf', using it both as the name of a leg muscle and as a young cow, creating a false premise that the two are the same and leading to invalid reasoning.

sentence: I see poached eggs on breakfast menus all the time. Why isn't this illegal?
details: The argument relies on the equivocation of the term "poached eggs", confusing the culinary method of cooking eggs with the illegal act of poaching (stealing) eggs. It also rests on a false premise that a term implying criminal activity must render the dish illegal.

sentence: It's 365 days until Christmas. Why do people already have their lights up?
details: The statement assumes without justification that it is exactly 365 days until Christmas, which is almost certainly false and forms the basis of the critic’s question. This unfounded assumption leads to a flawed argument about the timing of holiday decorations.

sentence: How did they get the Mississippi River to line up EXACTLY to the state border?
details: The question assumes the river was adjusted to match the state border, but in reality the border was defined along the river’s course. This makes the premise false.

sentence: Why hasn't my golden retriever brought me any gold yet?
details: This question equivocates on the word "golden," treating the breed descriptor as if it meant the dog literally possesses gold, and rests on the false premise that a golden retriever would or should fetch actual gold.

sentence: How do the farmers know when it's time to hang the apples in the trees?
details: The question presumes that farmers hang apples in trees, which is a false or unreasonable assumption since farmers typically pick or harvest apples rather than hang them.

sentence: How can I fine tune my metal detector to only detect when certain bands like Opeth or Slayer are playing near me?
details: This question equivocates on the term 'metal,' treating a device designed to detect physical metal as if it could detect 'metal' music bands. It also rests on the false premise that a metal detector can sense audio or musical performances.

sentence: Why is my new 55' tv only 5' big?
details: The question assumes, as a premise, that a '55\"' TV refers to its physical width, which is false. In television marketing, 55\" denotes the diagonal screen size, not the width. This confusion also stems from equivocation in how the term "inch" is used for diagonal measurement versus actual width.

sentence: If it takes 2 humans to make 1 human, why are there still humans left?
details: The argument assumes that because two people are required to produce one child, the total number of humans must decrease. This mistakes the local reproduction process for the population as a whole (fallacy of composition) and rests on the false premise that parents cease to exist when they have a child, ignoring that parents remain alive and the population can therefore be maintained or grow.

sentence: If we get a new moon every 30 days, why does it always look so old and crater-y?
details: The question equivocates the term "new moon" (a phase of the Moon) with a literally newly created moon, treating "new" as "newly formed" and thus expecting an uncratered surface. This false premise produces the flawed inference.

sentence: Help! I know that water boils at 100 degrees. I currently have a fever of 102. How much longer until all the water in me boils away??
details: The argument assumes without basis that water inside the human body behaves like pure water at 1 atm pressure and will boil away at 100 °C. This is a false premise. It also illegitimately equates boiling water in a kettle with bodily fluids under physiological pressure and binding conditions—an invalid analogy.

sentence: How come soda cans say HI, ME 5¢, but I still pay $1.50 for it?
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption (false premise) that the printing “HI, ME 5¢” on the can indicates its retail price is five cents. In reality, that imprint is a deposit or code, not a sales price. It also equivocates by treating an inanimate label as if it were a literal statement from the can (attributing human speech and intent to an object).

sentence: If an unborn fetus is by definition a part of a woman's body, do the four extra limbs turn her into an arachnid?
details: This argument assumes that a property of a part (extra limbs on a fetus) must apply to the whole (the pregnant woman), which is a fallacy of composition. It also draws an invalid analogy between having multiple limbs and belonging to the arachnid class without considering other defining biological criteria, constituting a false analogy. Finally, it equivocates on the notion of "part"—mistaking the legal or anatomical notion of a fetus as a part of the maternal body for a literal merging of categories—leading to confusion in classification.

sentence: If Ryan Gosling is already 33, how many more years till he becomes Ryan Goose?
details: This is simply a pun on the similarity between the names “Gosling” and “Goose,” and does not involve any logical inference or fallacious reasoning.

sentence: If you use half the ingredients from one bread recipe, and the other half from another, will the resulting loaf be inbread?
details: This question hinges on a pun that treats “in bread” the same as “inbred.” It equivocates on the sound and spelling of the word to suggest a causal link between mixing recipes and genetic inbreeding, and by analogy implies that combining halves of recipes is like combining genetic lines, which is a misleading false analogy.

sentence: If boiling water's temperature is 100 degrees and fire is 800 degrees, can I start a campfire using 8 pots of boiling water?
details: This argument treats temperature as an additive quantity (8 × 100°C = 800°C), which is false. Temperature is an intensive property and cannot be summed across separate objects. The reasoning exemplifies the improper distribution/addition fallacy, relies on a false premise about how temperatures combine, and draws an invalid analogy between quantity of pots and achievable temperature.

sentence: To land on the sun, will NASA be landing at night when it's coolest?
details: This question assumes the premise that one can land on the sun and that the sun has a ‘night’ period when it is cooler. In reality, the sun is a continuous ball of plasma without a night cycle and its surface temperature remains extremely hot. The argument thus rests on a false premise and draws an unwarranted analogy to Earth’s day–night temperature cycle.

sentence: Is burnt water unhealthy? I don't wanna remake the entire dish because my family is hungry.
details: The question assumes that water can be 'burnt,' which is impossible and thus rests on a false premise. It then frames only two options—use the so-called burnt water or remake the entire dish—ignoring the possibility of discarding the burnt portion and simply adding fresh water (false dilemma). Interpreting the metaphorical phrase 'burnt water' literally also reflects a nominal fallacy.

sentence: I parked in my son's parking spot. Do I have Parkinson's?
details: The speaker conflates the phrase 'parking son's spot' with the disease Parkinson's through a play on words (equivocation), and then wrongly infers that parking in a spot causes the disease (false cause).

sentence: Why is everyone so excited about water on mars if we've been mining erasers there for years?
details: The statement rests on the unfounded assumption that erasers have been mined on Mars, which is not supported by any evidence. This false premise undermines the entire argument.

sentence: If Google Fiber is introduced to my area, how will the sewage systems cope?
details: This question assumes without justification that the introduction of a fiber-optic internet service (Google Fiber) will have a direct impact on local sewage infrastructure. There is no causal link between installing high-speed internet and the performance of sewage systems, so inferring one will affect the other is a false cause fallacy. It also rests on a false premise that such a relationship exists.

sentence: Should I switch to Google fiber or stick with Fiber One?
details: This question presents only two options as if they were the only possibilities, ignoring other internet service providers or alternatives.

sentence: Why do other people drive so much worse when I'm drunk?
details: The statement rests on an unfounded assumption that others actually drive worse when the speaker is drunk (false premise). In reality, the speaker’s own impaired perception due to intoxication is causing them to misjudge other drivers, reversing the true cause-and-effect relationship (wrong direction).

sentence: I'm not a tailor or tradesman. Is this tape measure trick normal in these industries, and does it help with “measuring someone up”?
details: The sentence poses a genuine question about industry practice and the meaning of an idiom. It does not assume a false premise, present a flawed inference, or employ any logical fallacy.

sentence: Was Arkansas founded because Kansas exiled all of their pirates?
details: This question rests on the unfounded assumption that Kansas ever had pirates to exile (false premise) and then wrongly asserts a causal link between that exile and the founding of Arkansas without any evidence (false cause).

sentence: If headphones get tangled into a knot within 1 second of being placed into a pocket, how many pockets would you need to place them into repeatedly in order to cause a black hole to form due to the knot density?
details: The argument assumes without evidence that repeatedly tangling headphones can increase material density to black‐hole‐forming levels (a false premise), then infers a causal link between knot density and gravitational collapse (false cause), and implicitly compares knot density with astrophysical mass density despite lacking a valid basis for that comparison (false analogy).

sentence: If I overcook all my food, will I lose weight since I already burnt the calories?
details: This question equivocates on the word “burnt,” using it in the cooking sense (overcooking food) and in the metabolic sense (burning calories). It then commits a false cause fallacy by assuming that cooking away calories causes weight loss in the body.

sentence: If a single Polish male and a single Polish female get married, does that make a dipole or a magnet?
details: The statement equivocates by treating 'Polish' (nationality) as if it were 'pole' (magnetic pole), and then draws a false analogy that marrying two Poles produces a magnetic dipole.

sentence: How do they mine for tinfoil without it tearing?
details: The question assumes that tinfoil is directly mined from the earth, which is incorrect. In reality, aluminum foil is produced by rolling processed aluminum ingots, not extracted in foil form.

sentence: How much carbon dating should I do before I'm ready for carbon marriage?
details: The sentence conflates two distinct meanings of “dating” (scientific carbon‐14 dating vs. romantic courtship) and treats them as if they were the same concept. This is an equivocation error. It also takes a figurative play on words literally, which aligns with the nominal fallacy.

sentence: It is said that a cigarette takes away 7 to 11 minutes of a persons life. Why don't smokers just smoke faster to live longer?
details: The statement equivocates on what it means to ‘take away 7–11 minutes’ by treating that loss as if it were a rate per minute of smoking rather than a fixed cost per cigarette (equivocation). It also wrongly infers a causal link between smoking speed and life expectancy (false cause) and inverts the actual cause–effect relationship by assuming that shorter smoking time reduces harm, instead of recognizing that the act of smoking itself is the cause (wrong direction).

sentence: If we take all the oil out of the ground won't the Earth have trouble spinning on its axle?
details: This argument rests on the unfounded assumption that the mass of underground oil is significant enough to affect Earth's rotational inertia (false premise) and thus that removing it would cause the planet to spin improperly (false cause). In reality, the mass of oil is negligible relative to the mass of the Earth, and extracting it would not measurably alter Earth's rotation.

sentence: Why is the hemo goblin making my blood turn red? I don't like it tell him to stop
details: The statement relies on an unfounded assumption that a ‘hemo goblin’ exists and is responsible for turning the blood red (false premise), and it then infers a causal relationship solely from that assumption without evidence (false cause).

sentence: Im leaving town, but my cream says apply locally. Can I take it with me or is it too much of a risk?
details: The term “locally” is used in two different senses: one meaning 'apply to a specific part of the body' and the other meaning 'use only within your current town'. This equivocation creates a misleading interpretation of the instruction.

sentence: Why does dust not fall on the shaded area of my laptop?
details: The question assumes without evidence that shading alone prevents dust from settling (false premise) and then seeks a causal explanation for an effect that may not exist, implying a direct causal link between shade and absence of dust (false cause).

sentence: If I give my Ford Fiesta Adderall, Will it become a Ford Focus?
details: This treats the figurative effect of Adderall improving focus as if it could literally change the model name of a car. It mistakes a metaphorical label for a real transformation (nominal fallacy) and draws an invalid analogy between a human brain’s response to a drug and an inanimate object’s model designation (false analogy).

sentence: If a synchronised Swimmer drowns, do all the rest have to drown?
details: This question assumes that what happens to one member of a synchronized group (drowning) must happen to all members. It erroneously treats a part’s outcome as applying to the whole (fallacy of composition), rests on the unfounded premise that group members are bound to the fate of one individual (false premise), and implies a causal connection where none exists (false cause).

sentence: When I watch a meteor shower, does it feel violated?
details: The question assumes without justification that a meteor shower can experience feelings (false premise). It also treats a figurative expression as if it were literal, attributing human emotions to a natural phenomenon (nominal fallacy).

sentence: What was so dangerous about the 1800s that everybody from then is now dead?
details: The question assumes that all deaths of people born in the 1800s result from extraordinary danger in that century, conflating inevitable mortality over time with hazard and ignoring the normal human life span.

sentence: I just froze myself at absolute zero. I think I'm 0k, should I feel this way?
details: The statement assumes an impossible physical scenario—that a human can reach absolute zero—constituting a false premise. It also plays on the double meaning of "0k" (0 Kelvin vs. "okay"), an equivocation.

sentence: If electricity comes from electrons, does morality come from morons?
details: The argument equates two unrelated concepts purely on the basis of similar word structure. It assumes that because electricity is derived from electrons, morality must similarly derive from morons. This is a classic false analogy. It also involves a mild equivocation by playing on the linguistic similarity between ‘electrons’ and ‘morons’ rather than any real conceptual link.

sentence: Millennials seem to be living in a bubble. What is the refractive index of this bubble and can we calculate the distortion of reality looking through the bubble.
details: The phrase “living in a bubble” is a metaphor for social isolation, not a literal physical bubble. Treating it as if it has optical properties commits the nominal fallacy by interpreting a figurative expression as literal. It also relies on the false premise that such a physical bubble exists and draws an unjustified comparison between social attitudes and optical refraction (false analogy). Finally, the word “bubble” shifts meaning between metaphorical and literal uses, causing equivocation.

sentence: People never seem to disappear in the Bermuda Triangle anymore. Has it reached full capacity?
details: The statement infers that the absence of disappearances is due to the Triangle being 'full', improperly attributing a causal relationship without evidence (false cause) and relying on the unfounded assumption that there is a capacity limit for disappearances (false premise).

sentence: If pineapples have enzymes that degrade meat, can I throw one at a cow to give it low self esteem?
details: The argument wrongly assumes that because pineapple enzymes can break down meat, throwing a pineapple at a cow will causally produce low self-esteem. There is no evidence or mechanism linking enzymatic meat degradation to an animal’s psychological state, making this both a false causal inference and based on an unfounded premise.

sentence: Where can I get ear plugs like the one shown, to protect my hearing from the next Big Bang?
details: The question treats 'Big Bang' as a literal audible explosion that will produce a sound wave one could block with ear plugs, which misinterprets a scientific term metaphorically (nominal fallacy) and rests on the unfounded assumption that such an event would generate a hearable noise needing ear protection (false premise).

sentence: I had my mid-life crisis at 20. Does that mean I'll die at 40?
details: The assumption that experiencing a mid-life crisis at age 20 means you are at the literal midpoint of your life is an unfounded premise. It treats a psychological event as a definitive marker of lifespan (false premise), implies a causal link between having the crisis and dying at twice that age (false cause), and draws an invalid parallel between the timing of a mid-life crisis and actual life expectancy (false analogy).

sentence: What is Discrete Math and what exactly are trying to hide?
details: The question presupposes without evidence that the respondent is hiding something, creating a false premise that leads the reasoning astray.

sentence: If practice makes you better at things, why does pouring shots get harder the more I do it?
details: This question misapplies the general rule that “practice makes perfect” to a situation where other factors (fatigue, intoxication) degrade performance. It treats pouring more shots as pure practice when in fact the worsening is caused by unrelated factors, thus committing an accident fallacy by ignoring exceptions and a false cause fallacy by attributing the decline directly to practice.

sentence: Is a capsized ship small enough for a boat-in-a-bottle?
details: The question rests on an unfounded assumption that a real ship—capsized or not—could be small enough to fit inside a bottle, which contradicts the actual size of ships.

sentence: Is it safe to channel surf during Shark Week?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that watching TV’s Shark Week poses a real shark‐attack risk (false premise).
