It equivocates by treating ‘surf’ in ‘channel surf’ as if it meant literal ocean surfing. It also interprets the metaphorical title ‘Shark Week’ as if it signified actual sharks in the room (nominal fallacy).

sentence: How did the thesaurus survive the dinosaur extinction?
details: The question assumes that a thesaurus—a human‐made reference book—existed during the time of the dinosaurs. That premise is unfounded and makes the question logically invalid.

sentence: Why do aircraft carriers use catapults when the trebuchet is the superior siege engine?
details: This question commits a false analogy by inappropriately comparing medieval trebuchets to modern steam or electromagnetic catapults on naval vessels, ignoring differences in scale, medium, materials, and operational requirements. It also rests on a false premise that trebuchets are inherently ‘superior’ without considering context or engineering constraints specific to aircraft launch on carriers.

sentence: Who liked Saturn enough to put rings on it?
details: The question assumes without evidence that Saturn’s rings were intentionally placed by someone who ‘liked’ the planet. In reality, the rings formed naturally through astrophysical processes, so attributing them to a liking agent is an unfounded premise (false premise) and misattributes causation (false cause).

sentence: I've been sick lately and people keep telling me to drink a lot of fluids. I just drank a half bottle of lighter fluid and now I feel worse. What should I drink instead?
details: The advice to “drink a lot of fluids” uses “fluids” in the medical sense of safe, drinkable liquids. The person equivocates that term to mean any fluid, including lighter fluid, and thus misapplies the advice. This is primarily an equivocation fallacy, with an element of accident in misapplying a general recommendation without considering the exception that not all fluids are safe to ingest.

sentence: Seen a lot of burgers advertised as '100% Beef'. What parts of a cow are the lettuce, bread and sauce made of?
details: The question treats the claim “100% Beef” (which correctly refers only to the patty) as if it applied to every component of the burger. This is a fallacy of composition (inferring that what holds for one part holds for the whole), rests on a false premise about the scope of the label, and equivocates by shifting the meaning of “100% Beef” from the patty to the entire sandwich.

sentence: Will this debarking device work on my yapping dog?
details: The input is a direct question asking about the efficacy of a device. It does not assert a premise or draw a conclusion and so contains no logical error or fallacious reasoning.

sentence: If sound can't travel on vacuum, why my vacuum go BRUUUUUUUUUU?
details: This argument equivocates on the word 'vacuum,' using it first to mean empty space (through which sound cannot travel) and then to mean a vacuum cleaner (which makes a loud noise). The shift in meaning creates a misleading conclusion.

sentence: If water only has 3 states, does that mean that the USA is 17 times better than water?
details: This argument equivocates on the term "states" (confusing water's physical phases with political subdivisions of the USA) and then draws a false analogy by treating quantity of 'states' as a measure of overall quality or superiority.

sentence: If light travels faster than sound, how come I can hear my parents screaming at me before I see what I did wrong?
details: This question assumes that because light travels faster than sound one must always see an event before hearing any reaction tied to it. In reality the scream is generated after the parents perceive your action, introducing a delay. The argument also commits an inverse error by treating “if light is faster then seeing must precede hearing” as a biconditional and rejecting the premise when the order is reversed.

sentence: How did The Proclaimers walk 500 miles if Scotland uses the metric system?
details: This question rests on the false premise that because Scotland officially uses the metric system, its people cannot refer to or measure distances in miles. In reality, miles are still used culturally and colloquially, so the conclusion is flawed. It also commits the accident fallacy by misapplying the general rule about metric usage to a specific case where exceptions exist.

sentence: Why is everyone still flipping out about 9/11? It's just 0.8181.
details: The speaker conflates the historical event “9/11” with the mathematical expression 9/11 (≈0.8181), treating a date of a major tragedy as if it were merely a number. This is equivocation—shifting between two meanings of “9/11”—and a nominal fallacy by taking a figurative reference to a terrorist attack as a literal arithmetic statement.

sentence: Why does my birth certificate say 1990 when my birthday was just 2 weeks ago?
details: The writer equivocates on the word "birthday," treating it as the actual date of birth rather than the annual anniversary. This creates the false premise that celebrating a birthday two weeks ago means one was born then, despite the birth certificate correctly recording a 1990 birth date.

sentence: Can colourblind people see red flags in their relationships?
details: This question treats the idiomatic expression 'red flags' (meaning warning signs) as though it were a literal red object, committing a nominal fallacy by interpreting a metaphor as a physical phenomenon. It also equivocates between the figurative and literal meanings of 'see red flags' and rests on the false premise that perceiving relationship issues requires the ability to distinguish the color red.

sentence: I accidentally bought baby wipes instead of regular ones. What should I feed them so they grow into healthy mature wipes?
details: The question treats inanimate baby wipes as if they were living organisms that can be fed and will grow, which is a false premise. It also draws an invalid comparison between wipes and living creatures (false analogy) and takes the term 'baby' in 'baby wipes' literally rather than figuratively (nominal fallacy).

sentence: Why can't we simply just blow up the moon to solve the earth's werewolf problem?
details: This argument assumes without evidence that blowing up the moon is both feasible and that it would eliminate werewolves (false premise). It also commits a false cause fallacy by asserting that removing the moon’s phases would directly prevent werewolf transformations, ignoring other factors and the catastrophic consequences of destroying the moon.

sentence: If I live on Earth, how come my doctor insists I have Mercury poisoning?
details: This statement equivocates on “Mercury,” treating it as the planet rather than the toxic metal, and rests on the false premise that living on Earth precludes any form of mercury exposure or poisoning.

sentence: Why is Alaska cold and Hawaii hot if they are at the same latitude according to this map?
details: The question is based on the incorrect assumption that Alaska and Hawaii lie on the same latitude. Since that premise is false, the reasoning built on it is invalid.

sentence: After reaching their twenties, what causes this sudden drop in teenage pregnancy?
details: This question assumes that teenage pregnancy continues into individuals’ twenties, but by definition teenagers are ages 13–19. After age 19 there can be no teenage pregnancies, so the premise is unfounded and invalidates the inquiry.

sentence: Any doctors know how to cure an air mattress of a potentially malignant tumor?
details: The statement assumes that an inanimate object (an air mattress) can develop a malignant tumor, which is a false premise. It also treats the air mattress as if it were a living organism requiring medical treatment, a false analogy.

sentence: I asked my chemistry prof if his organic chemistry course was *certified* organic and he just stared at me. How can I be sure it doesn't contain pesticides?
details: The argument equivocates on the word 'organic,' conflating its chemical sense (carbon-containing compounds) with its agricultural sense (grown without synthetic pesticides). This creates a false analogy (treating a course like produce) and rests on the false premise that a course could be certified 'organic' in the pesticide-free farming sense.

sentence: 9 years ago my sister was 1 and I was 11 (11 times her age). Now, she's 10 and I'm 20 (only twice her age). How many years until we are the same age?
details: The argument assumes it is possible for two people with a fixed age difference to become the same age. In reality, the age gap remains constant (10 years) over time, so they will never be the same age. This rests on a false premise that a solution exists.

sentence: My doctor told me to take 1-2 pills every day. How do I take -1 pill?
details: The question is based on the unfounded assumption that one can consume a negative number of pills, which is impossible. This invalid premise makes the reasoning nonsensical.

sentence: How do stadiums get so hot when they're filled with fans?
details: This is a genuine causal question seeking explanation, not an argument that commits any logical fallacy.

sentence: How many metric miles has Science travelled when Science has gone too far?
details: This question treats the metaphorical phrase “Science has gone too far” as if Science could literally travel a measurable distance (nominal fallacy). It further assumes that an abstract concept can be quantified in metric miles (false premise) and shifts the meaning of “travel” between its metaphorical and literal senses (equivocation).

sentence: If our brains get too smart, could they become self-aware and take over our bodies?
details: This question rests on the unwarranted assumption that simply increasing intelligence guarantees self-awareness and that self-awareness would lead to body takeover. It posits a causal chain without evidence, making both the initial premise and the inferred causation fallacious.

sentence: Why is being xenophobic such a taboo? Don't the Xenomorphs pose a real threat to our species?
details: The question assumes without evidence that all Xenomorphs inherently pose a real threat to humanity (false premise) and generalizes the dangerous behavior of some individuals to the entire species (fallacy of composition).

sentence: Going to Canada for the vacation, so I need to know. Is it true that if you die in Canada, you die in real life?
details: The statement assumes an unsubstantiated causal relationship between dying in Canada and dying in real life, reflecting a false cause fallacy built on the false premise that death in one context automatically entails death in another.

sentence: In 2006, we had Super Bowl XL. In just under a month, we'll have Super Bowl L. How does an abstract concept like a sporting event lose a shirt size in ten years? Is it all that exercise?
details: The statement equivocates on the symbols "XL" and "L": it shifts from their intended use as Roman numerals for Super Bowl numbering to clothing sizes, creating a misleading comparison (equivocation). It also takes a figurative notion of 'losing a size' and treats it as a literal shirt size change (nominal fallacy).

sentence: If this scale weighs up to 400 pounds, why can I hold it in one hand?
details: The phrase “weighs up to 400 pounds” is being equivocated: on the scale it means maximum capacity, but the speaker treats it as the actual weight of the scale itself (a false premise). Thus the argument fails by confusing capacity with the device’s own weight.

sentence: I have a megaphone. Am I better off converting it to one million phones or one trillion microphones?
details: The question frames only two options—converting the megaphone into phones or microphones—while ignoring any other possibilities (false dilemma). It also rests on the questionable assumption that one can meaningfully convert a single megaphone into those devices (false premise).

sentence: Apparently we can't colonise venus because there is too much pressure. Why doesn't everyone just chill out about it?
details: The claim that high pressure alone makes colonizing Venus impossible is presented as an unquestionable fact, ignoring possible technological solutions. It rests on an unfounded assumption rather than supporting evidence.

sentence: How do identical twins know which one they are?
details: This is a neutral question about personal identification and does not present any argument or reasoning that involves a logical error or fallacy.

sentence: How long does it take a pair of ear pods to grow?
details: The question assumes without basis that ear pods—nonliving, manufactured objects—can grow like living organisms, which is an unfounded premise.

sentence: When I search on Amazon I am limited to 24 results per page. Does this have something to do with deforestation?
details: The argument equivocates on the term "Amazon", conflating the online retailer with the rainforest, and then commits a false cause by implying one causes the other without any evidence.

sentence: Statistics say a person is run over every 5 minutes, how does that person survive being run over so often?
details: The argument equivocates on “a person,” treating a generic statistic about different individuals as if it referred to one single person repeatedly. It also rests on the false premise that the same person must be run over every five minutes, which misinterprets the statistical claim.

sentence: Why didn't anyone take anti-depressants to prevent the great depression?
details: This question equivocates the word “depression” by treating an economic downturn as a medical condition; it commits the nominal fallacy by interpreting a metaphorical term literally, and it assumes a causal link between taking anti-depressants and preventing an economic crisis (false cause).

sentence: Was Steve Jobs' death a result of his line of work, as an Apple a day kept his doctor away?
details: This argument equivocates on the word “Apple,” conflating the fruit in the proverb “an apple a day keeps the doctor away” with the company Apple. It then commits a false cause fallacy by suggesting Jobs’s work at Apple led to his death. It also treats a figurative expression literally, a form of the nominal fallacy.

sentence: If a doctor ate an apple a day would he lose his medical license?
details: The question assumes a causal link between eating an apple and losing a medical license without any basis. It posits that apple consumption could lead to license revocation, which is unfounded (false cause) and rests on an unreasonable assumption (false premise).

sentence: Why Harry Potter didn't just conjured up an AK-47 and shoot up Voldemort?
details: This question assumes—without any basis in the rules of the Harry Potter universe—that Harry could magically produce a complex modern weapon like an AK-47 (false premise). It also treats the act of conjuring simple magical objects as equivalent to manufacturing a firearm, drawing an unwarranted analogy (false analogy).

sentence: If triangles are the strongest shape, why does Good Year make tires out of circles?
details: This argument misapplies the general rule that triangles are the strongest shape to a context where rolling function, material properties, and manufacturing needs override static structural strength (accident fallacy). It also rests on an unreasonable assumption that strength alone dictates tire design (false premise) and treats the comparison of static structural strength and dynamic wheel performance as if they were directly analogous (false analogy).

sentence: How many kilobytes in a trilobyte?
details: The question presumes the existence of a unit called ‘trilobyte,’ which is unfounded and thus the premise of the question is false.

sentence: Why doesn't my mirror work in the dark?
details: This question rests on the unfounded assumption that a mirror should produce a visible reflection without light. Mirrors reflect light, so in darkness there is no light to reflect, making the premise invalid.

sentence: Would there be more elephants around if we stopped poaching them and tried alternative cooking methods?
details: The question links stopping poaching with trying alternative cooking methods as if both would increase elephant numbers, but the second link is unfounded and creates an invalid causal assumption.

sentence: Caesium has a half life of 30 years. If I divide an atom of Caesium into 10 parts, will a half life of 3 be confirmed?
details: The argument assumes that splitting an atom of Cs into ten parts will reduce its half-life in direct proportion. This is a false premise because half-life is an intrinsic nuclear property, not dependent on sample size. It also wrongly infers causation (false cause) between dividing the atom and decay rate, and analogizes linear scaling of physical size to nuclear decay (false analogy).

sentence: They say snake venom is the most toxic thing in the world, but what about some Dota 2 players?
details: The argument equivocates on the term 'toxic', shifting from its literal chemical meaning (snake venom) to a figurative social meaning (toxic behavior of players), and thus draws a false analogy between two unrelated senses of toxicity.

sentence: Can YouTube slow down time? I just read that they upload 300 hours of video every 1 minute.
details: The argument treats YouTube’s upload rate (300 hours of video per one minute of real time) as if it implied a physical slowing of time. This equivocates between video hours and actual time, and then infers a causal effect (time dilation) from a statistical upload rate, which rests on an unfounded premise.

sentence: It's a well known fact that whatever doesn't kill you makes you stronger. I've been watching tv for a week straight, and haven't gained any muscle. Is my TV going to kill me?
details: The speaker treats the figurative aphorism as a literal causal rule (nominal fallacy) and then commits an inverse error by inferring from 'I did not get stronger' (~B) that 'the TV must kill me' (~A), reversing the original implication.

sentence: Do monitor lizards come in HDMI connection?
details: The question equivocates on the word "monitor", using it both for the reptile and for an electronic display, and rests on the false premise that a lizard could have an HDMI connection.

sentence: How can I find the friend zone? I need friends
details: The user is asking for advice, not making an argument, so no logical fallacy or error is present.

sentence: If America evolved from England, why is there still England?
details: The question is built on the unfounded assumption that one country can ‘evolve’ from another in a biological sense (false premise). It also improperly treats political history as if it were biological evolution (false analogy) and equivocates on the term “evolve,” using it in a metaphorical sense but expecting literal interpretations (equivocation).

sentence: If the law of conservation of energy says energy can't be destroyed then why do we have to pay for more every month?
details: This question equivocates between the scientific principle that energy cannot be created or destroyed in a closed system and the economic practice of billing for energy consumption. It rests on the false premise that conservation implies unlimited, free availability of usable energy, and it incorrectly analogizes the physical law to the need to pay for delivered energy services.

sentence: How is mercury a liquid at room temperature, yet a large solid when orbiting close to the sun?
details: The sentence conflates two different meanings of “mercury” (the liquid metal and the planet), committing equivocation by treating them as the same. It also implicitly draws a false analogy by assuming that properties of the metal should apply to the planet.

sentence: Could the Space Needle be used to vaccinate against asteroids?
details: This question equivocates on “needle,” conflating the Space Needle (a tower) with a medical needle, assumes without basis that a structure can administer vaccines (false premise), and draws an invalid analogy between vaccinating living organisms and protecting against inanimate asteroids (false analogy).

sentence: My wisdom teeth are coming in. How much longer until my GPA goes up?
details: The speaker equivocates on the word “wisdom,” treating the growth of wisdom teeth (a biological event) as if it directly conferred intellectual wisdom and thus caused a rise in GPA. This is a form of equivocation. Additionally, it assumes a causal link without evidence (false cause) and draws an invalid comparison between dental development and academic performance (false analogy).

sentence: Is it true that Thomas Edison got the idea for electricity when he accidentally left a fork in his microwave?
details: This claim is based on a factually impossible scenario (Edison lived long before microwaves were invented), so its premise is false. It also wrongly attributes Edison’s discovery of electricity to a microwave accident, creating a spurious causal link between two unrelated events.

sentence: If steak is so rare, why is it so commonly found in stores?
details: The sentence equivocates on the word 'rare', using it to mean both 'infrequently occurring' and 'cooked to a low internal temperature', thus misleading the argument.

sentence: WHY DOES MY HEARING AID THAT WAS MADE IN CHINA UNDERSTAND ENGLISH HERE IN AMERICA?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that a hearing aid 'understands' English. In reality, a hearing aid merely amplifies or processes sound, it does not possess cognitive language comprehension (false premise). This also confuses a figurative use of 'understand' with a literal ability to comprehend language (nominal fallacy).

sentence: If I climb Mount Everest is my life all downhill from there?
details: The phrase "all downhill" is used both literally (after summiting, one must descend) and figuratively (things become easier or decline). Conflating these meanings makes this an equivocation, and treating the metaphor as literal invokes a nominal fallacy.

sentence: Farmers of Reddit, what is the typical growing season for telephone poles? It seems pretty early for planting to me.
details: The question is based on the unfounded assumption that telephone poles are plants with a growing season (false premise). It also treats telephone poles as if they share growth characteristics with crops, which is an invalid comparison (false analogy).

sentence: Do STEM Cells always function better than liberal arts cells in repairing diverse tissue? What can you actually do with a liberal arts cell?
details: The argument assumes without basis that ‘liberal arts cells’ exist and function analogously to stem cells (false premise). It then compares two non‐equivalent entities (stem cells vs ‘liberal arts cells’), constituting a false analogy. The phrase ‘liberal arts cell’ is taken literally despite being a metaphorical or playful use (nominal fallacy). Finally, the term 'cell' is used ambiguously, shifting between educational and biological senses (equivocation).

sentence: The tesla Elon Musk send into space is travelling with 121,600 kmh (75,600 mph). Considering that a Tesla can drive for 300km without recharging, where does it recharge 400 times an hour?
details: The argument rests on a false premise by assuming a Tesla in space must recharge every 300 km just as it does on Earth, ignoring that in the vacuum of space it coasts without expending battery power to maintain speed. It then commits a false cause fallacy by inferring a recharging requirement solely from the ratio of distance to range, and a false analogy by treating space travel identically to terrestrial driving.

sentence: Why does dental floss taste like blood?
details: The question presumes that the flavor of dental floss itself is like blood (false premise), when in reality any blood taste comes from bleeding gums coating the floss. It also reverses cause and effect (wrong direction) by attributing the taste to the floss rather than to the blood on it.

sentence: If Britain leaves the EU, how will the birds migrate each year?
details: This question assumes without evidence that Britain’s departure from the EU will affect bird migration, attributing a causal link where none is established (false cause). It also relies on an unfounded assumption that political membership directly influences natural migration routes (false premise).

sentence: If people who eat nuts generally weigh less, why is my mom so fat?
details: This statement takes a general statistical trend (nut eaters tend to weigh less) and misapplies it to a single case without considering exceptions (accident fallacy). It also treats correlation as causation, assuming nut consumption directly causes lower weight (false cause), and implies that if eating nuts leads to less weight, then excess weight must mean nut consumption did not occur or must be flawed (inverse error).

sentence: Why do sharks only attack me when I'm wet?
details: The question assumes a causal link between being wet and shark attacks based on the correlation that attacks occur while in water, which is a false premise. This also represents a false cause fallacy by treating a coincident condition as the cause.

sentence: If the Earth stopped rotating on its axis at 7 am, would McDonald's serve breakfast forever?
details: This question rests on the unfounded assumption that McDonald’s breakfast hours are determined solely by the planet’s rotation (a false premise) and that stopping Earth’s spin would therefore extend breakfast indefinitely (a false cause), ignoring how timekeeping and service schedules actually work.

sentence: If humans are 75% water, and I drink water, does that make me a cannibal?
details: This argument treats water consumed as if it were equivalent to human flesh because humans are largely water. It falsely draws an analogy between two distinct categories (drinking water vs. eating human tissue), assumes what is true of the whole (humans contain water) applies to the part (water itself), and equivocates on the term “water” by ignoring that the water in a human body is not composed of human cells.

sentence: If crashing at twice the speed is four times as bad, does this mean that if I crash at twice the speed while in reverse, it'll be four times as good?
details: The argument assumes that reversing the direction of the crash inverts its effect, as if harm were a signed quantity rather than depending on the square of speed. In reality, kinetic energy—and thus crash severity—is proportional to speed squared regardless of direction, so going in reverse is not ‘good’ but equally harmful. This misattributes causality by reversing the cause–effect relationship (wrong direction), treats forward and backward crashes as analogous in a way that they are not (false analogy), and assumes that reversing the input (direction) reverses the output (inverse error).

sentence: Why is the element of surprise not on the periodic table? Is it hiding somewhere?
details: The question hinges on an equivocation of the word “element,” using its figurative sense (a component) and its chemical sense interchangeably. This creates a false premise that the “element of surprise” could literally appear on the periodic table.

sentence: How can something be 100% cotton AND 100% algodon?
details: The question assumes that “cotton” and the Spanish word “algodón” are two different materials, when in fact they are the same substance expressed in different languages. This is a false premise built on equivocation—inaccurately treating identical terms as if they differ—and a nominal fallacy by misreading a translation as a literal contradiction.

sentence: Where does the air go when an anti air missile explodes?
details: This is a factual question about the physical behavior of air during an explosion and does not rely on any faulty reasoning or invalid assumptions.

sentence: If I'm 34 and I haven't touched any of my daylight savings in my entire life, how much is that worth to your average scientist who makes solar panels? Should I sell now or keep saving?
details: This question rests on a false premise that ‘untouched daylight savings’ can be quantified as a tradable asset with monetary value to a solar-panel scientist; it equivocates on the term “savings” (mixing the idea of time‐shift in clocks with financial savings); and it commits a false analogy by implying that unused daylight saving time behaves like financial capital that one can ‘sell’ or ‘keep saving’.

sentence: How am I supposed to test my new anti-diabetes tablets if the control group on the sugar-pill placebo keep dying?
details: The speaker implies that the sugar‐pill placebo is causing the deaths in the control group and therefore prevents testing. In reality, it is the absence of an effective treatment (not the placebo itself) that leads to mortality in diabetic patients. This misattributes causation (false cause), reverses cause and effect by blaming the placebo for deaths instead of lack of treatment (wrong direction), and rests on the unfounded premise that the inert placebo actively kills subjects (false premise).

sentence: My blood type is A+, yet i'm still failing college
details: This statement implies a causal link between having blood type A+ and performing well in college, which is unfounded. There is no logical or evidential basis to connect blood type with academic success, so it commits a false cause fallacy. It also rests on the false premise that blood type should determine educational outcomes.

sentence: I just washed my dog with conditioner, but it still doesn't drool when I ring a bell. Why?
details: The speaker confuses 'conditioner' (a grooming product) with 'conditioning' (Pavlovian training). This is an equivocation on the word 'conditioner,' which leads them to draw a false analogy between washing a dog and conditioning it to drool, and ultimately to a false cause by assuming the bath should produce a learned drooling response.

sentence: If I eat pasta and antipasto at the same time, will my stomach be annihilated? Or do the vowels make a difference?
details: The argument mistakenly treats the prefix "anti" in antipasto as indicating a literal opposition that would annihilate pasta in the stomach (equivocation). It also misinterprets the word’s name as a literal description (nominal fallacy) and is based on the unfounded assumption that antipasto physically counters pasta (false premise).

sentence: If baby shampoo says 'no more tears', how much should I consume to cure my depression?
details: The argument treats the shampoo’s slogan “no more tears” as a literal medical claim that ingesting the product will stop emotional crying and cure depression. This confuses a figurative expression with a literal effect (nominal fallacy), equivocates on the meaning of “tears,” relies on an unfounded assumption that a marketing tagline is a health claim (false premise), and wrongly infers causation without evidence (false cause).

sentence: There's a Stairway to Heaven and a Highway to Hell. Does that mean all people in wheelchairs/who cannot climb stairs are automatically going to hell?
details: This argument treats the metaphorical “Stairway to Heaven” and “Highway to Hell” as literal paths, assuming that inability to climb stairs forces a person onto the highway to hell. 1) Nominal fallacy: it misunderstands figurative expressions as literal. 2) False premise: it assumes without basis that reaching heaven requires climbing actual stairs. 3) False dilemma: it presents only two literal routes (stairs vs highway) as the sole outcomes, ignoring other possibilities.

sentence: How can Dora the Explorer hear me over TV? Is she the only one or other TV people just rude?
details: This question assumes without evidence that a fictional character can literally hear the viewer speaking through the TV (false premise). It then presents only two options—that Dora alone is capable or all other characters are merely rude—ignoring any other explanations (false dilemma).

sentence: The Titanic wreck has soo many broken parts, how did it stay afloat for so long?
details: The question assumes that the extensive damage visible on the sunken wreck existed while the ship was still afloat. In reality, most of that damage occurred during the sinking event. This is a false premise (assuming an unfounded condition) and also reverses cause and effect (wrong direction), treating the aftermath of the sinking as if it were the pre‐sinking condition.

sentence: If 30 Seconds to Mars was formed in 1998, why is it that 17 years later, we have yet to land on the Red Planet?
details: The argument draws an invalid comparison between forming a music band and achieving a Mars landing. It assumes these two events are comparable in terms of resources, goals, and constraints (false analogy) and rests on the unfounded premise that their timelines should align (false premise), making the inference invalid.

sentence: Why do we spend billions on drug research instead of just using the Placebo Effect to cure everything?
details: The argument rests on the false premise that the placebo effect can cure all illnesses, which is unfounded. It also commits a false dilemma by presenting only two options—expensive drug research or universal placebo cures—ignoring other valid medical treatments. Finally, it makes a false cause error by implying that because placebos sometimes produce benefits, they are sufficient to cure everything.

sentence: Is it possible my Memory Foam Mattress has Alzheimer's?
details: This question assumes that an inanimate mattress can suffer from Alzheimer’s, a human medical condition, which is a false premise. It also improperly analogizes human memory loss to mattress performance without a valid basis.

sentence: If swimming is such good exercise, why are whales so fat?
details: The argument commits the accident fallacy by misapplying the general rule that swimming is good exercise to whales, ignoring that whales carry thick blubber for insulation and have very different biology. It also relies on a false analogy between humans and whales, assuming exercise affects both species identically, and implies a false cause by concluding that whales’ fatness disproves swimming’s exercise benefits, overlooking other factors.

sentence: I've read somewhere that one could last until the end of their life without oxygen. Is that true?
details: The claim rests on the unfounded assumption that humans can survive life without oxygen, which contradicts well-established biological facts about cellular respiration and makes the argument invalid.

sentence: If humans share 99.9% of DNA, does that make me 99.9% Jesus?
details: This argument illegitimately equates DNA similarity with proportional identity (false analogy), rests on a mistaken assumption about what 99.9% genetic overlap implies for personal identity (false premise), and assumes that what is true of parts (gene-by-gene similarity) applies directly to the whole (personhood) (fallacy of composition).

sentence: Wouldn't the easiest way to improve fuel economy be reducing the length of a mile?
details: The argument equivocates on the term “mile,” treating it as a variable rather than a fixed unit of distance to falsely ‘improve’ fuel economy by redefining the measurement. It also relies on the false premise that altering a distance unit changes the actual efficiency of a vehicle.

sentence: If almost all money is digital, and digital data can be compressed. Can we use Winrar to reduce the national dept?
details: This argument treats digital money as if it were ordinary data files that can be losslessly compressed by Winrar, which is false. It falsely assumes that money’s digital representation determines its economic value or supply (false premise) and equates monetary units with generic data (false analogy). It also implies that compressing data would causally reduce national debt (false cause) and relies on an ambiguous sense of "compressing" value rather than storage size (equivocation).

sentence: Here in my country markets can't provide free plastic bags anymore, and the alleged reason is to protect nature. But what about the harm done to animals that can't afford plastic bags and can't find them in their habitats anymore?
details: The argument assumes without evidence that wild animals need or can 'afford' plastic bags, which is a false premise. It also draws an invalid comparison between human shopping habits and animal survival needs (false analogy), and uses the term 'afford' ambiguously, switching from the financial sense to a nonsensical application to animals (equivocation).

sentence: If having a shower uses less water than having a bath, why don't we simply fill the bath using a shower?
details: This argument rests on the unfounded assumption (false premise) that a shower’s lower water usage for bathing automatically applies when filling a tub, ignoring flow rates and usage context. It also improperly analogizes shower water usage for cleaning with using the shower head to fill a bath.

sentence: Are FeMales just Men made out of Iron?
details: This question relies on the superficial similarity between the letters “Fe” (the chemical symbol for iron) and the word “female” to conclude that women are literally iron‐made men. That inference is invalid. It is primarily a false analogy—shared labels do not establish shared properties—coupled with equivocation on “Fe” (using its chemical meaning rather than its role in a word) and based on a false premise that name similarity dictates physical composition.

sentence: I just dropped my phone in water so I put it in some rice, how long do I boil the rice for?
details: The speaker confuses the use of raw rice to absorb moisture with the process of cooking rice. They equivocate on the meaning of “rice,” assuming it must be boiled like food, and thus base their question on a false premise that boiling is required for the moisture-absorbing remedy to work.

sentence: Why does water taste so different when it comes from the bottles with 'vodka' written on them?
details: This question assumes that the label on the bottle (the word “vodka”) directly alters the taste of the water. It falsely attributes a causal relationship between labeling and flavor rather than recognizing psychological expectation or context as the real factor.

sentence: Did the Apollo astronauts wait for a full moon so they would have a bigger target to hit?
details: This question assumes that NASA scheduled Apollo launches to coincide with a full moon to make the lunar surface a larger visible target. In fact, mission timing was determined by orbital mechanics, illumination angles, and safety considerations, not by the phase of the moon for target size. The argument therefore rests on a false premise.

sentence: Can I cleanse my hands by clapping REALLY hard to smash bacteria?
details: This question rests on the unfounded assumption that mechanical force from clapping is sufficient to kill or remove bacteria (false premise). It also presumes a causal link between impact and bacterial removal without evidence (false cause), and implicitly compares clapping to effective cleaning methods despite lacking a valid basis for that analogy (false analogy).

sentence: I can't afford a colonoscopy, how much does a semicolonoscopy cost?
details: This argument assumes the existence of a ‘semicolonoscopy,’ a procedure that does not exist, making it a false premise. It also relies on a flawed analogy—that halving the procedure (colon to semi-colon) would halve the cost—constituting a false analogy. Additionally, it treats a playful or figurative term (‘semicolon’) as if it names a real medical procedure, which is a nominal fallacy.

sentence: Are people with pixelated faces genetically predisposed to crime?
details: This question rests on an unfounded assumption that a video-editing effect (pixelation) corresponds to a genetic trait influencing criminal behavior (false premise). It also implies a causal link between pixelated faces and crime without any evidence (false cause).

sentence: If I have 8 bitcoins, will I have a bytecoin?
details: The question assumes without basis that owning bitcoins automatically grants ownership of a different cryptocurrency (Bytecoin). This is a false premise because the two coins are distinct assets. It also relies on a false analogy, treating similarly named cryptocurrencies as if they share all properties, when in fact they do not.

sentence: Would it be possible to build a radio out of a meat other than ham?
details: The question presumes without evidence that ham can serve as a material for a functioning radio, establishing a false premise. It also implies only two options (ham or some other meat), creating a false dilemma by ignoring non‐meat materials entirely.

sentence: Who is Et Al, and why has he researched so many different fields?
details: The question treats “Et Al”—a citation abbreviation meaning “and others”—as if it were a single person, equivocating the term and relying on the false premise that there is an individual named Et Al.

sentence: We've sent several rovers to Mars now and they still haven't sent one back. Is it time to play red rover with a different planet?
details: The statement plays on the double meaning of “rover” (a Mars exploration vehicle vs. a player in the children’s game Red Rover), equivocating on the term and drawing a misleading analogy between scientific missions and a playground game.

sentence: Why are there so many occurrences of homicide-suicide but None of suicide-homicide ?
details: The question wrongly treats ‘homicide–suicide’ (kill then self) and ‘suicide–homicide’ (self then kill) as symmetrical events. It infers that because A→B occurrences exist, then B→A should too (the converse or improper transposition fallacy). It also draws an unwarranted analogy between the two sequences (false analogy) and rests on the mistaken premise that a reverse sequence simply doesn’t occur rather than being impossible once death happens.

sentence: If we generate new cells every seven years, how come our prisons are overcrowded?
details: The argument equivocates on the word "cells": in biology it refers to living cells that regenerate, whereas in prisons it refers to confinement units. This shift in meaning creates a false premise linking cellular regeneration to prison capacity.

sentence: If Pangaea existed 300 million years ago, how do we know it was called Pangaea?
details: This question assumes without justification that the ancient landmass had the modern name 'Pangaea.' That is a false premise, since the name was coined by scientists millions of years later. It also equivocates by shifting the meaning of 'called' from an ancient usage to a modern term.

sentence: If E=MC^2, why doesn't the alphabet go A,B,C,D,MC^2,G?
details: The argument treats the formula E=MC^2 as if it were simply another letter in the sequence, which makes no logical sense. 1) false analogy: it assumes that because letters A–D are symbols in a sequence, the formula MC^2 should also fit that pattern. 2) equivocation: it conflates the letter 'C' in the alphabet with the constant 'c' in the formula E=mc^2. 3) accident fallacy: it misapplies the general rule of alphabetical ordering to an exception (a scientific equation), ignoring that not every symbol qualifies as a letter.

sentence: My grandad has just had hip surgery but he doesn't seem any cooler, did the doctor do it wrong?
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption that hip surgery should make your grandad ‘cooler’ rather than address a medical issue (false premise), and then infers a causal failure by the doctor solely because the unintended effect of increased ‘coolness’ did not occur (false cause).

sentence: Will eating lighter make me lose weight?
details: The question assumes without justification that simply "eating lighter" will cause weight loss, ignoring other factors such as total caloric intake, metabolic rate, nutritional balance, and physical activity. This is an unfounded premise and an improper attribution of direct causation.

sentence: Before lightbulbs were invented, how did people get ideas?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption (false premise) that people needed electric light to form ideas. It also wrongly infers a causal link (false cause) between invention of the lightbulb and idea generation, effectively reversing cause and effect (wrong direction) by implying ideas depended on later technology.

sentence: If antioxidants are essential for stopping free radicals, why do we fight terrorists with weapons and not fruits and vegetables?
details: This argument rests on a false analogy by equating biochemical actions of antioxidants neutralizing free radicals with military actions against terrorists. It also equivocates on the term “fight,” shifting from a chemical context to a physical combat context, thus conflating two unrelated domains.

sentence: Can I use this backyard bug spray in my front yard? What are the risks involved?
details: The query is a straightforward request for usage guidance and risk assessment; it does not rely on any faulty premises or invalid reasoning.

sentence: If the moon is so big. Why does it fit in my iPhone?
details: The statement conflates the actual physical size of the moon with its image on the iPhone screen, using the term ‘moon’ in two different senses and assuming that fitting on a screen implies literal smallness.

sentence: If kilometers are shorter than miles, could I save gas by taking my next road trip in kilometers?
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption that kilometers are physically shorter than miles; in reality, units of measurement do not change the actual distance traveled, so the conclusion about saving gas is invalid.

sentence: A potato is 80% water and I am 72% water. Does that mean I am 152% potato?
details: This argument misuses percentages by treating water‐content ratios from two different wholes as if they could be directly combined into a valid proportion (improper distribution or addition) and draws an invalid comparison between a potato and a human based solely on that shared attribute (false analogy).

sentence: My parents told me I'm retarded, does that mean that I can't catch on fire?
details: The question equivocates on the word "retarded," treating it as if it were the same as "retardant" (a substance that resists fire). This shift in meaning leads to a false analogy and a faulty premise that being labeled "retarded" confers fire resistance, which is invalid reasoning.

sentence: Why are humans so emotionally attach to onions, but not to other vegetables?
details: The question rests on an unfounded assumption that humans generally form emotional attachments to onions but not to other vegetables, which constitutes a false premise.

sentence: We know the effect of smoking on our lungs, but what about the effects of seasoning and brining our lungs?
details: This statement commits a false analogy by treating human lungs like meat that can be seasoned or brined, drawing an invalid comparison between smoking effects and cooking processes. It also rests on a false premise that culinary techniques applicable to food can be meaningfully applied to internal human organs.

sentence: If it's too dangerous to stand on the top step of a ladder, why is there a top step in the first place?
details: The statement highlights a direct inconsistency: the ladder includes a top step (implying it is intended for use), yet simultaneously warns that standing on it is too dangerous. This negates itself by both providing and forbidding the same feature. A secondary issue is the false premise that the mere existence of a feature must imply it is safe to use in all circumstances.

sentence: If 1 woman can give birth to a baby in 9 months, can 9 women give birth to a baby in 1 month?
details: This argument treats the nine‐month gestation period as if it were a divisible, parallelizable task that can be split among multiple women. In reality, pregnancy duration is an intrinsic biological process that cannot be shortened by increasing the number of participants. This is a fallacy of composition (what applies to one individual cannot simply be aggregated to a group), a false analogy (comparing childbirth to a divisible task like manufacturing), and an improper distribution/addition (distributing one woman’s nine months of gestation across nine women to reduce total time).

sentence: Why don't we fix the damage from hurricane sandy by creating a hurricane of the same size, but backwards?
details: The suggestion rests on a false premise that one can artificially create and control a hurricane in reverse. It also commits a false cause fallacy by assuming that generating a hurricane will undo damage rather than cause further destruction, a false analogy by treating complex atmospheric dynamics as if they were reversible like a simple mechanical process, and a wrong direction fallacy by inverting the actual cause‐and‐effect relationship between a hurricane and its damaging impact.

sentence: If I eat a dum dum and a roll of smarties will they cancel each other out and leave me at average intelligence?
details: The argument relies on the unfounded assumption that consuming candies affects intelligence (false premise), infers a causal link without evidence (false cause), and treats their putative effects as additive and canceling without justification (improper distribution or addition).

sentence: If Hand sanitizer kills 99.99% of germs, why don't we just drink it instead of antibiotics when we are sick?
details: This argument treats the effect of hand sanitizer on external surfaces as if it applied identically inside the human body (false analogy). It also relies on the unfounded assumption that ingesting sanitizer would kill internal pathogens safely (false premise). Finally, it equivocates on the term “kill germs,” shifting from external application to internal treatment without justification (equivocation).

sentence: Why do surgeons wash their hands before surgery when they're just going to get them dirty again?
details: This argument equivocates on the term "dirty," conflating visible soil with harmful microbes, and assumes as a false premise that hand washing is pointless if hands will later become contaminated again, ignoring the critical role of reducing infection risk.

sentence: My girlfriend says I'm one in a million. Does that mean that there are 7294 of me out there?
details: The speaker treats the figurative expression "one in a million" as a literal statistical claim rather than a metaphor for uniqueness. This is a nominal fallacy (taking a metaphorical phrase literally), based on a false premise about how idioms work and equivocation over the meaning of "one in a million."

sentence: I heard that pi is irrational, but has anyone ever tried just going up and talking nicely to pi?
details: The term "irrational" is shifted from its precise mathematical meaning (a number not expressible as a ratio of integers) to its everyday sense of being unreasonable or illogical, and the speaker then anthropomorphizes π as if polite speech could alter its nature. This is a classic equivocation on "irrational," and also treats a figurative statement as literal (nominal fallacy).

sentence: I cut myself shaving. How tight should I make this tourniquet around my neck to stop the bleeding?
details: This question misapplies the general rule that tourniquets stop bleeding on limbs to a case (the neck) where the rule does not apply; exceptions (e.g. airway obstruction, cerebral ischaemia) are ignored, making it an accident fallacy. It also assumes by analogy that neck tissue behaves like arm or leg tissue under a tourniquet, which is a false analogy.

sentence: If A picture is worth a thousand words, can I submit a picture of my thesis statement and get full credit for the 1000 word essay?
details: The argument misinterprets the figurative proverb 'a picture is worth a thousand words' as a literal equivalence (nominal fallacy). It then treats that invalid analogy as sufficient to meet an academic requirement (false analogy) and rests on the unfounded assumption that the metaphor can substitute for actual written content (false premise).

sentence: If ice floats, why is Antarctica at the bottom of the earth?
details: The argument rests on the false premise that Antarctica is a floating block of ice like an ice cube in water. It draws an invalid analogy between small ice chunks and an entire continental landmass (false analogy) and assumes that what is true of a part (ice) must be true of the whole (continent) (fallacy of composition).

sentence: If opposites attract why can't I get a good looking girl?
details: The argument equivocates on “attract,” using it first in the sense of personality opposites and then in the sense of physical attractiveness. It also draws a false analogy by assuming a principle about personality differences applies directly to physical appearance.

sentence: why do people always commit crimes near caution tape?
details: The question assumes as fact that crimes always occur near caution tape, which is an unfounded, overgeneralized assumption forming a false premise.

sentence: What % of people who commit suicide regret doing so?
details: The question presumes that individuals who complete suicide can experience regret afterward. Since suicide results in death, it is impossible for them to have subsequent thoughts or feelings, making the premise unfounded and self‐contradictory.

sentence: I was deployed to Afganistan and got shot, but my health isn't regenerating like in Call of duty. Why?
details: The statement assumes that human biology should mirror a video game's health regeneration mechanic (false analogy) and relies on the unfounded premise that game rules apply to real life (false premise).

sentence: How much deeper would the oceans be if sponges didn't grow in them?
details: The question assumes without justification that sponge growth has a meaningful impact on overall ocean depth (false premise) and implies a direct causal link between sponge absence and increased ocean depth without evidence (false cause).

sentence: If the destruction of the Library of Alexandria set us back a thousand years, why do we not destroy more libraries as a means of time travel?
details: The argument assumes that destroying libraries causally results in backward time travel without evidence (false cause), infers that because one library’s destruction had a large effect, destroying more will have proportionally greater effects (false analogy), and treats the impact of destroying each library as directly additive toward achieving time travel (improper distribution or addition).

sentence: They say that global warming is 'off the charts', but couldn't we just fix this by changing the axis scales?
details: The speaker treats the idiom “off the charts” (meaning extremely high) as a literal statement about chart scales. This is a nominal fallacy—misinterpreting a figurative expression as literal—and also an equivocation, using the phrase’s different senses interchangeably.

sentence: If pigs can't fly, how come swine flu?
details: This question relies on equivocation by conflating the verb “fly” (pigs physically flying) with the homophone pun on “flu,” creating a misleading play on words rather than a valid logical inference.

sentence: Why do computers only get viruses? Have they evolved to the point where they are unaffected by bacterial infections?
details: The question equivocates on the term "virus", conflating biological viruses with computer viruses. It also relies on a false analogy between biological infections and software exploits and assumes the unsupported premise that computers could suffer bacterial infections if they evolved.

sentence: If twins share their DNA, what happens if they both need it on the same day?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that DNA is a consumable resource shared between twins that can be "used up" or allocated, which is false (false premise). It also misleadingly compares DNA to transfusable materials like blood, drawing an invalid analogy (false analogy).

sentence: I am trying to raise awareness of a medical condition I have that causes me to lose consciousness for 7 to 9 hours a day. It generally manifests at night. How far along is research for a cure?
details: No logical fallacy detected. The statement is a factual description of a medical condition and a request for information, without any flawed reasoning or invalid inference.

sentence: If being an alcoholic means being addicted to alcohol does being catholic mean being addicted to cats?
details: The argument relies on a punning misuse of the suffix “-holic.” It equivocates on the term “catholic” by treating it as though it follows the same morphological rule as “alcoholic,” and then draws a faulty analogy between addiction to alcohol and an imaginary addiction to cats. In reality, “Catholic” is unrelated to the suffix meaning “addicted to,” so the comparison is invalid.

sentence: If we added 15 days to Gemini and 15 days to Leo would we get rid of Cancer?
details: This question assumes without justification that extending the durations of Gemini and Leo automatically eliminates Cancer. That is a false premise, and it also commits a false cause fallacy by attributing removal of Cancer to merely shifting days without any valid causal link.

sentence: If E=mc^2 and a^2+b^2=c^2. Does E=m(a^2+b^2)?
details: The argument illegitimately treats the symbol "c" as identical in both formulas. In E=mc², "c" denotes the speed of light, whereas in a²+b²=c², "c" is the hypotenuse of a triangle. Substituting one for the other is an equivocation fallacy (and relies on a false premise that the two meanings coincide).

sentence: 2 out of 3 cigarette users die. if I start smoking now, does this mean I have a 1/3 chance of living forever?
details: This argument rests on the false premise that the one-third of smokers who do not die must therefore live forever. It equivocates between ‘not dying (from smoking)’ and literal immortality, and it improperly projects a group statistic onto an individual as an unbounded outcome.

sentence: If I wear two fitbits will I burn twice as many calories?
details: This question reverses cause and effect by implying that wearing a device (the Fitbit) causes calorie burn, rather than merely measuring it (wrong direction). It further assumes a causal relationship between number of devices and calories burned—a false cause fallacy—because wearing additional trackers does not increase physical energy expenditure.

sentence: I've been told drinking water is supposed to help with weight loss. Just weighed myself after drinking over a liter of water and my weight had actually increased by more than a kilogram. What gives?
details: The speaker assumes that immediate weight gain from drinking water disproves water’s role in long-term weight loss. This draws an invalid causal inference (false cause) based on short-term scale changes, rests on the unfounded premise that water intake must instantly lower scale weight (false premise), and conflates temporary fluid mass with true fat loss (equivocation).

sentence: If 10 millimetres = 1 centimetre, does 10 millipedes = 1 centipede?
details: This argument wrongly assumes that the metric prefixes “milli-” and “centi-” operate the same way in biological names as they do in units of measure. It draws an invalid comparison between two different categories (units of length vs. names of arthropods) – a classic false analogy – while also equivocating on the meaning of “milli” and “centi,” and resting on the unfounded premise that the same prefix rules apply across unrelated contexts.

sentence: How long do Asians have to spin around before they become disoriented?
details: This question treats all Asians as a homogeneous group with a uniform physiological response to spinning. That relies on an unfounded generalization (false premise) and assumes a property of some individuals applies to the entire group (fallacy of composition).

sentence: If I bought a balloon for 50 cents, how much should I sell it for to account for inflation?
details: This is a straightforward question requesting a price adjustment formula based on inflation. It does not rest on any false premises, equivocations, or invalid inferences, but merely lacks specific data such as the inflation rate and time period to compute the result.

sentence: How come the Mississippi River lines up perfectly against the state line?
details: The question assumes as fact that the Mississippi River and the state boundary coincide exactly, which is untrue. This is a false premise because the river’s course shifts and the state line follows the original surveyed channel, so they do not ‘line up perfectly.’

sentence: Since humans share 50% of their DNA with bananas, can scientists merge two bananas to create a human?
details: This argument commits a false analogy by implying that sharing 50% of genetic material makes bananas functionally equivalent to humans. It rests on a false premise that merging bananas could produce a human, and it also misapplies part‐to‐whole reasoning (fallacy of composition) by assuming what holds for a portion of DNA holds for the entire organism.

sentence: If I can see the moon, why can I not see Florida? I thought Florida was closer.
details: The argument assumes that visibility depends solely on distance and treats the moon and Florida as equivalent objects. In reality the moon is visible because it reflects sunlight against a dark sky, whereas Florida does not emit or reflect light in the same way. This mistaken comparison is a false analogy, based on the false premise that anything closer should be visible if a farther object is seen.

sentence: If I put Listerine breath strips on my eyes, will I gain a fresh perspective on life?
details: This question assumes that applying a product designed for oral freshness to the eyes will produce a meaningful change in outlook or vision. It commits a false cause fallacy by attributing a causal effect without evidence, and rests on a false premise that breath strips on the eyes have any valid or safe function.

sentence: If two serial killers kill each other at the same time, do they become parallel killers?
details: This quip hinges on treating “serial” in “serial killer” as referring to sequential timing (one after another) and then swapping it for a technical sense of “parallel” (simultaneous), shifting the meaning of a key term. That is classic equivocation. A secondary nominal fallacy arises by taking the figurative label “serial killer” as if it were a literal descriptor of timing rather than a category of criminal behavior.

sentence: I have two cats. One cat constantly lays in the sun and is fatter than my other cat. Is the energy from the sun making him bigger?
details: The argument assumes that because the cat that basks in the sun is heavier, the sunlight exposure must be the cause of weight gain. This mistakes correlation for causation (false cause) and rests on the unfounded premise that solar energy directly increases body mass.

sentence: How many viruses do I need to expose my computer to before its immune system develops?
details: The question is based on the unfounded assumption that a computer has an immune system analogous to a biological organism (false premise). It treats the analogy between biological viruses and computer malware as if the same principles apply (false analogy) and takes the metaphorical concept of an "immune system" for computers as a literal, biological system (nominal fallacy).

sentence: If time travel is impossible, how come i can rewind a VHS tape and see the past?
details: This argument equivocates on the meaning of 'time travel'—conflating physical traversal through time with the simple playback of recorded images. It also draws a false analogy by treating rewinding a tape as if it were actual backward movement in time. Finally, it rests on a false premise that seeing recorded events is equivalent to time travel.

sentence: If mules are completely sterile, why don't we introduce them into hospital wards to cheer up the patients and transport medical supplies?
details: The argument rests on the false premise that sterility alone makes mules safe for hospital environments. Sterility does not prevent the transmission of pathogens, allergies or logistical challenges. By assuming sterility guarantees safety, it also commits a false cause fallacy (inferring that sterility causes suitability) and misapplies the general rule that 'sterile things are safe in hospitals' to a special case without considering exceptions (accident fallacy).

sentence: Is it safe to use toothpaste if you have multiple teeth? Or do I need to get teethpaste?
details: This question treats the common term "toothpaste" as if it were literally designed for a single tooth and thus insists you need a separate "teethpaste" for multiple teeth. It commits a nominal fallacy by interpreting a conventional expression literally, relies on a false premise that regular toothpaste only works on one tooth, and sets up a false dilemma by presenting only two product options.

sentence: I was told that by not moving my muscles for a longer period of time I'd get a trophy. Where can I collect my reward?
details: The argument rests on an unfounded assumption that remaining immobile will earn a trophy (false premise) and implies without evidence that non-movement causes an award (false cause).

sentence: If my smartphone has more power than the computers NASA used to put man on the moon, why can't it take me to the moon?
details: The argument treats the term power as if computational capacity and rocket thrust were the same (equivocation), draws an invalid comparison between a smartphone’s processing ability and the full system requirements for lunar travel (false analogy), and rests on the unsupported assumption that more processing power alone would enable a moon mission (false premise).

sentence: What will we do to protect our mouths once the Listerine mines run out due to climate change?
details: The statement assumes the existence of “Listerine mines” – a baseless assumption since Listerine is a manufactured product, not a mined resource (false premise) – and equates mouthwash with mineral extraction despite no valid similarity (false analogy).

sentence: Is time a pandemic? In this video taken in 1901 every single person is currently dead. How can we protect our selves from this time virus?
details: The argument treats the metaphor of time as a disease literally, falsely equating the passage of time with a viral infection (false analogy). It misinterprets a metaphorical expression as a literal one (nominal fallacy) and uses the terms “pandemic” and “virus” ambiguously, shifting between figurative and literal senses (equivocation).

sentence: Why do I have to brush my teeth when they don't even have hair in the first place?
details: The argument treats brushing teeth as if it were the same activity as brushing hair. It assumes—incorrectly—that brushing is only required when hair is present (false premise) and that what applies to hair must apply to teeth (false analogy). It also hinges on the shifting meaning of 'brush,' implying you only brush bristly things like hair (equivocation). Therefore the conclusion is unsupported.

sentence: The law of gravity says every woman in the world is attracted to me. Newton's third law says she is attracted to me in the same amount I am to her. Therefore she is lying and is extremely attracted to me.
details: The argument equivocates on the word "attraction", using it to mean both gravitational pull and romantic interest. It rests on the false premise that the law of gravity implies every woman is emotionally attracted to the speaker. It also commits a false analogy by treating physical forces between masses as if they directly translate into human feelings, producing an invalid conclusion.

sentence: If I travel the same route more than once on my bike am I recycling?
details: This question equivocates on the term "recycling," conflating the environmental process of reusing materials with simply repeating a route. It also commits a false analogy by assuming that doing something again (riding the same path) is analogous to processing materials for reuse.

sentence: How many space heaters do I need to make outer space a comfortable 68 degrees F?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that space heaters—designed to warm air in an enclosed environment—can heat the vacuum of outer space to 68 °F (false premise). It improperly equates the behavior of heaters in a room to their behavior in space (false analogy) and misapplies a general rule about heater use to a context where exceptions (vacuum, radiative heat loss) completely change the outcome (accident fallacy).

sentence: If Angelina Jolie got her breasts removed to prevent breast cancer, and her ovaries removed to prevent ovarian cancer, should I get my heart removed to prevent heart cancer?
details: This argument falsely treats the removal of vital organs as equivalent preventive measures simply because one person’s case worked; it assumes without justification that because removing some organs reduces cancer risk, any organ can be removed to prevent its cancer (false analogy). It also rests on the unfounded premise that heart removal would prevent heart cancer without regard to its necessity for life (false premise).

sentence: Why do so many people want these cloud factories shut down? Isn't rain important?
details: The question assumes without evidence that cloud factories are necessary for rain, implying that shutting them down would eliminate rain (false premise). It also mistakenly infers a direct causal link between cloud factories and natural rainfall (false cause).

sentence: When Windows freezes, will unplugging your computer fans help it thaw?
details: This question treats the metaphorical ‘freeze’ of an operating system as though it were a literal physical freezing event. It therefore commits the nominal fallacy by interpreting a figurative expression as literal, a false analogy by comparing software unresponsiveness to ice formation, and a false cause by implying that unplugging fans (which would actually increase temperature) could ‘thaw’ the software.

sentence: With life expectancy rising, should I wait until 30 to have my quarter life crisis?
details: The argument assumes that because average lifespan increases, the timing of a ‘quarter‐life crisis’ must shift proportionally. This relies on an unfounded premise that developmental milestones scale linearly with statistical life expectancy (false premise), wrongly imputes causation between two unrelated factors (false cause), and equates a societal/psychological event with a mathematical fraction of lifespan without justification (false analogy).

sentence: My wife's eye cream contains plant stem cells. Can I use this to grow and harvest new limbs from my face?
details: The argument assumes without evidence that plant stem cells in an over-the-counter cream can regenerate human limbs (false premise). It also equates cosmetic stem cells with medical regenerative stem cell therapy despite no valid basis for such a comparison (false analogy). Finally, it infers a causal effect—limb growth—from merely applying a topical product containing plant cells (false cause).

sentence: How do scientists determine whether a crime has been committed by a human or a tree?
details: The question rests on an unfounded assumption that a non‐sentient entity (a tree) can commit a crime (false premise) and further restricts outcomes to only two options, ignoring other possibilities such as accidents or animal involvement (false dilemma).

sentence: Why is it that all birds can fly, but no fly can bird?
details: This is an equivocation fallacy: the word “fly” is used first as a verb (‘to fly’) and then as a noun (the insect), and similarly “bird” is a noun then treated as a verb. It also invokes a false analogy by assuming that because birds can fly (verb), flies can ‘bird’ (verb), even though the terms don’t share the same grammatical or semantic roles.

sentence: If I pour root beer into a square cup do I end up with just beer?
details: This sentence equivocates on the term "root beer", treating it as if it were literally "root" plus "beer" and implying that changing the container removes the "root" component. This misuse of the term is a classic equivocation fallacy.

sentence: If three lefts make a right, does that mean a third of all Democrats are secretly Republicans?
details: This statement equivocates on the term “left,” shifting from the directional turn to political affiliation. It then makes a false analogy by treating the numeric relation of turns (three left turns equals one right turn) as if it applied to proportions of political groups.

sentence: If space is infinite, why does my computer keep warning me it's running out of it?
details: This argument equivocates on the term 'space,' treating physical (cosmic) space and computer (storage) space as the same. It also falsely analogizes between infinite physical space and finite digital storage.

sentence: Before they invented golf balls, how did they measure hail?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that hail size is measured by comparison to golf balls, implying that golf balls are the standard unit for hail measurement. In fact, meteorologists use tools like rulers, sieves, or imaging. This makes the argument a false premise and also relies on an invalid analogy between golf balls and hailstones without justification.

sentence: My doctor said I have Mono. How come I can still hear out both ears?
details: The speaker equivocates on the term “Mono,” confusing infectious mononucleosis (the doctor’s diagnosis) with monaural hearing. This false premise leads to the erroneous question about hearing in both ears.

sentence: Shampoo is expensive. Would real poo clean my hair just as well?
details: This argument assumes that real poo and shampoo share the same cleaning properties despite no evidence, making it a false analogy. It also relies on the unsupported assumption that poo can function as an effective hair cleanser, which is a false premise.

sentence: There's no way liquid carbon fiber is stronger than solid carbon fiber. Why would Ford do this??
details: The statement assumes without evidence that a liquid form of carbon fiber cannot be stronger than its solid form, using this unfounded premise to reject Ford’s claim rather than providing supporting data.

sentence: If Homo Sapiens aren't an endangered species then why is it illegal for me to hunt them?
details: The argument assumes that because endangered status (A) implies hunting is illegal (B), the absence of endangered status (not A) implies hunting is legal (not B). This is the inverse error. It also rests on a false premise that endangered status is the sole criterion for hunting laws.

sentence: Why did my pedometer say 3594 when going for a walk this morning when I made sure there were only like 3 kids at the park?
details: The speaker implies without justification that the number of kids at the park would influence the pedometer’s step count, creating an unfounded causal link.

sentence: Why are we trying so hard to cure cancer in mice?
details: This question assumes without justification that curing cancer in mice is pointless or irrelevant. It rests on the unfounded premise that work on mice cannot contribute to cancer research, which is false because mouse models are a standard and vital step toward understanding and treating cancer in humans.

sentence: My friend says he's allergic to peanuts but yesterday I saw him wearing a Charlie Brown t-shirt, is he lying to me?
details: The argument equivocates the word 'Peanuts'—using it to refer to the comic strip rather than the food legume—and falsely infers that wearing a Peanuts t-shirt implies no peanut allergy. This analogy is invalid because a clothing choice has no bearing on a medical condition.

sentence: Do these plots of internet traffic during the eclipse prove that the internet is solar powered? If not, then what does power it?
details: This question conflates a drop in traffic during a solar eclipse with the notion that the internet is powered by sunlight, mistaking correlation for causation (false cause) and relying on the unfounded assumption that solar energy directly powers the internet infrastructure (false premise). In reality the internet is powered by electrical grids supplied by a mix of energy sources such as fossil fuels, nuclear, hydroelectric, wind, and solar installations on the grid, not by direct sunlight on network traffic.

sentence: If the Sun is a star, why is it a circle?
details: This question rests on a false premise that being a star excludes having a round shape. In reality, stars (including the Sun) are roughly spherical due to gravity. It also equivocates between the two‐dimensional circle symbol often used in cartoons or diagrams and the three‐dimensional sphere that the Sun actually is.

sentence: Why is the sky blue? And what can I do to make it feel better?
details: The second question presupposes that the sky is capable of emotions and can ‘feel better,’ which is an unfounded assumption (false premise). It also treats a figurative expression (‘make it feel better’) as if it were literally applicable to an inanimate object (nominal fallacy).

sentence: From an evolutionary standpoint, what is the advantage of developing chains and a ball for ghosts?
details: This question presupposes that ghosts exist and evolve by natural selection, which is an unfounded assumption. It builds its reasoning on a false premise, since there is no evidence that ghosts are real biological entities subject to evolution.

sentence: Why do my arrow keys put letters on my screen instead of the arrows?
details: This is a straightforward technical question about keyboard behavior and does not present any argument or reasoning structure, so no logical errors or fallacies apply.

sentence: Why are some gases afraid of lit matches?
details: The question assumes that gases can experience fear, which is a human emotion (false premise). It also treats the metaphorical use of ‘afraid’ as if it were literal, misunderstanding the figurative language (nominal fallacy).

sentence: If the appendix has lost its function, why do so many books still have them?
details: The argument equivocates on the term "appendix," treating the vestigial organ in anatomy and the supplemental section in books as if they were the same, and then draws a false analogy by assuming that sharing a name implies sharing function.

sentence: If 9 of 10 dentists recommend Listerine mouthwash, why doesn't last one just give in to peer pressure?
details: This argument appeals to peer pressure by assuming that because nine dentists recommend Listerine, the tenth must also adopt that view. It treats the group endorsement as if individual members are compelled to conform (improper distribution or addition), wrongly infers that a property of the majority must apply to the lone dissenter (fallacy of composition), and rests on the unfounded premise that consensus alone justifies belief (false premise).
