sentence: Where do I buy evidence seeds? I always hear about cops planting evidence on the news?
details: The speaker takes the figurative expression 'planting evidence' literally, equivocating between planting seeds and framing someone, and assumes without basis that 'evidence seeds' are an actual product.

sentence: The faster you go slower the time moves. Is this why I feel 10 minutes on a treadmill longer than 10 minutes in front of a TV?
details: The argument conflates relativistic time dilation (which only occurs at speeds near light) with subjective human time perception, thus drawing an invalid analogy. It also assumes a causal relationship without evidence (false cause) and uses the phrase “time moves slower” in two different senses (equivocation).

sentence: If riding the bus is more fuel-efficient, why don't we all just drive buses?
details: The argument conflates riding a bus (using a public transport service) with each individual driving a bus, assuming that what is true for bus travel efficiency applies directly to personal operation of buses. This is a false analogy. It also presents a false dilemma by implying fuel efficiency is the only consideration, ignoring factors like cost, licensing, and practicality. Furthermore, it rests on a false premise that everyone could or would want to drive a bus under the same conditions that make mass transit efficient.

sentence: Why do we have an air conditioner if we don't have an air shampoo?
details: This question treats the mere presence of the term “air” in “air conditioner” as if it guarantees the existence of any analogous product like “air shampoo.” That is a false analogy—assuming similarity in label implies similarity in reality. It also equivocates on the meaning of “air” (shifting from conditioning indoor climates to washing hair) and relies on the false premise that an “air shampoo” would be a coherent or expected counterpart.

sentence: Why is my Vacuum cleaner so loud when sound cannot travel in a vacuum?
details: The argument equivocates on the term “vacuum,” using it first to refer to a vacuum cleaner device and then to the physical vacuum of space. It thereby rests on the false premise that the cleaner operates in a vacuum where sound cannot travel.

sentence: Where do we mine lava from to fill the earths core?
details: The question is based on the unfounded assumption that we can mine lava and use it to fill the Earth's core, which is scientifically and logically impossible.

sentence: Why do scientists spend so much time trying to create medicines for mice? Surely this time could be spent trying to cure cancer!
details: This argument wrongly presents only two options—research on mouse medicines or curing cancer—ignoring the broader objectives of preclinical studies. It also rests on the unfounded assumption that time spent on one research area necessarily detracts from another, which is not established.

sentence: How does Mountain Dew™ collect the dew that forms on mountains for their product?
details: The question treats the brand name ‘Mountain Dew’ literally, assuming the product is made by harvesting natural dew from mountains. This is a nominal fallacy (interpreting a metaphorical name as a literal process), built on a false premise (there is no actual dew‐collection process for the drink) and involves equivocation on the word “dew,” conflating the natural phenomenon with the trademarked name.

sentence: If guns are better than knives, then why don't surgeons use guns when operating?
details: This argument improperly compares guns and knives across entirely different contexts (weaponry versus medical surgery), assuming that because one tool is better for one purpose it must be better for a completely unrelated purpose. The unstated premise that superiority in one domain transfers universally is unfounded, making this a false analogy underlain by a false premise.

sentence: If space isn't fake, how did the moon end up in this Utah lake?
details: This question rests on the unfounded assumption (false premise) that the Moon is physically in the lake rather than its reflection. It also reverses cause and effect (wrong direction) by treating the reflection (effect) as evidence of the Moon being in the water (cause). Finally, it treats two visually similar phenomena (reflection vs. actual Moon) as identical (false analogy).

sentence: How much does a hydrant grow each year? Does it eventually stop growing? Is its final height affected by genetics?
details: The questions assume that a fire hydrant—a non-living, inanimate object—grows over time and is influenced by genetics. This is an unfounded and incorrect premise, as hydrants do not biologically grow or have genetic traits.

sentence: Can I trust atoms knowing that they make up everything?
details: The argument hinges on the double meaning of 'make up': atoms compose all matter (literal) versus 'make up' as in inventing falsehoods (figurative). This equivocation creates a pun rather than a valid logical inference.

sentence: In the rap song ‘The 3rd World' by Immortal Technique he states that “Seven hundred children will die by the end of this song”. How come Technique doesn't make the song shorter so that all those children don't die?
details: The question mistakenly assumes a causal link between the duration of the song and the real‐world deaths of children. It commits a false cause fallacy by implying that shortening the song would prevent those deaths, and relies on the unfounded premise that the artist’s track length can influence mortality rates.

sentence: What is the advantage of building bridges over dry ground?
details: The question rests on an unfounded assumption that constructing bridges over dry land confers any benefit. Bridges are meant to span obstacles like water or valleys; on dry ground there is no such obstacle, so the premise is false.

sentence: I'm having a bunch of Gen-Zers over for Thanksgiving. Will this help make my turkey more based?
details: The question assumes that simply hosting Gen-Zers (stereotypically considered “based”) will cause the turkey itself to become based. This misattributes a causal relationship (false cause) and rests on the unfounded premise that a cultural trait can transfer by proximity (false premise).

sentence: Will pets ever be able to live in space with us for fear of the vacuum?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that pets’ fear of the vacuum is what prevents them from living in space. In reality the barrier is physiological (lack of atmosphere and pressure), so this premise is false and it misattributes causality.

sentence: Hand sanitizer is supposed to kill bacteria. I drank a bottle, but it didn't cure my cold. Why is this?
details: The argument assumes that because hand sanitizer kills bacteria, drinking it will cure a cold. This rests on the unfounded assumption that colds are caused by bacteria rather than viruses (false premise) and wrongly infers that killing bacteria internally will cure a viral infection (false cause).

sentence: NFT means Non-Fungible Token. How do we know the Tokens will resist Fungus in the long term?
details: The argument equivocates between 'fungible' and 'fungus', treating a linguistic classification as a literal property and leading to a false premise that tokens must resist fungus.

sentence: I just acquired an eleven-foot pole. Is it safe for me to touch anything now?
details: The argument assumes, without justification, that merely possessing an eleven-foot pole guarantees safety in touching anything. This is a false premise because it ignores other hazards (e.g. high voltage, unstable objects) and thus an invalid inference. A secondary related error is a false cause: attributing safety outcome solely to pole length.

sentence: How do male silverback gorillas get so ripped if they don't even lift?
details: The question relies on the unwarranted assumption that lifting weights is the only way to develop large muscles (false premise) and presents muscle growth as having only two possibilities—either you lift weights or you can’t get ripped—ignoring other biological and activity-based factors (false dilemma).

sentence: I deleted all my software and updated the firmware, but my iPhone still bends. What gives?
details: The speaker assumes that deleting software and updating firmware—purely software changes—would prevent or reverse a physical, hardware issue (bending). This is a false premise (the assumption is unfounded) and a false cause (attributing physical bending to software state without justification).

sentence: If perpetual motion is impossible, then how do GIFs loop?
details: This statement equivocates on the term “perpetual motion,” conflating the physical impossibility of machines that produce work indefinitely without energy input with the purely digital repetition of a file. It relies on a false analogy by treating the infinite loop of an image file as if it were a physical process. It also rests on a false premise that any endlessly repeating digital animation constitutes the same phenomenon as a physical perpetual motion machine.

sentence: How do boats reproduce if they're all female?
details: The question is based on a false premise that boats are female and capable of biological reproduction. It also commits a nominal fallacy by treating the figurative tradition of calling ships ‘she’ as a literal classification, and a false analogy by equating boats with living organisms that reproduce sexually.

sentence: If there is safety in numbers, how could nine fall prey to seven?
details: The statement plays on the idiom “safety in numbers” (meaning more people lower individual risk) by applying it literally to the numerals nine and seven. This is equivocation because “numbers” shifts from a metaphorical group of people to actual digits. It also commits the nominal fallacy by treating the figurative expression as a literal fact. Additionally, it relies on the false premise that the idiom must hold universally, even in contexts where it is not applicable.

sentence: How does vitamin D travel from the Sun?
details: The question assumes that vitamin D exists in sunlight and travels from the Sun to the body. In reality, UVB radiation from sunlight triggers the skin to synthesize vitamin D; the vitamin itself does not originate in or travel from the Sun.

sentence: If we are what we eat, and I eat a cannibal, will that make me a cannibal?
details: The statement treats the metaphorical saying “we are what we eat” as a literal truth (nominal fallacy) and equivocates on the meaning of ‘eat’ and ‘be’—shifting from figurative to literal sense. It also relies on the unfounded premise that consuming something literally makes you that thing (false premise).

sentence: Should I learn archery? I want to become a skeleton with a bow after I die, not just regular skeletal infantry
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption that learning archery influences your form after death (false premise) and implies without justification that this action will directly cause you to become a skeleton archer (false cause).

sentence: I found an unplugged Ethernet cable in my house an hour ago. How much internet has leaked into my house so far?
details: The question is based on the false premise that a disconnected cable can 'leak' internet like a fluid. It also draws a false analogy between digital data and physical substances, and takes a metaphorical expression literally (nominal fallacy).

sentence: Why do meteors always land in craters?
details: The question assumes that meteors land in preexisting craters, when in fact craters are formed by the meteor impacts themselves. This reverses cause and effect (wrong direction) and relies on a false premise that craters exist before the meteor lands.

sentence: Where do caterpillars store their filament spools?
details: The question assumes without evidence that caterpillars store filament spools. This is an unfounded assumption, making it a false premise.

sentence: If you're allergic to polo shirts, are you 'lacoste intolerant'?
details: This is a play on words that equivocates the brand name 'Lacoste' with the term 'lactose', misleadingly treating them as the same concept. It also relies on a false analogy by comparing a clothing allergy to a food intolerance, two unrelated phenomena.

sentence: So there's a giant wildfire going on near me, and it's spreading really fast because of the wind. Shouldn't the wind be blowing the fire out?
details: The speaker treats a wildfire like a candle, assuming that blowing air will extinguish it. In reality, strong winds feed oxygen to large fires and drive their spread. This is a false analogy—equating candle-blowing with wildfire suppression—and rests on the false premise that wind always puts fires out.

sentence: If alcohol kills bacteria, how much vodka must I drink to cure my leprosy?
details: This question assumes that because alcohol can kill bacteria in laboratory or surface settings, ingesting vodka will cure leprosy. It is a false analogy (mixing external disinfection with internal treatment), a false cause (linking alcohol consumption directly to disease cure without evidence), and rests on a false premise (that drinking alcohol can selectively eliminate the bacteria responsible for leprosy inside the body).

sentence: If 2 vegans are fighting, is it still considered beef?
details: This joke hinges on the double meaning of “beef” (meat vs. slang for a dispute). It equivocates between the literal and figurative senses, and misreads a figurative expression as if it were literal.

sentence: If alcohol dehydrates you how's come I cry so much when I'm drinking?
details: The speaker assumes that because alcohol causes dehydration, it must reduce all fluid outputs, including tears (false premise). They then misapply the general rule about dehydration to the specific case of crying, ignoring that mild dehydration doesn’t prevent tear production and that alcohol can trigger emotional responses (accident fallacy).

sentence: Are all deaf people in a gang? If not then why do I always see them putting up gang signs?
details: This question assumes without evidence that deaf people ‘put up gang signs,’ which is a false premise. It then draws a direct comparison between ordinary sign language gestures and gang signage, a false analogy. Additionally, it equivocates on the word ‘signs,’ using it both for linguistic gestures and criminal symbols, conflating two unrelated meanings.

sentence: Does color blindness occur in blind people, for instance while reading braille text?
details: The question assumes that 'color blindness' can meaningfully apply to individuals who are completely blind, which is an invalid assumption. Color blindness is a deficiency in perceiving colors among those with functional vision; if one cannot see at all, the concept of color blindness is inapplicable. This rests on a false premise and conflates the terms 'blindness' and 'color blindness.'

sentence: If my friend is colourblind and I wear a coloured shirt, does that mean I'm invisible to him?
details: This question rests on the false premise that colourblindness (an inability to distinguish certain colors) makes a person unable to see an object at all. In reality, colourblind individuals still perceive shapes, brightness and contrast, so the conclusion of invisibility is invalid. It also involves a false analogy by treating the absence of color perception as equivalent to the absence of visual detection, and an equivocation on 'invisible,' shifting its meaning from literally undetectable to merely lacking color.

sentence: Shouldn't the anti-tank gun annihilate the tank and just leave a gun?
details: This is a rhetorical question rather than an argument committing a formal logical fallacy; it does not assert a flawed premise or false inference.

sentence: If mercury is so close to the sun how come we can get it inside thermometers???
details: The argument equivocates the planet Mercury with the element mercury, treating them as the same thing. It also assumes a false premise that the element must share the planet’s proximity to the sun.

sentence: Why don't phones come with film pre installed when you buy it? Seems silly to have to buy it separately.
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption that modern phones need photographic film to take pictures (false premise) and treats phones as if they operated like traditional film cameras despite their digital technology (false analogy).

sentence: how do tape measures trigger government spies also known as 'birds', to dance?
details: The question rests on an unfounded assumption that tape measures can make government spies dance, which is a false premise. It also incorrectly infers a causal relationship without any evidence, constituting a false cause fallacy.

sentence: Why do microwaves always skip from 100 seconds to 59 seconds?
details: The question assumes as fact that microwaves display a countdown from “100 seconds” directly to “59 seconds.” In reality, microwave timers use a minutes:seconds format (so “1:00” is 60 seconds, not “100”), making the premise incorrect.

sentence: I applied .5atm of pressure to volume 1 of a book I just read, but it did not turn into volume 2. According to Boyle's Law, this should work. What went wrong?
details: The argument equivocates on the word “volume,” treating a book’s edition number as if it were the physical volume of a gas. It also rests on the false premise that Boyle’s Law (which governs gas pressure and volume) applies to solid objects like books. Finally, it makes a false analogy between gas behavior and paper binding, assuming that what holds for gases must hold for books.

sentence: If global warming was real, wouldn't the ice wall melt and let the oceans out of the flat earth? So then why is the sea level rising?
details: The argument assumes without evidence that Earth is flat and surrounded by an ice wall. This false premise invalidates any conclusion about melting walls or sea levels, as it misrepresents the actual shape and dynamics of our planet.

sentence: Standing up too fast causes not enough blood get to your head, making you light headed. Could I stand up too slowly force extra blood into my head, giving me hyper intelligence?
details: The argument wrongly reverses the known effect (fast standing leads to light-headedness) and assumes the opposite action (slow standing) will produce the inverse outcome (extra blood equals hyper intelligence), which is not supported. This is primarily an inverse error (assuming ¬A yields ¬B), compounded by a false cause (inferring a direct causal link between blood volume and intelligence) and a false premise (assuming more blood flow inherently boosts cognitive ability).

sentence: Why doesn't the water flow out when they open the door of the aquarium?
details: The question assumes there is a side door on an aquarium through which water could escape. In reality, aquariums are sealed containers made of glass or acrylic without such a door, so the premise of opening a door to let water out is unfounded, making it a false premise.

sentence: How do I convert my money back into time?
details: The question treats the common metaphor 'time is money' as if it were a literal fact, assuming one can be converted into the other. This misinterprets figurative language (nominal fallacy), relies on an unfounded assumption (false premise), and equivocates between two distinct concepts.

sentence: If ebola isn't an airborne virus, why does it matter if infected people travel in airplanes?
details: The question rests on an unfounded assumption that only airborne viruses pose a risk when traveling, ignoring direct-contact transmission. It therefore relies on a false premise and limits the issue to two options, creating a false dilemma.

sentence: If marijuana has never killed anyone, then why do I hear of people dying from blunt force?
details: This question equivocates on the word “blunt,” using its meaning as a marijuana cigar and as in “blunt-force trauma.” It misleadingly treats reports of deaths by blunt-force injury as though they were deaths caused by smoking blunts (nominal fallacy), thus creating confusion and an invalid inference.

sentence: If I take some ordinary water and boil the hell out of it will I get holy water?
details: This joke rests on the unfounded assumption (false premise) that water literally contains “hell” that can be removed by boiling. It also plays on the idiomatic phrase “boil the hell out of it,” equivocating between its figurative meaning (to boil thoroughly) and a literal removal of “hell,” thus producing the pun about ‘holy’ water.

sentence: Why do I get sick when I eat rat poison? I thought am human?
details: The speaker assumes that being human should confer immunity to rat poison, which is an unfounded assumption leading to a flawed conclusion.

sentence: Why did ancient people bury so many buildings?
details: The question presupposes without evidence that ancient people intentionally buried many buildings, making its foundational assumption unfounded.

sentence: If eating fat causes fat people to get fatter, why don't they eat skin to get skinnier?
details: The argument equivocates on the word "fat," shifting between dietary fat (the nutrient) and body fat (the descriptor), and then makes a false analogy by assuming that eating skin (to obtain "skin") would mirror eating fat in reverse and thus lead to weight loss. Neither the shift in meaning nor the analogy is valid.

sentence: If the moon landing videos are real, how come Neil Armstrong's movements looks very different than Michael Jackson's?
details: This argument relies on a false analogy by comparing Neil Armstrong’s lunar movements under low gravity with Michael Jackson’s Earth-bound dance style, assuming they should appear alike. It also rests on a false premise that genuine footage must match an unrelated reference standard.

sentence: How come writers are always able to finish the story right before the book runs out of pages?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption (false premise) that writers inherently time their narrative to end exactly when pages run out, ignoring editing, drafting and publishing adjustments. It also implies a causal link (false cause) between the writer’s planning and the page count without evidence.

sentence: Do warehouses change into houses when there is a full moon?
details: The claim relies on an unfounded assumption that buildings can physically transform based on lunar phases (false premise) and implies a causal link between a full moon and conversion of warehouses into houses without any evidence (false cause).

sentence: How do people tolerate the blood rushing to their heads in the Southern Hemisphere? Do they just adapt?
details: The assertion that people in the Southern Hemisphere experience blood rushing to their heads due to their geographic location rests on an unfounded assumption—no physiological effect arises from hemisphere. This is a false premise, and attributing causality to hemisphere is a false cause.

sentence: How many bees would it take to cook, let's say, a chicken?
details: The question is based on an unfounded assumption that bees could generate enough heat or have the capability to cook a chicken. This false premise renders the question logically flawed.

sentence: Why do football players sweat so much if there are so many fans around them?
details: The argument hinges on the ambiguous term “fans,” conflating spectators with mechanical devices that cool by blowing air. This equivocation creates a false premise that the ‘fans’ present are intended to cool players, leading to the erroneous question.

sentence: I was told I could keep chicken in my freezer for several months without any problems. I put it in last night, but I think I did something wrong because this morning it was dead. What did I do wrong?
details: The speaker confuses advice about storing chicken meat in a freezer with keeping a live chicken. The word “chicken” shifts meaning between premise and conclusion, leading to an equivocation. This also reflects a nominal fallacy in treating a figurative or conventional usage as literal and a false premise that the same rule applies to living animals.

sentence: Why can nuclear plants photosynthesize so many CO2? Much more than other plants and trees?
details: The statement assumes without justification that a nuclear power plant is capable of photosynthesis, which is biologically impossible (false premise). It also uses the word "plants" in two different senses—biological organisms versus industrial facilities—creating ambiguity (equivocation).

sentence: How can we eliminate cancer if people still keep being born between June 22 and July 22?
details: The statement equivocates on the term 'cancer', conflating the astrological sign with the disease, and is based on the false premise that stopping births under the sign would eradicate the disease.

sentence: If helmet-to-helmet collisions cause concussions why don't they just leave their helmets off?
details: This argument commits the inverse error by assuming that because helmet-to-helmet collisions (P) cause concussions (Q), eliminating helmets (¬P) will eliminate concussions (¬Q). It also gets causality backwards (wrong direction), blaming helmets rather than collisions, and relies on a false premise that removing helmets would prevent head injuries.

sentence: How come we don't just build more of these fans to fix global warming?
details: The argument assumes without justification that simply scaling up fans designed for local cooling can counteract global warming (false premise). It also draws an invalid comparison between small‐scale cooling devices and planetary climate control, lacking a valid basis for that inference (false analogy).

sentence: According to Occam's Razor, the simplest solution is the best. If that is true, why do razor manufacturers keep adding more blades to their shaving tools?
details: The argument assumes without justification that Occam’s Razor—a heuristic for choosing between competing scientific theories based on simplicity—must apply directly to product design choices like razor blade count (false premise). It misapplies a general rule to a specific context where other factors matter (accident fallacy) and treats the number of blades as if it were analogous to theoretical simplicity (false analogy).

sentence: Can spending too much time with your nuclear family give you radiation sickness?
details: This question conflates the word “nuclear” in “nuclear family” with nuclear radiation (equivocation), draws an invalid analogy between family gatherings and radiation exposure (false analogy), and wrongly infers a causal link between time spent with family and radiation sickness (false cause).

sentence: My soap says 'liquid hand wash.' Can i still use it for my solid hands?
details: The question mistakes the label “liquid hand wash” (describing the form of the soap) for a requirement that one’s hands be liquid. This shift in the meaning of “liquid” is equivocation, and it rests on the false premise that the product is intended only for “liquid hands.”

sentence: Why are thin people called skinny? Don't fat people generally have more skin than thin people?
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption that 'skinny' refers to the literal amount of skin and that fat people have more skin (false premise). It also confuses the colloquial term 'skinny' with the literal word 'skin', using two different meanings of 'skin' (equivocation).

sentence: If there's no expiration date an item will last forever?
details: The statement assumes without justification that absence of an expiration date implies indefinite longevity (false premise) and incorrectly infers a causal link between no label and perpetual durability (false cause).

sentence: What if a werewolf astronaut went to the moon?
details: This is a purely hypothetical scenario without any argumentative inference or conclusion. It does not rest on flawed reasoning or commit any of the listed logical fallacies.

sentence: How is the Greek economy in trouble when they sell so much yogurt?
details: The argument assumes that because one sector (yogurt sales) is performing well, the entire Greek economy must be healthy. This is a fallacy of composition (mistaking part for whole). It also relies on a false premise that strong yogurt exports directly indicate overall economic strength, and implies a causal connection between yogurt sales and macroeconomic health without justification (false cause).

sentence: Why do only people with dash cams get in car accidents?
details: The question assumes, without evidence, that only drivers who use dash cams ever have accidents. This is a false premise because many people without dash cams also get into car accidents, so the foundational assumption is invalid.

sentence: I got Laser-eye surgery a month ago, but I still can't shoot lasers out of my eyes. Am I doing it wrong, or should I get a refund?
details: The speaker treats the term 'laser' in 'laser-eye surgery' literally (nominal fallacy), equivocates between the surgical tool and a superpower, and assumes the surgery’s name guarantees the ability to shoot lasers (false premise).

sentence: Is there an evolutionary reason why all trees are made of wood?
details: The question assumes that trees are defined by being made of wood, so asking why they have wood simply restates the definition and thus begs the question.

sentence: If I heat a 90 degree angle to 90 degrees, does it become a 180 degree angle?
details: The argument hinges on using the word "degree" in two different senses (an angular measure vs. a temperature measure), conflating them to draw a patently false conclusion.

sentence: If centipedes have 100 legs then why can't they run 100x faster than humans?
details: The argument assumes without justification that more legs automatically yield proportional increases in running speed. This is a false premise – there is no evidence that leg count alone determines velocity – and it also improperly distributes or adds individual leg contributions as if they summed linearly to total speed.

sentence: If the sun is a circle, how can it be hotter than 360°?
details: This statement equivocates on the term “°”, confusing the 360° of a geometric circle with degrees of temperature. It also relies on a false premise (that the sun is literally a perfect circle) and draws an invalid analogy between angular measure and heat intensity.

sentence: Can someone please explain to me how all socks eventually evolve into unmatchable pairs?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that inanimate objects like socks can 'evolve,' which is a biological process—this is a false premise. It also treats the term 'evolve' literally rather than figuratively, committing a nominal fallacy.

sentence: By how many degrees earth got cooler following the total solar eclipse? Have we dodged the global warming bullet or do we need a few more eclipses?
details: The statement implies that a brief solar eclipse caused or could avert long-term global warming (false cause) and presents only two options—either the eclipse has already solved global warming or we must have more eclipses—ignoring other solutions (false dilemma).

sentence: Can celebrities summon storms? Moreover, how many followers will it take for me to get my own cloud?
details: The assertion assumes without evidence that celebrities can control weather events, which is a false premise, and further implies that gaining social media followers will causally grant a personal cloud, another unfounded causal assumption.

sentence: If people can lift 2x there body weight why can't they just pick them selfs up and fly away?
details: The argument treats the ability of muscles to lift external weights as if the whole body could lift itself and sustain flight. It assumes what’s true of the parts (muscles lifting weight) applies to the whole (body lifting itself), and relies on the unfounded premise that gym‐style lifting directly enables self‐propulsion against gravity.

sentence: Isaac Newton discovered Newton's laws of motion; Schrodinger discovered Schrodinger's equation; Is it just a coincidence that so many scientists discover things with their own name in it?
details: This argument treats the correlation between a scientist’s name and their eponymous discovery as though it required a causal explanation beyond the standard naming convention. By asking if it’s ‘just a coincidence,’ it implies that the observed pattern needs a special cause (false cause) and forces a binary choice between coincidence or something mysterious (false dilemma), while ignoring the obvious premise that discoveries are routinely named after their discoverers (false premise).

sentence: If a lot of our memory is muscle memory, why aren't there more genius bodybuilders?
details: This question conflates two different senses of “memory”: cognitive memory versus procedural or “muscle” memory (equivocation). It also rests on the unfounded assumption that most human memory is muscle memory (false premise) and that excellence in one domain (muscle control) should analogously produce excellence in another domain (intellectual genius), despite no valid basis for that comparison (false analogy).

sentence: Don't volcanoes know smoking is bad for their health?
details: The question assumes volcanoes are sentient beings capable of knowing and worrying about health, which is an unfounded and unreasonable assumption, making it a false premise.

sentence: It's 2015 and computers still have semiconductors. Why hasn't someone invented a totalconductor?
details: The question rests on an unfounded assumption that a ‘totalconductor’ (a perfect, zero-resistance conductor) is physically possible and therefore ought to have been invented by now. This false premise leads to flawed reasoning.

sentence: How are forklifts lifted to be shipped? Bigger forklifts? Where does the cycle end?
details: These are a series of questions without an asserted premise or conclusion. There is no argumentative structure present, so no logical fallacy applies.

sentence: The Atlantic Ocean was named after Atlantis. Atlantis doesn't exist. The Indian Ocean was named after India. Is it possible India also doesn't exist?
details: This argument wrongly transfers the special case of a mythical eponym (Atlantis) to a real-world example (India). It assumes that because the Atlantic Ocean’s name stems from a non-existent Atlantis (a disputed or mythical origin), the naming of the Indian Ocean similarly implies India might not exist. That is a false analogy, comparing two naming origins without valid basis. It also rests on a false premise that an ocean’s name reliably proves or disproves the existence of its namesake. Finally, it equivocates on the concept of ‘named after,’ treating a mythological source and a historical/political entity as equivalent.

sentence: Some sites on the internet are restricted to 18+ men. Can I still go there if I'm in a group of only 17 men, including myself?
details: The argument equivocates on “18+ men,” treating the age-based restriction as if it meant a minimum headcount rather than requiring each person to be at least 18 years old. This rests on a false premise that having fewer than 18 individuals somehow satisfies an age-based rule.

sentence: Why do physicians take the Hippocratic Oath when hippos kill +500 people/year? Shouldn't their oath be more dogmatic since they're man's best friend? Asking for a friend
details: This question equivocates the word “Hippocratic” (derived from Hippocrates) with “hippo” the animal, misleadingly linking a medical oath to a dangerous mammal. It also rests on the false premise that the purpose of the Hippocratic Oath is to protect against hippo attacks, and draws a faulty analogy between the severity of an oath and the unrelated threat posed by hippos.

sentence: If I'm going to commit a sin, can I protect myself from hell by rotating myself 90 degrees so it becomes cos?
details: This argument equivocates on the word “sin,” treating a moral wrongdoing and the mathematical sine function as if they were the same. It also commits the nominal fallacy by interpreting a metaphorical idea (rotating away sin) as a literal transformation. Finally it relies on a false analogy, inferring that rotating in a mathematical sense could change moral outcomes.

sentence: My fish is called a 'Beta' fish. Where was the alpha, and when is the full version getting released?
details: The speaker equivocates on the term "Beta," treating the fish’s name as if it follows software release stages. This rests on the false premise that an "alpha" fish must have existed and that a final "full version" release is forthcoming, which also constitutes a false analogy between biological naming and software development.

sentence: Will I become more attractive if I eat magnets?
details: The question rests on an unfounded assumption that ingesting magnets can improve one’s physical attractiveness (false premise) and implies a causal link without evidence (false cause).

sentence: Why did we name our galaxy after a chocolate bar?
details: The question assumes as fact that the galaxy was named after the chocolate bar, which is untrue. In reality the candy took its name from the galaxy. This reverses the actual cause-and-effect and rests on a false premise.

sentence: Why have a 97 year old be the first person to break the sound barrier, and how could we not have foreseen his untimely death at such high speeds.
details: The statement relies on an unfounded assumption—that a 97-year-old breaking the sound barrier and dying as a result was unforeseeable or inherently problematic—without providing any evidence or rationale for why age makes the feat implausible or why his death should have been predicted.

sentence: If this rainbow has no end, where's the gold?
details: The statement simultaneously treats the rainbow as having no end and as having gold at its end, creating a direct contradiction and relying on the unfounded assumption that a rainbow can both be endless and terminate in gold.

sentence: Why is Celsius so much colder than Fahrenheit?
details: The question presumes without justification that the Celsius scale represents inherently colder temperatures than the Fahrenheit scale. In reality both are arbitrary scales measuring the same physical quantity; the numeric values differ by unit size and zero point, not by actual temperature. This misstep stems from a false premise.

sentence: Wouldn't it be genetically beneficial for hedgehogs to share hedges?
details: This question assumes without evidence that hedgehogs both share physical hedges and that doing so increases their genetic fitness. In reality, hedgehogs are solitary animals and there is no basis for claiming communal use of hedges would be genetically advantageous. The argument therefore rests on a false premise.

sentence: If you reverse the direction a microwave rotates will it make food colder?
details: This question assumes without evidence that changing the turntable’s rotation direction will causally reverse heating into cooling (false cause), is based on the unfounded premise that rotation direction affects microwave energy absorption (false premise), and implies a reversed effect–cause relationship (wrong direction).

sentence: Since STEM(science, tech, engineering, math) has added art to become STEAM, does that mean that our stem cells are now steam cells?
details: The argument equivocates on the term STEM by treating an acronym change (adding Art) as if it literally renames biological stem cells, creating a misleading analogy between unrelated concepts.

sentence: Wife has 4 living grandparents. I have two. With our family history, what are the odds of giving birth to a baby that is 75% elderly?
details: This reasoning assumes without basis that counting living grandparents produces a percentage of ‘elderly’ in a baby (false premise), draws an invalid parallel between inheritance of genes and inheritance of age (false analogy), and treats a property of parts (grandparents are elderly) as if it applied to the whole (the baby) (fallacy of composition).

sentence: How can I get a foreign girlfriend, if the International Date line is in the middle of the ocean?
details: The question equivocates on the word 'date' (using it once as a time‐zone divider and once as romantic dating), literally interpreting the figurative term 'International Date line' and building an argument on that false premise.

sentence: If a non-Muslim man marries a Muslim woman he needs to convert. If a non-Muslim woman marries a Muslim man she needs to convert. I, a non-Muslim, am about to marry my non-Muslim fiance. Do we both need to convert?
details: The premises state conversion is required only when a non-Muslim marries a Muslim. In this case neither spouse is Muslim, so neither antecedent holds and no conversion is needed. There is no misuse of implication or other fallacy here.

sentence: If Batman's parents were murdered, how was he born?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that the murder of Batman’s parents must have occurred before his birth, ignoring the actual timeline in which they gave birth to Bruce and were murdered later.

sentence: Why don't people just set their phone clocks forward a few years and refresh the news pages to see what will happen in the coming years?
details: The proposal rests on the unfounded assumption that altering a device clock will produce actual future news (false premise). It also confuses correlation with causation by implying that changing the clock causes future events to appear (false cause). Finally, it illegitimately equates changing a display clock with time travel or accessing future data (false analogy).

sentence: We all know the dangers of chem-trails, but why do we refuse to talk about boat trails?
details: The statement equates chem-trails and boat trails as if they share the same risks without any supporting evidence (false analogy). It also asserts as fact that everyone accepts the dangers of chem-trails, which is an unsubstantiated assumption (false premise).

sentence: Why are old people inclined to drive so slow? Shouldn't they be in a hurry since they don't have much time left?
details: The argument assumes without evidence that elderly drivers have limited remaining lifespan (false premise) and then infers that limited lifespan should make them hurry when driving (false cause), ignoring other factors that influence driving speed.

sentence: Can I get a bachelor's degree if I'm married?
details: This question assumes without evidence that marital status affects eligibility for a bachelor's degree. That unfounded assumption is a false premise, and it also implies a causal relationship (marriage prevents degree attainment), which is a false cause.

sentence: If space is a vacuum, shouldn't it be a lot louder?
details: The question assumes as a premise that a vacuum amplifies sound, but in fact sound requires a material medium to propagate. By building the argument on the unfounded assumption that emptiness produces loudness, it commits a false premise fallacy. It also treats the vacuum as the cause of loud sound without justification, which is a false cause error.

sentence: If knowledge is power, why don't we use textbooks as a source of renewable energy?
details: This joke equivocates the metaphorical meaning of “power” (influence or ability) with literal electrical power and then draws an invalid analogy between textbooks and energy sources. The shift in meaning and the comparison create the logical error.

sentence: My internet is 1000x faster then what it was in 2002. Why can't my 2002 ford fiesta go 65,000 MPH?
details: The argument assumes that because internet speeds have improved dramatically over time, car top speeds must follow the same pattern. It ignores the fundamentally different physical, engineering, and regulatory constraints on vehicle performance and thus draws an invalid comparison, making it a false analogy.

sentence: If alcohol is a good solvent why do people say drinking it won't solve your problems?
details: The argument hinges on the ambiguous use of the word 'solvent' (a chemical that dissolves substances) versus 'solve' (to find a solution), creating a misleading pun rather than a valid reasoning.

sentence: If Aliens exist, how come only humans have won the Miss Universe Pageant?
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption that extraterrestrials would participate in and win a human beauty contest (false premise), and then treats the absence of an alien winner as evidence that aliens must not exist, improperly inferring causation from mere absence (false cause).

sentence: I'm 150 pounds, and can lift 200 pounds. So why don't I️ fly when I'm sitting on a chair, grabbing the sides, and pulling upwards?
details: The argument treats lifting a 200-lb weight externally as directly equivalent to pulling yourself up by the chair. That is a false analogy because in the gym lift the load is external, whereas pulling on the chair is an internal force pair yielding no net lift. It also reverses cause and effect (wrong direction): pulling up on the chair applies equal and opposite force downward on you, so you cant fly.

sentence: If the Hubble Telescope can see stars millions of light years away, how come it can't see why kids love cinnamon toast crunch?
details: This question equivocates on the word “see,” shifting from literal optical detection (viewing distant stars) to understanding motives or feelings (why kids like a cereal). It also rests on a false premise that an astronomical instrument designed to collect light can reveal psychological reasons, and it draws a false analogy between observing physical objects and uncovering human preferences.

sentence: If the Titanic disaster is 100 years old, why did they wait until 1997 to release the footage?
details: The argument assumes without basis that because an event is 100 years old, relevant footage must already have existed and been available for release, ignoring that no footage was taken or discovered until much later.

sentence: If I drive my Mercedes into a lake, how deep do I have to go until I get the Benz?
details: This question hinges on a pun that treats “Benz” as both the car brand and the decompression sickness (“the bends”), using the same word in two different senses. This ambiguous shift in meaning is a textbook example of the equivocation fallacy.

sentence: Why don't math majors get the option to graduate with a radian?
details: This question hinges on the double meaning of “degree”—one as an academic qualification and one as a unit of angular measure—thus committing an equivocation fallacy by using the same word in two senses. It also relies on a false analogy by treating an academic degree and a radian (a unit of angle) as equivalent types of ‘awards.’

sentence: How much water could we save if meteors decided to take baths instead of showers?
details: This question assumes that meteors are decision-making entities that use water for bathing, which is an unfounded and impossible premise.

sentence: If the Sun is a star, how come we can't see it at night?
details: This argument rests on the incorrect assumption that all stars are visible at night (false premise). It then treats the Sun just like distant stars without accounting for its daytime brightness and glare (false analogy).

sentence: if 4 out of 5 people suffer from diarrhea, does that mean that one person enjoys it?
details: This argument treats the situation as if there are only two possible outcomes—either you suffer from diarrhea or you must enjoy it—ignoring any neutral or alternative states. That is a classic false dilemma. It also rests on the unfounded assumption (false premise) that the complement of one group must automatically possess the opposite trait. Finally, it improperly distributes group statistics onto the lone remaining individual, assuming that what applies to the majority (suffering) forces an inverse condition (enjoying) on the minority.

sentence: When I check my computer files I see Data(D:), why is my computer sad?
details: The joke treats the computer as if it can feel sadness (false premise) and plays on the double meaning of “D:” as both a drive label and a sad face emoticon (equivocation).

sentence: What does my body do with the extra hour of energy if I drink a 5-Hour Energy right before daylight savings?
details: The question equivocates on the term “hour,” treating the brand name “5-Hour Energy” as if it literally provides hours of bodily energy, and then conflates that with the extra hour gained by setting clocks back. It rests on the false premise that an extra hour in the clock automatically becomes an extra hour of metabolic energy. It also implies a causal relationship between daylight savings time and physiological energy levels without any basis for such a link.

sentence: How do I know if a website's cookies are gluten free?
details: This question equivocates on the term “cookies,” treating digital HTTP cookies as if they were edible baked goods containing gluten, thus conflating two distinct meanings of the word.

sentence: If 12.8% of drivers involved in fatal accidents were intoxicated, that means 87.2% of drivers were sober, and thus driving drunk means I have a chance of avoiding death right?
details: The argument conflates P(intoxicated│fatal accident)=12.8% with P(no fatal accident│intoxicated)=87.2%. This reverses the conditional probability (inverse error) and treats the implication as bidirectional (improper transposition). It also assumes a causal safety outcome from these percentages (false cause).

sentence: Why doesn't an air conditioner make my hair as soft and silky as normal conditioner does? Isn't air like, really smooth?
details: The argument equivocates on the word "conditioner," treating an air conditioner as if it should function like a hair conditioner simply because they share a name. It then makes a false analogy by assuming that air blown by the unit must smooth hair the way a cosmetic conditioner does, and relies on the false premise that air is inherently "smooth" in the sense required to soften and silkify hair.

sentence: If you pee in a drysuit, does it turn into a wetsuit?
details: This question relies on a false analogy by equating any liquid inside a suit with the technical function of a wetsuit, and equivocates on the term “wet suit” (a garment designed to allow controlled water contact for insulation) versus simply being wet from urine.

sentence: If Schrödinger's cat had a bell tied around its neck which rang when it moved would Pavlovs dog both simultaneously be drooling and not drooling?
details: This question hinges on improperly transferring the quantum superposition thought experiment (Schrödinger’s cat being alive and dead at once) to a classical conditioned response (Pavlov’s dog drooling). It assumes without justification that because one system can be in two states simultaneously, another unrelated system will also be in a contradictory state. That is a false analogy, and it rests on the false premise that quantum superposition effects simply carry over to macroscopic, classical behavior.

sentence: How do bananas know when they've been bought so they can start turning brown?
details: This question assumes as a premise that bananas ‘know’ when they’ve been purchased and that this knowledge causes them to brown. In reality, bananas brown due to natural ripening processes (ethylene production) and environmental factors, not any cognitive awareness. The reasoning thus rests on a false premise, and it also commits a false cause by attributing browning to the imagined act of knowing.

sentence: How many Coronas must i drink to contract the Coronavirus?
details: This question equivocates the beer brand ‘Corona’ with the coronavirus, assumes drinking beer causes viral infection (false cause), and rests on the unfounded premise that ingestion of Corona beer can transmit the virus (false premise).

sentence: How much can a car's life be extended if you freeze them first? Can frozen cars be reheated in a microwave?
details: This question treats cars like perishable items that can be preserved by freezing and restored by microwaving. That is a false analogy—mechanical objects do not behave like biological matter—and it rests on the false premise that freezing and microwaving would extend or restore a car’s functionality.

sentence: What's the current interest rate for Daylight Savings? Should I stick to a 401K?
details: The question treats the phrase ‘Daylight Savings’ as if it were a financial savings account (equivocation), assumes it carries an interest rate that doesn’t exist (false premise), and takes a metaphorical expression literally (nominal fallacy).

sentence: Im trying to make a super cleaner so I mixed ammonia and bleach in a spray bottle. The only problem is that every time I test it I wake up hours even days later aftet using it. Could I have accidentally unlocked the secret to time travel?
details: The speaker assumes that waking up much later after inhaling toxic gases from mixing ammonia and bleach is evidence of time travel. In reality, the toxic byproducts cause unconsciousness, not temporal displacement. This is a false cause fallacy (attributing an effect to the wrong cause) built on the false premise that the observed gap in consciousness must indicate time travel rather than poisoning.

sentence: We've all heard of plant-based burgers (impossible burger, beyond meat, etc.), but why has science not yet invented burger-based plants?
details: The claim reverses the actual cause-and-effect (wrong direction): we make burgers from plants, not plants from burgers. It also treats the two processes as if they were symmetric without basis (false analogy) and assumes the implication ‘plants → burgers’ can be inverted to ‘burgers → plants’ (improper transposition).

sentence: If I ate a load of corn seeds and locked myself in a sauna would i explode?
details: The question assumes without evidence that consuming corn seeds and exposure to heat in a sauna could cause a human body to explode. That is a false premise. It also implies a causal link between eating seeds, heat, and explosion without justification, a classic false cause fallacy.

sentence: My teacher asked me to find the volume of a cylinder. So far it hasn't made any sound, is it safe to say the volume is 0?
details: This argument conflates two different meanings of 'volume'—geometric capacity versus sound level—assuming that absence of audible sound means zero geometric volume, which is an equivocation fallacy. It also relies on the false premise that lack of sound implies no volume.

sentence: We learned today that microwaves are invisible yet I see ours in the kitchen plain as day. I have always seen them. Is this because of my astigmatism?
details: The argument hinges on using the term “microwaves” equivocally: first it refers to invisible electromagnetic waves, then to the visible kitchen appliance called a microwave. This shift creates a false premise that anything called a microwave must be invisible, leading to the mistaken question about astigmatism.

sentence: If humans are 98% chimpanzee, and 25% of astronauts are chimps, are astronauts 123% chimp?
details: This statement improperly sums percentages from unrelated categories: 98% refers to genetic similarity between humans and chimpanzees, while 25% refers to the share of chimpanzees among astronauts. Adding them to claim 123% chimp commits the fallacy of improper distribution or addition, assumes a part-to-whole inference (composition), and equivocates on the meaning of “percent chimp.”

sentence: If flies eat shit as a part of their diet, how come they never go near my wife's cooking?
details: The argument rests on the unsupported assumption that because flies consume feces they would likewise consume cooked food, which is a false premise. It also relies on an invalid analogy equating decaying matter with prepared cooking.

sentence: Belugas can mimic the human voice so well. How can I know that you're all not Belugas?
details: The argument takes a true implication (if something is a beluga then it can mimic human speech) and incorrectly reverses it (if something mimics human speech then it must be a beluga), assuming the converse of the implication without justification.

sentence: If I rename system32 to system64, how much faster will my computer be?
details: The question is based on the unfounded assumption that merely renaming a system folder alters the computer’s architecture or performance (false premise). It further implies a causal link between renaming and speed increase without any supporting mechanism (false cause).

sentence: How come earth weed is illegal, but people can buy sea weed all the time?
details: The argument relies on the ambiguous use of the word ‘weed’ to mean two different things (marijuana vs. edible seaweed), conflating their legal statuses (equivocation). It also improperly treats the shared label as evidence they should be regulated the same way (false analogy).

sentence: If breakfast is the most important meal of the day, why don't we just eat breakfast all day?
details: The argument equivocates on “most important,” conflating nutritional or functional importance with the idea that one should spend the most time consuming it. It wrongly assumes that because breakfast is important, one should eat it continuously (a false analogy between importance and duration of consumption).

sentence: Guys, I can't afford to go see an ophthalmologist this year. Can you please upvote this post for visibility?
details: The request assumes—without justification—that upvoting will meaningfully increase visibility and that this visibility will enable the author to afford an ophthalmologist. This is an unfounded premise (false premise) and also implies a causal link between upvotes and financial support (false cause).

sentence: I burned two CDs in my toaster but I can't hear any music when I play them. What am I doing wrong?
details: The speaker uses the term “burn” in two different senses (equivocation): one meaning to write data onto a CD with a CD burner, and the other meaning to char with heat in a toaster. They also treat a toaster as if it were functionally analogous to a CD burner (false analogy), leading to the mistaken assumption that baking CDs will produce playable discs.

sentence: My friend invented a laser gun that cools things down to absolute zero and accidentally shot himself with it. Will he be 0K?
details: The argument relies on the impossible assumption that a device can cool anything to absolute zero (0K), violating the third law of thermodynamics. This makes the foundational premise false.

sentence: Why are some gemstones so low-res? Does that detract from their value? Is the value determined by number of pixels?
details: The argument assumes gemstones possess digital properties like resolution and pixel count (false premise) and wrongly equates them with digital images (false analogy). It also takes the colloquial label “low-res” literally (nominal fallacy) and misuses the term “pixels” outside its proper context (equivocation).

sentence: Who is responsible for holding the leaning tower of pisa after the tourists have left for the day?
details: The question is based on the unfounded assumption that tourists physically hold up the Leaning Tower of Pisa, a premise for which there is no evidence.

sentence: If humans are more than 60% water, why aren't we controlled by the moon?
details: This argument treats the water in our bodies as if it were a single, free-moving body of water like the ocean, implying it should respond to lunar gravity with tides. That is a false analogy. It also assumes a direct causal link between body water content and moon-driven tidal motion (false cause) and equivocates between water in cells/tissues and ocean water.

sentence: I'm currently on my 15th pouch of Capri Sun, and have yet to transform into liquid metal. What am I doing wrong?
details: The speaker assumes as a premise that drinking Capri Sun can turn a person into liquid metal (false premise). They also treat the lack of transformation as if it must result from some mistake on their part, implying an unfounded causal link between their actions and the expected effect (false cause).

sentence: I had a 'gut feeling' that something was going to happen. Then I farted, am I psychic?
details: The argument assumes that because one event (the fart) followed a prior ‘gut feeling,’ the speaker must possess psychic powers. This is a classic post hoc fallacy: inferring causation from mere sequence without any evidence of a causal link.

sentence: If I eat myself would I become twice as big, or disappear completely ?
details: The question poses only two exclusive outcomes, ignoring other possibilities (false dilemma), and assumes without basis that one can wholly consume oneself (false premise).

sentence: If the NSA's budget is $52.6 billion and NASA's budget is $16.6 billion then does that mean the going rate for A's is $36 billion?
details: This argument assumes without justification that the numerical difference between two unrelated budgets yields a meaningful ‘going rate’ for A’s. It rests on a false premise (budgets cannot be directly reinterpreted as prices), involves improper distribution or addition (treating distinct budget figures as if they can be summed or subtracted to produce a valid rate), and implies a causal link where none exists (false cause).

sentence: Why don't we just stop naming people Kelvin so we can reach Zero Kelvin?
details: This statement equivocates the name 'Kelvin' (a personal name) with the temperature unit 'Kelvin', treating them as the same concept. It thereby falsely implies that eliminating people named Kelvin would enable reaching absolute zero, attributing a causal relationship that does not exist.

sentence: I was taught that without water you would die. My grandma drank water every day for over a hundred years, but yesterday she died anyway. Can somebody explain this?
details: The argument treats water as both a necessary and sufficient condition for life. From the premise “without water → death” it wrongly infers “with water → no death,” which is the inverse error (¬A does not imply ¬B). It also assumes drinking water alone causes survival, a false cause by attributing life expectancy solely to water consumption.

sentence: If you spin a pencil sharpener backwards, do you gain more pencil?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption (false premise) that reversing the sharpener will reverse the material removal process and actually add wood/graphite. It also commits an inverse error by treating the negation of ‘sharpening removes pencil’ as ‘reversing removes removes pencil’ implying ‘reversing adds pencil.’ Finally, it implies a causal relationship (false cause) without any mechanism by which reversed motion could restore or add material.

sentence: Help! My milk expires in three minutes at midnight, but I live near the edge of a time zone. Can I go across the border so I have an extra hour to drink it before it expires?
details: The argument rests on the false premise that a printed expiration time of “midnight” automatically resets to local civil time in any time zone, implying you can buy yourself an hour by crossing the border. In reality, the expiration refers to an absolute moment (based on a single time standard or production timezone), not a movable local deadline. It also equivocates on “midnight,” treating it interchangeably as a fixed timestamp and as a flexible local clock time that shifts with the time zone.

sentence: Why didn't people in 1955 make a big deal about it being the year Marty McFly goes back to in the first Back to the Future movie?
details: The question assumes that people in 1955 would already be aware of a movie released in 1985, which is an unfounded assumption and thus constitutes a false premise.

sentence: If higher temperature increases enzyme activity, will drinking boiling water make exercise easier?
details: This question assumes without justification that drinking boiling water will significantly raise core body temperature to boost all relevant enzymes and thus ease exercise (false premise). It improperly extends a laboratory observation about isolated enzymes to complex human physiology (false analogy) and posits a direct causal link between hot-water ingestion and improved exercise performance, ignoring homeostatic mechanisms and potential harm (false cause).

sentence: Isn't suicide self defence because you killed the person who was trying to kill you?
details: This argument treats suicide (self-inflicted death) as if it were the killing of a distinct attacker, which is a false analogy. It also rests on the false premise that you can kill an external aggressor when in fact the victim and the agent are the same person. The phrase “you killed the person who was trying to kill you” equivocates on “you,” conflating the roles of killer and victim in one individual. Finally, it is self-contradictory because it posits both attacker and defender as the same person, making the concept of self-defence inapplicable.

sentence: Why are the holes in our ears shaped like earbuds?
details: The question rests on an unfounded assumption that human ear canals naturally match the shape of manufactured earbuds (false premise), it inverts cause and effect by implying that biology adapted to technology rather than the reverse (wrong direction), and it draws an invalid comparison between a natural anatomical form and a consumer device (false analogy).

sentence: If metric system truly is better than imperial, then why are inchworms cute, but centipedes are scary?
details: This argument assumes that the aesthetic qualities of creatures derive from the measurement prefixes in their names. First, it is a false analogy because it treats the shared characteristic of unit prefixes ('inch' vs 'centi') as if it justifies comparing cuteness to system quality. Second, it commits a false cause by implying that the metric system’s superiority causes centipedes to be scary. Third, it rests on a false premise that the naming component of an animal determines its appeal or fear factor.

sentence: If Australia is 10 hours ahead, why didn't they warn us about 9/11?
details: This question rests on the false premise that being ten hours ahead on the clock somehow grants Australia foreknowledge of events occurring elsewhere. In reality, time‐zone differences do not confer predictive power, so the conclusion does not follow. It also commits a false cause fallacy by assuming that temporal precedence (their local date/time being later) implies causality (they could warn). Finally, it reverses cause and effect (wrong direction) by treating the clock offset as if it were the source of information rather than a mere convention.

sentence: If I take an inchworm out of the US, do I have to turn it into 2.54 centipedes?
details: The statement equivocates on 'inchworm' (the insect) versus 'inch' (unit of measurement), leading to a punny but misleading premise that living creatures can be converted like units. It also rests on the false premise that organisms transform by numeric conversion and draws an invalid analogy between units of length and centipedes.

sentence: How much water does the wind turbine plant need for it to grow?
details: The sentence equivocates on the word "plant", conflating an industrial facility with a living organism that grows. It commits a false analogy by implying wind turbines require watering like biological plants and treats a metaphorical expression as a literal fact.

sentence: Is breaking the law of gravity a misdemeanor or a felony?
details: The question assumes gravity can be legally broken (false premise), conflates scientific 'law' with legal statutes (equivocation), and limits outcomes to misdemeanor or felony, ignoring that no such crime exists (false dilemma).

sentence: If hemispherectomies have a success rate of 90%, would removing the other half of the brain as well mean a 180% success rate?
details: This argument treats the 90% success rate of one hemispherectomy as if it could be simply summed with another 90% to reach 180%. It erroneously distributes and adds individual probabilities (improper distribution or addition), assumes that characteristics of removing one hemisphere apply identically and cumulatively to removing both (false analogy), and mistakes a property of the part for a property of the whole (fallacy of composition).

sentence: Whenever I watch a movie on Netflix, my computer will go into 'sleep mode' after about 15 min. Are there more stimulating movies that I can watch so my computer will stay awake?
details: The user assumes that the type or ‘stimulation’ level of a movie directly causes the computer’s sleep behavior. In reality, sleep mode is controlled by system power‐management settings, not by movie content. This is a false cause fallacy and rests on the unfounded premise that more stimulating films will prevent the computer from sleeping.

sentence: My new girlfriend is a doctor. Why does she insist I stop eating apples?
details: The text presents a question about medical advice from a doctor but does not commit any of the listed logical fallacies. There is no unwarranted assumption, false cause, equivocation, or other error in reasoning evident in the statement.

sentence: I swallowed an ice cube 24 hours ago and it hasn't come out yet. Should I be worried?
details: The speaker assumes that an ice cube must remain intact and be expelled whole in the stool, which is an unfounded premise. In reality, the ice will melt into water, be absorbed or pass invisibly, so there is no need to expect a solid cube to appear.

sentence: I watched a pot today and it boiled. Should I publish my findings?
details: The statement assumes without justification that observing a commonplace event (a pot boiling) constitutes a noteworthy finding worthy of publication. This rests on a false premise—that any mere observation, no matter how trivial or already known, should be published.

sentence: If the good die young, are all old people bad?
details: The argument rests on the unfounded claim that all good people die young (false premise). It also implicitly forces a strict good/bad dichotomy (false dilemma), ignoring other moral or neutral categories and any evidence to support the initial assumption.

sentence: If a circle is 360 degrees, will it melt due to the heat?
details: The argument hinges on the word “degrees” meaning both angular measurement and temperature, conflating two unrelated concepts (equivocation). It then draws an inappropriate parallel between having 360 degrees and heat sufficient to cause melting (false analogy).

sentence: Why are there so many protons and electrons, but only one Megatron?
details: The question illegitimately compares fundamental subatomic particles (protons and electrons) with a fictional character named Megatron, treating them as if they belong to the same category (false analogy). It also rests on the unfounded assumption that because many particles exist, there should likewise be many copies of a character (false premise). Finally, it equivocates by using the term 'Megatron' in a way that blurs the distinction between real physical entities and a proper noun for a fictional robot (equivocation).

sentence: According to the UN, 6 billion people have mobile phones, but only 4.5 billion have access to toilets. Where do the 1.5 billion people sit when they browse Reddit?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that browsing Reddit necessarily occurs while sitting on a toilet (false premise). It also misapplies a generalization that some users browse on the toilet to all mobile users (accident fallacy), and implies incorrectly that the only seating option when browsing Reddit is a toilet seat (false dilemma).

sentence: Are Flaming Hot Cheeto fingers safe from Frostbite?
details: The question treats the figurative term “flaming” as if it meant actual flame or heat, implying a protective effect against frostbite. This is a nominal fallacy (misreading a metaphor as literal) and an equivocation on “flaming,” built on the unfounded assumption (false premise) that Cheeto dust can insulate or generate heat to prevent frostbite.

sentence: Yesterday while cooking bacon I had a small grease fire. With some quick thinking I remembered the phrase, 'Fight Fire With Fire'. I grabbed my flamethrower to fight the fire, but instead of fighting it, it actually seemed to intensify the fire. What happened?
details: The idiom "fight fire with fire" was taken literally rather than figuratively, which is a nominal fallacy. It also equivocates on the word 'fire' by using its metaphorical and literal senses interchangeably.

sentence: My friend mentioned how great it was to drop acid. Why is it that all I get out of it is holes in my clothing, chemical burns, and an angry chemistry teacher?
details: The argument equivocates on the term “acid,” using it first as slang for LSD and then interpreting it as literal corrosive acid, which is a classic equivocation fallacy. It also treats the figurative expression “drop acid” as a literal act, committing a nominal fallacy.

sentence: If Pi is never ending why is there still world hunger?
details: The argument falsely assumes a causal connection between Pi’s infinite decimal expansion and the existence of world hunger (false cause). It also treats two unrelated phenomena as if one’s property should determine the other’s outcome (false analogy).

sentence: Is 7 the only number in which we have observed cannibalistic tendencies?
details: The question assumes without evidence that an abstract entity (the number 7) can exhibit biological behavior such as cannibalism. That is an unfounded assumption (false premise). It further implies an analogy between numbers and living organisms without a valid basis (false analogy).

sentence: If I melt dry ice, can I swim in it without getting wet?
details: The statement rests on the unfounded assumption that dry ice (solid CO₂) will melt into a liquid you can swim in, conflating it with water ice (false premise). It also treats two different substances both called “ice” as if they share the same properties (false analogy) and equivocates on the term “ice,” implying water when referring to dry ice.

sentence: Why are Americans still being weighed in Pounds and not Dollars?
details: This question treats units of mass (pounds) and units of currency (dollars) as if they were interchangeable, assuming one could simply swap measuring systems across entirely different categories. That is a false analogy. It also equivocates on the word pound by confusing its meaning as a weight unit with its meaning as a currency, and is based on the false premise that weight measurements could legitimately be expressed in monetary terms.

sentence: I put 32GB of RAM in my PC in 2018. If technology doubles every 2 years, why don't I have 64GB of RAM now?
details: This argument rests on the unfounded assumption that because technology (broadly understood) doubles every two years, an individual’s installed RAM will automatically double without any action. It misapplies a general trend to a specific circumstance and ignores the need for manual hardware upgrades and other practical constraints.

sentence: If sunlight kills vampires, and moonlight is reflected sunlight, why doesn't moonlight kill them?
details: The argument equivocates on “sunlight,” treating direct, high-intensity solar radiation and the much weaker reflected light from the moon as the same. It also commits a false analogy by assuming shared origin implies identical effects, and an accident fallacy by applying the general rule that “sunlight kills vampires” to a special case where the intensity and properties differ.

sentence: Why do bees have built-in antennae? What is their favourite radio station?
details: This joke hinges on the dual meaning of 'antennae'—biological sensory organs versus radio antennas—creating a pun by equivocating on the term.

sentence: How come it costs NASA 3 billion dollars to get to Mars, but I can buy chocolate from Mars for only $3?
details: This argument equivocates on the term "Mars," treating the planet and the candy brand as if they were the same entity, and then draws a false analogy between the massive expense of an interplanetary mission and the retail price of candy. The two contexts are entirely different, so the comparison is invalid.

sentence: What is 'Cole's Law' and why does it appear on so many restaurant menus?
details: This is a straightforward question seeking the origin of a pun (a play on words between 'Cole's Law' and 'coleslaw'). It does not present an argument, assumption, or inference that could contain a logical fallacy.

sentence: Cigarettes take 7 minutes off of your life, but it takes me 10 minutes to smoke a cigarette. Am I technically adding 3 minutes to my life?
details: The argument wrongly treats the 10 minutes spent smoking as if it could be directly added to life expectancy to offset the 7-minute reduction. It misapplies simple arithmetic to life expectancy loss without justification, and rests on the unfounded premise that time spent smoking counts as life gained.

sentence: I'm an Aussie tourist in America. How long does it take for the jet lag to wear off so I can use my legs again?
details: There is no logical argument or fallacy present. The sentence is a humorous exaggeration conflating general fatigue from jet lag with literal leg immobility.

sentence: How are Santa and his elves allowed to produce and distribute high-end technology like iPods and tablets without violating patent law?
details: The question assumes without evidence that Santa and his elves actually manufacture and distribute patented products, when in fact they are fictional characters and patent law applies only to real entities. This unfounded assumption makes it a false premise.

sentence: How are babies always born on their birthday?
details: The question equivocates on the term "birthday" (using it both for the literal day of birth and for the annual celebration), rests on the false premise that it is surprising or meaningful for babies to be born on their birthday (when by definition a birthday is the day one is born), and reflects a nominal fallacy by misunderstanding the word's definition.

sentence: How was color blindness diagnosed in the 1940's and earlier if everything was black and white?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that all visual materials before the 1950s were black and white, which is false. Color vision tests and colored objects existed long before color photography became widespread.

sentence: If I put the L earbud in my right ear and the R earbud in my left ear do I hear sound backwards?
details: This is a straightforward question about stereo channel orientation, not an argument making invalid inferences. No fallacious reasoning is presented.

sentence: If mermaids are one half fish, and one half human, would that make me one half mermaid, and therefore one quarter fish?
