details: The argument rests on an unfounded assumption that mermaids literally consist of exactly half fish and half human (false premise).  It then applies that fractional makeup transitively to anyone half mermaid, inferring a precise quarter‐fish composition without justification (false analogy).  Finally, it conflates a metaphorical or mythical composite with a literal arithmetic fraction (equivocation).

sentence: My sunscreen says to 'apply liberally,' but am I allowed to do that in Texas, where I live?
details: The question assumes that the manufacturer’s instruction “apply liberally” constitutes a legal requirement or restriction enforceable by Texas law, but it is merely usage guidance, so the argument is based on a false premise.

sentence: If I turn a bulletproof vest inside out will the bullet do more damage to me?
details: This is a straightforward question about the physical effect of reversing a vest’s orientation on its ballistic performance. It does not rely on any hidden premises, flawed causality, or equivocal language, and thus contains no logical fallacy.

sentence: If ants can survive a fall from any height then why don't we make airplanes out of ants?
details: This argument assumes that because individual ants can survive high falls, a structure composed of ants (an airplane) would share that property. That wrongly attributes a part's trait to the whole (fallacy of composition) and draws an invalid comparison between ant biology and aircraft design (false analogy).

sentence: If it costs so much to send a pound into space, why don't we send dollars?
details: This argument equivocates on the word “pound,” shifting from the unit of weight to the unit of currency. By conflating these two distinct meanings, the conclusion does not follow from the premise.

sentence: Since time is money, does that mean time is slower in 3rd world countries?
details: The argument treats the metaphorical statement “time is money” as a literal equivalence (nominal fallacy), equivocating on the meaning of “is” by shifting from figurative to literal usage. It also relies on a flawed analogy between time and money without justification for how economic status would affect the flow of time.

sentence: It's my birthday but I haven't given birth is something wrong?
details: The sentence conflates the phrase 'birthday' (commemoration of one's birth) with the act of giving birth, thus creating an equivocation by using 'birth' in two senses.

sentence: Some guy offered me a penny for my thoughts, so I gave him my two cents. Did I just get hustled?
details: This is a pun based on idiomatic expressions (“a penny for your thoughts” and “my two cents”) and does not involve any logical fallacy or flawed reasoning.

sentence: With over 60% of those who walked the moon now dead, how come activities with such high mortality rates are still allowed?
details: The argument assumes without evidence that moonwalking itself caused the deaths (false premise) and that the high death rate among astronauts implies a causal link between the activity and mortality (false cause). It then generalizes this supposed danger to all high-mortality activities despite lacking a valid basis for comparison (false analogy).

sentence: If I am 75% water, a watermelon is 92% water, and I eat a watermelon, will I become 167% water?
details: This reasoning treats the water percentages of two different bodies (your body and the watermelon) as directly additive, which misunderstands how mixture percentages work. You cannot sum percentage contents of separate masses to get a new total percentage, so the jump to 167% water is invalid.

sentence: How do British people carry around money if it gets so heavy? Isn't 50 pounds a lot?
details: This reasoning equivocates on the word “pound,” treating the British currency denomination as if it were a unit of weight, and rests on the false premise that £50 literally weighs fifty pounds.

sentence: Why do we always hear about the deaths of celebrities, but not their birth???
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption that we ‘‘never’’ hear about celebrity births, which is demonstrably false and thus a false premise. It also implies a simplistic either/or framing (only deaths are reported versus only births), suggesting a false dilemma, though this is secondary to the false premise.

sentence: If folding a piece of paper 42 times reaches the moon; then how come we need rockets to put people on the moon? Surely folding some printer paper 42 times would be faster.
details: The argument assumes that because exponential folding could theoretically reach moon‐height, it could also function as a means of transport. This rests on the impossible premise that paper can be folded 42 times and falsely equates thickness with propulsion or travel capability, making it a false analogy built on a false premise.

sentence: Is smoking with my first hand safer than with my second hand?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption (false premise) that which hand holds the cigarette affects safety, and it also plays on the ambiguous use of “first hand” versus “second hand” (equivocation), conflating the idiom “second-hand smoke” with the literal hand used to smoke.

sentence: I just won a game in Smash Bros against a guy with the gamertag 'cancer.' Since I just beat cancer, why is my cat still dying?
details: This argument equivocates the term "cancer": defeating a player named “cancer” in a video game is not the same as curing the disease. It uses a false analogy by treating two unrelated things that share a name as if they share relevant properties. It also rests on a false premise that the gamer’s nickname and the illness are identical, and on a false cause fallacy that winning the game would affect the cat’s health.

sentence: I asked my Magic 8 Ball if it felt like it was sentient and it replied 'no.' Should I believe it?
details: The reasoning assumes without evidence that a Magic 8 Ball can self-assess or truthfully report its own sentience, which is a false premise. Then it uses that unfounded trust to conclude the ball isn’t sentient, effectively begging the question by presupposing the device’s reliability in proving its own state.

sentence: Why are storm clouds multicolored on the news, but gray in the sky?
details: This is a straightforward question about differences in visual representation (camera sensors, display settings, atmospheric scattering) rather than an argument containing a flawed inference or unfounded premise. No logical fallacy is present.

sentence: My lunar calendar says there is a going to be a new moon this week. What happened to the old one?
details: The expression 'new moon' is a technical term for a phase of the lunar cycle, not a literal replacement of one moon by another. Interpreting it as implying an actual new object exemplifies the nominal fallacy (taking a figurative phrase literally). There is also an element of equivocation on the word 'new,' conflating its ordinary meaning with its astronomical usage.

sentence: How many tennis players would it take to form a national missile defense system?
details: The question improperly equates the role of tennis players with that of missile defense components, drawing an invalid analogy. It also rests on the unfounded assumption that athletes could function as interceptors or launch platforms.

sentence: My wife sprained her ankle, and they told us to 'elevate' it, so I had her hike up a 2,000 foot mountain. Her ankle is much worse now, help?
details: The advice to “elevate” the ankle was taken in the sense of gaining altitude (hiking up a mountain) rather than the medical meaning of raising the injured limb above heart level. This misuse of a word with multiple meanings is a classic equivocation fallacy.

sentence: If I read something that says 'RIP headphone users,' and I'm wearing headphones, does that mean I'm a ghost?
details: The phrase "RIP headphone users" is a figurative internet meme warning about loud sounds. Treating it as a literal statement that all headphone users are dead is a misinterpretation of figurative language (nominal fallacy) and relies on the unfounded assumption that wearing headphones causes death (false premise).

sentence: Why are humming birds wings censored?
details: The question presupposes without evidence that humming bird wings have been censored, which is an unfounded assumption (false premise).

sentence: If humans are 80% water, and clouds are 100% water, does that make clouds 80% human?
details: This argument commits a false analogy by assuming that sharing the property of water content implies sharing the attribute of being human. It also involves a fallacy of composition, treating the part-to-whole relationship (percentage of water) as if it transferred human identity to clouds.

sentence: If people hate spoilers then why did snape kill dumbledore?
details: This sentence equivocates on the term “spoilers,” shifting from the sense of revealing plot details (which people dislike) to the literal killing of a character by Snape. It thus draws a non sequitur causal link between hating narrative spoilers and an in-story event.

sentence: Why did the scientific community spend $13 billion finding the elusive Higgs' boson when he should've been more responsible and not lost it in the first place?
details: This question personifies the Higgs boson as if it were a person who irresponsibly ‘lost’ something, committing the nominal fallacy by treating a subatomic particle and the act of scientific discovery as equivalent to a misplaced physical object. It equivocates on the term ‘finding’ (discovering existence versus retrieving a lost item) and relies on the false premise that the boson was ever ‘lost’ by a responsible agent.

sentence: Is a right angle 90° celsius or 90° fahrenheit?
details: This question equivocates the word “degree” by conflating units of angular measurement (degrees) with units of temperature (°C or °F). It rests on the false premise that an angle’s magnitude can be expressed on a temperature scale.

sentence: Can we use antibodies to kill terrorist cells?
details: This question treats terrorist groups as if they were biological cells targeted by antibodies. It commits a false analogy by assuming that because antibodies kill harmful cells in the body, they could likewise kill terrorists. It also equivocates on the word “cells,” shifting from its biological sense to a political/militant sense, and it falls into the nominal fallacy by interpreting the metaphorical phrase “terrorist cells” as literal biological entities.

sentence: I live in a nuclear family, and my parents want a divorce. If they split, are we all going to explode?
details: The argument equivocates on the word 'nuclear,' using its figurative sense in 'nuclear family' to imply literal nuclear explosion. This is classic equivocation. It also commits the nominal fallacy by treating a metaphorical expression as if it were literal.

sentence: If I drop soap on the ground, is the floor clean or the soap dirty?
details: The question frames only two options—either the floor is clean or the soap is dirty—ignoring other possibilities (e.g., both become dirty), thus creating a false dilemma.

sentence: If 8 out of 10 smokers die, do the other 2 live forever?
details: This question sets up a binary choice—either you die from smoking or you live forever—ignoring all intermediate outcomes. That is a false dilemma. It also rests on the unfounded premise that surviving smokers must become immortal, which is a false premise.

sentence: If no shipments go to the North Pole, does Santa Claus create gifts by converting energy into matter? Is this why the Arctic is cold?
details: This argument rests on the unfounded assumption that Santa Claus exists and must create gifts by converting energy into matter (false premise), and then wrongly attributes the Arctic's cold temperatures to that imagined energy‐to‐matter conversion process (false cause).

sentence: Why do ghosts have clothes? If someone gives you a wedgie at the moment you die, will you have it for all eternity?
details: The questions assume without evidence that ghosts exist and wear clothes, and that a wedgie would persist after death as a ghostly condition. These are unfounded premises leading to invalid conclusions.

sentence: What is the chemical formula for 'scratch' and how can it be used to make so many things?
details: The question builds on the unfounded assumption that “scratch” is a chemical substance with a formula (false premise). It also mistakes the name “scratch” for a literal chemical entity (nominal fallacy), treating a word as if it has inherent chemical reality.

sentence: Is a baby cow a calf because it's half a cow?
details: This statement assumes that the term "calf" literally means "half a cow", which is an unfounded premise (false premise). It also uses the word "calf" in two senses—baby cow versus half of an adult cow (equivocation). Additionally, it treats the name "calf" as if it described a fractional part rather than a young animal (nominal fallacy).

sentence: My neighbor says that he has 300 horses under his car hood. How does one manage to take care of such a large equestrian population? Is this humane?
details: The argument assumes as fact the impossible scenario of fitting 300 horses under a car hood. This unfounded assumption renders the subsequent questions invalid, as they rely on a false premise.

sentence: Why are Americans so concerned with global temperatures being so high? Couldn't they just switch to Celsius?
details: The argument rests on the false premise that Americans’ alarm over climate change is driven solely by the numerical value on the Fahrenheit scale. Converting to Celsius would not alter the physical reality of higher temperatures. It also implies a spurious causal link between scale choice and concern (false cause) and reverses cause and effect by suggesting that changing the scale could eliminate the problem (wrong direction).

sentence: Everytime I see photos of the Andromeda Galaxy, it is from the same direction. Why doesn't anyone ever take a picture from a different angle?
details: This question assumes—without basis—that photographers or spacecraft can readily position themselves around the Andromeda Galaxy to capture it from multiple angles. In reality, all observations come from Earth or its vicinity, so alternate viewpoints are not physically available.

sentence: What if we don't need food but by being fed early on we develop an addiction and hunger is just withdrawal?
details: The statement begins with an unfounded assumption that humans do not need food, which is a false premise. It then reverses the actual cause–effect relationship by claiming feeding causes hunger rather than hunger driving the need to eat (wrong direction). Finally, it asserts a causal link between early feeding and a lifelong ‘addiction’ manifesting as hunger without evidence, exemplifying a false cause fallacy.

sentence: Is it alright to drink spring water in the summer? (Answer fast I'm thirsty)
details: This is a straightforward question with an added sense of urgency; it does not commit any of the listed logical fallacies.

sentence: What structural concerns must be taken into account when building a city on rock and roll?
details: The question treats the idiomatic phrase "rock and roll" (a music genre) as if it were a literal building material. This equivocates on the meaning of "rock," misinterprets a figurative expression as literal (nominal fallacy), and rests on the unfounded premise that music can serve as a foundation for construction.

sentence: Buenos Aires means 'good air' but the city only has moderate air why come?
details: This argument assumes that the literal meaning of the city’s name must determine its actual, present‐day air quality. It relies on the unfounded premise that a name’s etymology guarantees real-world conditions (false premise), and it treats the name as a causal factor for air quality (false cause). It also parallels the name to the current state without valid basis (false analogy).

sentence: CERN just created 9 trillion degree plasma. Isn't that too hot for a TV?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption (false premise) that a television is exposed to or must withstand the plasma’s temperature. It also draws an invalid comparison (false analogy) between the extreme particle-collision temperatures inside a vacuum chamber and everyday ambient heat that would affect a TV.

sentence: I hear people shout 'fire at will' in a lot of old war movies. Who's Will and why do people want to shoot him?
details: The speaker mistakenly interprets the idiomatic command "fire at will" as if "Will" were a person to be shot. This is a nominal fallacy—treating a figurative expression literally—and also involves equivocation by confusing the noun "will" (volition or readiness) with a proper name.

sentence: If someone drops the base, and then some acid, do they cancel each-other out?
details: This is a hypothetical chemistry question rather than an argument making a faulty inference; it does not commit any logical fallacy.

sentence: I always see 'rock' salt, but no pop salt or even jazz salt... What gives?
details: This argument hinges on treating the word “rock” in “rock salt” as if it referred to the music genre rock. In reality, “rock salt” means salt in rock (stone) form. Conflating these two senses is an equivocation. It then draws an invalid analogy to other music genres (pop, jazz), and rests on the false premise that naming conventions for salts follow musical categories.

sentence: If the Dinosaurs lived 230 million years ago, how do we know their names?
details: This question rests on the false premise that because dinosaurs lived millions of years ago, it would be impossible to know or assign their names. In reality, modern scientists create and assign names to species based on fossil evidence and established taxonomic practices.

sentence: If I mix together two different kinds of soap, can I kill 198% of germs?
details: The statement assumes you can kill 198% of germs, which is impossible because you cannot eliminate more than all of the germs present. This rests on an unfounded premise and directly contradicts the concept of percentages, where 100% represents the total.

sentence: Why do blue links turn purple when clicked on, what is the chemical reaction that causes this change in color?
details: The question is built on the unfounded assumption that clicking a link triggers a chemical reaction. In reality, the color change is a styling rule (CSS) applied by web browsers, not a chemical process.

sentence: If I stare too long at the sun, I'll go blind. If I stare too long at a rainbow, will I go colour blind?
details: The argument equivocates on the term “blind,” using it in its literal sense for the sun but then implying a parallel effect (colour blindness) from staring at a rainbow. It also relies on a false analogy between physically damaging one’s eyes by intense sunlight and harmlessly observing a rainbow.

sentence: I bought one of those monitor lizards but when I tried to plug it in, it bit me. How do I connect it to my PC?
details: The argument equivocates on the word “monitor,” using it first to mean a reptile and then to mean a computer display. This shift in meaning leads to the absurd conclusion that the lizard could be plugged into a PC (false analogy), when in fact the two senses of “monitor” are unrelated.

sentence: We have evidence of Pre-malone and Post-malone. Is there anything known about an intermediary transition state (which must have been brief)? i.e. Was there a 'malone', so to speak?
details: The question assumes without evidence that because Pre-malone and Post-malone exist there must also have been an intermediary ‘malone’ state. This is a false premise and it also begs the question by presuming the very point in dispute.

sentence: How clean would a meteor shower make you?
details: The question rests on an unfounded assumption that a meteor shower can clean a person (false premise) and further implies a causal effect without any basis (false cause).

sentence: If traveling is illegal in basketball, shouldn't the home team win every single game?
details: This argument assumes without evidence that committing a "traveling" violation directly causes a team to lose (false cause) and that away teams travel more than home teams. It also hinges on the equivocation of "illegal" (treating a rule foul as a legal crime) and rests on the unfounded premise that the home team never travels or commits the foul (false premise).

sentence: Why does my raw chicken give me salmonella, but my raw salmon doesn't give me chickenella? Am I being ripped off at the grocery store?
details: This statement commits a nominal fallacy by misinterpreting the term "salmonella" as a literal disease derived from salmon, a false analogy by assuming that salmonella and the invented "chickenella" are parallel diseases, a false premise by expecting every meat to have a similarly named pathogen, and equivocation on the meaning of "salmonella."

sentence: If I tell someone I ate poop but I lied about it, am I full of shit?
details: The question treats the idiom “full of shit” literally, asking if lying about eating poop makes one literally full of feces. This is a nominal fallacy (misreading a figurative expression as literal) and also involves equivocation on “shit” between its literal and figurative meanings.

sentence: If moles are blind then why are they so good at measuring chemical substances?
details: This statement equivocates on the word "mole": it shifts between the burrowing mammal (which has poor eyesight) and the chemical unit or professional technician. It also relies on a false analogy by treating the animal’s sensory abilities as comparable to the skills or definitions involved in chemical measurement.

sentence: are gummi bears endangered? disappearing from my hands at alarming rate
details: The statement plays on the formal term ‘endangered’ (used for species conservation) to describe candy disappearance, equivocating its meaning, and draws an analogy between candy consumption and wildlife decline without a valid basis.

sentence: They say the best time to plant a tree is 10 years ago. And the second best time is today. But my gardener says the best time to plant a tree is in the spring. Who is correct?
details: The statement uses the word “time” ambiguously—first referring to a point on the timeline (years ago vs. today) and then to a season (spring). This shift in meaning creates an equivocation fallacy.

sentence: Could the fact that the universe is expanding explain the growing divorce rate, since couples just aren't as close as they used to be?
details: This argument commits a false cause fallacy by attributing rising divorce rates to cosmic expansion without any causal link. It also uses equivocation on the word “close,” shifting from physical distance between galaxies to emotional closeness between partners. Finally, it relies on a false analogy equating the behavior of astronomical bodies with human relationships.

sentence: Did Schrödinger ever consider the fact that his cat had 9 lives?
details: The question assumes without basis that Schrödinger’s cat literally had nine lives, a premise not found in the original thought experiment and therefore an unfounded assumption.

sentence: If a person is stabbed in the USA every 4 minutes, how is that person still alive?
details: The statement rests on the unfounded assumption that the statistic refers to the same individual being stabbed every four minutes, rather than different people. This false premise is enabled by equivocation on the phrase 'a person.'

sentence: My dad told me I have to hold my breath when I drive through a tunnel. But now I'm in a tunnel and traffic is stopped. What do I do? (Time sensitive inquiry)
details: The advice rests on a false premise (there is no real need to hold your breath when passing through a tunnel). Moreover, applying this blanket rule even when traffic is stopped misapplies the general instruction to a special circumstance, illustrating the accident fallacy.

sentence: What part of a bear's magnetic molecular make up determines whether it is or isn't polar?
details: This question equivocates the term “polar,” mixing magnetic polarity with the geographical term for polar bears, and is built on the false premise that bears have a magnetic molecular structure determining ‘polarity.’

sentence: My gf said she wants to be the Sun in my life. Does it mean she wants to be 150 million kms away from me?
details: The speaker treats the metaphorical phrase 'sun in my life' as a literal physical statement about distance. This is a nominal fallacy (misinterpreting figurative language as literal) and involves equivocation by shifting the meaning of 'sun' from a symbolic role to an actual celestial body.

sentence: My soap is expired. Is it ok to still eat it?
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption that soap is a consumable food item, making it a false premise. It also equivocates by applying concepts of expiration and eating—which pertain to edible goods—to a non‐food product.

sentence: If I go on vacation, will my memory foam mattress forget me?
details: This question treats the term “memory” in memory foam as if it referred to human memory and consciousness, then assumes the mattress can literally remember or forget you. That is equivocation on the word memory. It also relies on the false premise that an inanimate object can form and lose memories like a person.

sentence: Is otter space any different from outer space?
details: This question hinges on treating ‘otter space’ (a pun or nonstandard phrase) as if it were the same as ‘outer space.’ It equivocates on two different terms that sound alike but have distinct meanings. It also rests on a false premise that ‘otter space’ denotes a real, analogous concept, and by comparing them implies a false analogy between unrelated ideas.

sentence: If E=MC², why isn't Elephant spelled MC²LMC²phant?
details: This argument equivocates the symbol E for energy with the letter E in ‘Elephant,’ falsely treating a physics formula as a rule for spelling. It draws an invalid analogy between mathematical notation and English orthography and rests on the unfounded premise that equation symbols dictate word spelling.

sentence: My boss said time is money. Is the universe really then a fabric of space and dollars? A space dime continuum?
details: The speaker treats the metaphor “time is money” as a literal equivalence (nominal fallacy), shifts the meaning of “money” from figurative to literal (equivocation), and then extends the metaphor without justification by comparing the universe to a space–dollar fabric (false analogy).

sentence: I'm trying to kill a vampire but can't find the right type of cow that will yield wooden steaks. What gives?
details: The speaker confuses the homophones “stake” (a wooden implement) and “steak” (meat), equivocating on the word “steak” and thus mistakenly searches for a cow that produces wooden steaks. This also reflects a nominal fallacy by interpreting a figurative instruction (wooden stake) as a literal source of steaks from cattle.

sentence: If I drink Red Bull right before I go to bed, will I have a lot of energy in my dreams?
details: This question wrongly assumes a direct causal link between drinking an energy drink and gaining more ‘energy’ in the content of dreams (false cause). It also uses the term ‘energy’ ambiguously, conflating physiological stimulation with subjective dream vitality (equivocation).

sentence: My dentist says I need my wisdom teeth removed. How can I be sure the rest of my teeth are sufficiently educated to carry on without them?
details: This statement treats the term wisdom in 'wisdom teeth' as literal wisdom or education. It equivocates on the meaning of wisdom and commits the nominal fallacy by reading a figurative label as a real attribute of the teeth.

sentence: My play-doh says 3-5 years on the label, but I managed to eat it in under 30 minutes, do I have a genetically superior digestive system?
details: The phrase “3-5 years” on a toy label is an age recommendation, not a time period for eating or digestion. By treating it as such, the speaker equivocates on the label’s meaning (equivocation) and builds the argument on that incorrect assumption (false premise). They then jump to a causal conclusion—eating it quickly implies a genetically superior digestive system—without justification (false cause).

sentence: If money doesn't grow on trees, why do banks have branches?
details: This question hinges on using the word “branches” in two senses: tree limbs versus bank offices. It equivocates on the term “branch,” treating a figurative proverb (“money doesn’t grow on trees”) as if trees and banks shared the same kind of limbs. It also draws a superficial analogy between trees and banks without a valid basis, and it treats a metaphorical expression literally.

sentence: You are what you eat. I eat fast food. Why am I not fast? 1234💨
details: The argument treats the metaphorical claim “you are what you eat” as a literal premise and then equivocates on the word “fast” (fast food vs. being quick). It also draws a false analogy by assuming sharing one attribute (eating ‘fast’ food) implies another unrelated attribute (being ‘fast’ oneself).

sentence: If I bury my lava lamp, will it become a magma lamp? How will I know?
details: The question assumes that simply burying a ‘lava lamp’ will turn it into a ‘magma lamp,’ implying a literal change based solely on the names. This is a false premise (an unfounded assumption about transformation), reinforced by a false analogy (treating the lamp’s wax as if it were actual lava/magma) and equivocation (equating two different senses of 'lava' and 'magma').

sentence: Is this big lighter lighter than a little lighter even though it's bigger because it's more lighter?
details: The sentence equivocates by using "lighter" first as a noun (the fire‐starting tool) and then as a comparative adjective (meaning "less heavy"). It also rests on a false premise that a bigger object can automatically be "more lighter," and even uses the ungrammatical double comparative "more lighter." Finally, it contradicts itself by claiming something larger is simultaneously heavier in size but lighter in weight without any justification.

sentence: How Come Mercury is on the Periodic Table but all the other planets aren't?
details: The sentence conflates two different senses of the word 'Mercury' (the element vs. the planet), which is equivocation. It also rests on the false premise that planets in general should appear on the periodic table like chemical elements. Finally, it draws a faulty analogy by assuming that because one planet’s name matches an element, the same must hold for all planets without any valid basis.

sentence: is a light year further in a leap year?
details: The question equivocates on the word “year,” treating the calendar year (which can be 366 days) and the fixed astronomical definition of a light-year (based on a standard Julian year of 365.25 days) as if they were the same. It also rests on the false premise that a leap day changes the distance of a light-year.

sentence: If a fish underwater is wet, and my skin is dry because it is in contact with the air, but my insides are wet, does this mean my insides are under water?
details: The argument assumes that because being underwater guarantees wetness (if A then B), the reverse must also be true (if B then A). This is an improper transposition or converse fallacy. It also relies on a weak analogy—just because fish underwater are wet does not mean all wet things must be underwater.

sentence: Looking at a map of the US, I noticed that the states all perfectly fit together with no gaps. How is this possible?
details: This is a factual observation about political boundaries on a map and does not involve an argument or flawed reasoning. States are defined to share borders, so there are no logical fallacies present.

sentence: If a Canadian reaches an important event or advancement in their career, do they call it a kilometerstone?
details: This is a pun playing on the word “milestone” by substituting “mile” with “kilometer” to reference Canada’s metric system. It does not attempt to prove anything or present an argument, so no logical fallacy is committed.

sentence: If I heat my solid state hard drive until it becomes a gaseous state hard drive, would that enable cloud computing?
details: This question equivocates on the term "cloud," conflating literal gas with network-based cloud computing (equivocation). It also rests on the impossible assumption that a solid‐state drive can be heated to a gaseous state and remain functional (false premise), and treats the physical transformation as analogous to moving data into the digital “cloud” without justification (false analogy).

sentence: It's really foggy outside today, can you guys up vote for visibility?
details: The statement shifts the meaning of “visibility” from weather conditions to social media exposure (equivocation), then wrongly implies that fog outside can cause increased post visibility (false cause).

sentence: Could the oil industry learn to clone dinosaurs and then immediately bury them in order to solve the oil crisis for future generations?
details: This proposal rests on the unfounded assumption (false premise) that cloning and burying dinosaurs would produce usable oil. It also assumes a direct causal link (false cause) between newly buried dinosaur biomass and commercially viable oil formation, ignoring geological timescales and the actual organic sources of petroleum. Finally, it treats dinosaurs as interchangeable with the microplankton and organic matter that naturally generate oil (false analogy).

sentence: How can I be expected to believe atoms, when they make up everything?
details: The statement plays on the dual meaning of “make up,” conflating atoms literally composing everything with the notion of fabricating or lying, thus committing an equivocation.

sentence: Today I found a family of five moles in my lawn... Is it possible to calculate the molarity?
details: The argument equivocates on the term 'mole,' treating the animal (a burrowing mammal) as if it were the chemical unit of substance. This false premise leads to the flawed idea that one can compute 'molarity' from a count of animals. Equivocation is the primary fallacy, with the wrong assumption (false premise) as a close secondary error, and a nominal fallacy in interpreting a common name literally as the technical term.

sentence: If we cry when cutting onions, why do we continue to hurt them?
details: The argument assumes without evidence that onions can feel pain or cry like humans (false premise). It treats a figurative description of tearing—caused by onion vapors—as literal human crying (nominal fallacy). It further draws an analogy between human emotional pain and cutting onions without a valid basis for that comparison (false analogy).

sentence: Why hasn't the Zodiac Killer killed Cancer yet?
details: The question conflates the real criminal nickname “Zodiac Killer” with the astrological zodiac signs, treating “Cancer” (a sign) as an entity the killer should target. This equivocation on “Zodiac” and “Cancer” leads to a false premise that the murderer operates by killing zodiac‐named signs rather than people.

sentence: If the 2 major components of human blood are red blood cells and white blood cells, why isn't human blood pink?
details: The argument rests on an incorrect premise that blood consists only of red and white blood cells (ignoring plasma and platelets) and assumes that mixing a red part with a white part must yield pink, overlooking component proportions and the fact that white blood cells are essentially colorless.

sentence: If the sound barrier gets broken so often, why do they even bother setting them up?
details: The argument treats the 'sound barrier'—a natural physical phenomenon—as if it were a literal barrier that humans erect and must continually break. This is a nominal fallacy (misreading a metaphor as a real object) and relies on a false premise that the barrier is intentionally set up by people.

sentence: Is the sound of 10 bells equivalent to 1 decibel?
details: This question conflates the instrument “bell” with the unit of sound level “bel” (and its subdivision, the decibel). It equivocates on the term “bell” and draws an invalid analogy between the number of bells and a logarithmic sound‐pressure unit, relying on a false premise that count of bells maps directly to decibel value.

sentence: If the James Webb Space Telescope can see things as they were millions of years in the past, why don't we point it at the Earth to take photos of dinosaurs?
details: This argument assumes without basis that the telescope’s ability to see the past is an intrinsic function rather than a consequence of observing very distant objects whose light takes millions of years to reach us (false premise). It also likens distant observations to local ones without justification, implying that point-and-shoot at Earth would similarly reveal its ancient past (false analogy). Finally, it misattributes cause and effect by treating the telescope’s time lag as a property of the instrument instead of the travel time of light over cosmic distances (wrong direction).

sentence: Why wasn't Pavlov conditioned to feed a dog every time he heard a bell?
details: The question rests on a false premise that Pavlov himself could be conditioned in the same way as his canine subjects, as if hearing a bell would train him to feed a dog. It also commits a false analogy by treating the experimenter and the conditioned subject as interchangeable, despite their fundamentally different roles in the classical conditioning setup.

sentence: Can colorblind people taste an orange?
details: The question assumes without basis that a deficiency in color perception (colorblindness) would impair the separate gustatory system (taste). This is a false premise, and it also implies a causal link where none exists.

sentence: Is the world's supply of iceberg lettuce in danger due to global warming?
details: This is a legitimate question seeking information. It does not assert a premise or draw a conclusion, so no logical fallacy is committed.

sentence: Now that Kobe is retired, will the price of beef go up?
details: The question presumes a causal relationship between Kobe Bryant’s retirement and beef prices solely based on their temporal connection, committing a post hoc fallacy without any supporting evidence.

sentence: If time is relative, why is it legal to sleep with an alarm clock? Is time my third cousin?
details: This question equivocates on 'relative' by treating the physics concept of time dilation as if it meant family relationship. It also draws a false analogy between being scientifically relative and being a blood relative, and the legality question is a non sequitur since the premise about relativity has no bearing on legal permissions.

sentence: Why do we only hear about oxymorons and never oxygeniuses?
details: The question treats the shared prefix "oxy-" as if it guarantees a counterpart term "oxygenius", assuming that words built with the same parts must all exist and mirror each other (false analogy). It also exploits the different meanings of "oxy-" (sharp vs. acid), creating ambiguity (equivocation).

sentence: How many times do you have to open a door before it is a jar?
details: The sentence depends on the ambiguity between 'ajar' (meaning slightly open) and 'a jar' (a container). It equivocates by treating the descriptor 'ajar' as if it meant 'a jar', and interprets a figurative expression literally, thus committing both equivocation and the nominal fallacy.

sentence: How come water doesn't prey on all the fish?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that water is an agent capable of preying on fish. Since water is not a predator, the premise is false, making the reasoning invalid.

sentence: Can you get rich by buying gold at the equator and selling it in Alaska due to higher gravity there?
details: This argument rests on the false premise that gravity in Alaska is significantly stronger than at the equator—any difference is negligible—plus it commits a false cause fallacy by assuming that a tiny weight difference would translate into real profit arbitrage.

sentence: People keep saying 'If it's stupid but it works, it isn't stupid', but people at my work are still stupid. Is this an example of a paradox?
details: The statement hinges on a shifted meaning of “works” (devices ‘working’ vs. people ‘working’) and misapplies an adage about tools or methods to human traits. This is equivocation. It also treats people like machines (false analogy) and relies on a self-contradictory premise that ‘stupid’ implies ‘not stupid.’ It is not a true paradox but a fallacious play on words.

sentence: Are slugs just snails that got hit hard in the 2008 housing crisis?
details: This question erroneously equates biological differences between slugs and snails to the economic impact of a housing crisis. It draws an invalid comparison (false analogy) by suggesting that slugs are simply snails minus shells due to a financial event, and it implies a causal relationship without evidence (false cause).

sentence: Roughly 30% of all traffic fatalities are caused by drunk drivers. This means that 70% are caused by sober drivers. Why are we still allowed to drive sober?
details: This argument misinterprets correlation as causation by assuming that because a driver wasn’t drunk, that driver must be the cause of 70% of fatalities (false cause). It rests on the unfounded premise that ‘not drunk’ equals direct responsibility for any crash not involving alcohol (false premise). It also frames the issue as a binary choice—either ban sober driving or accept 70% of deaths—ignoring other solutions or factors (false dilemma). Finally, it equivocates on the word ‘cause,’ conflating involvement in an accident with causal responsibility (equivocation).

sentence: When I mute my TV or a YouTube video, where does all the sound go?
details: The question is based on the false premise that muting a device must redirect or store existing sound somewhere. In reality, muting simply stops the audio signal from driving the speaker, so no sound waves are produced. It also treats the figurative term “mute” as if it described a literal physical relocation of sound, which is a nominal fallacy.

sentence: What is it about cold turkey that makes it so hard to quit?
details: This is a neutral question asking for reasons why quitting abruptly ('cold turkey') is difficult. It does not assert a flawed premise, offer a forced dichotomy, or rely on any improper inference, so no logical fallacy applies.

sentence: If Pluto is a Dwarf planet, shouldn't we try to contact the Dwarves living there?
details: The argument equivocates on the word "dwarf", treating the astronomical term "dwarf planet" as if it implied the existence of sentient "dwarves". This rests on a false premise (that such beings exist on Pluto) and draws a false analogy between a category label and a living species.

sentence: How do people drown? Why don't they just drink the water?
details: The question equivocates the act of drinking water (swallowing into the stomach) with inhaling water into the lungs, which is what actually causes drowning. It rests on the false premise that ingesting water by mouth is the only way water can enter the body in a harmful way.

sentence: Just got some ducks, now how do I get them to make tape?
details: The question rests on an unfounded assumption that ducks can produce tape, which is impossible and leads to an invalid argument.

sentence: Can you flip a bitcoin?
details: This question assumes bitcoins are physical coins that can be flipped, which is a false premise because bitcoins are purely digital. It also relies on an equivocation of “flip,” which can mean either physically turning over or trading for profit, creating ambiguity.

sentence: Can I boost my WiFi signal by placing a fan behind my router?
details: The question implies without any supporting evidence that placing a fan behind a router will causally improve WiFi signal strength, which is a false cause and stems from an unfounded premise.

sentence: How can America have 50 states when my science teacher says there's only three? Solid, Liquid, and Gas.
details: This statement equivocates on the word \"state\", confusing U.S. political subdivisions with states of matter. It also relies on the false premise that the teacher’s reference to three states applied to American geography rather than to physical phases of matter.

sentence: If a wood saw is used to saw wood, then why can't I use a chainsaw to saw chains?
details: This reasoning treats the name "chainsaw" as a literal description of its function (i.e. a saw for chains), which is a nominal fallacy. It also equivocates on the word "saw" (tool vs. action) and draws an invalid analogy between naming and intended use.

sentence: Where can I buy the toothpaste that only 1 out of 5 dentists recommends?
details: The question rests on the unverified assumption that there exists a toothpaste recommended by exactly one in five dentists. This premise may be fabricated or misleading and is presented without evidence.

sentence: If I want 8 hours of sleep but I only have one spare hour, can I sleep 8 times as hard for that one hour?
details: This question assumes without justification that sleep can be intensified proportionally to time (false premise), likening rest to tasks that scale with effort (false analogy), and treats sleep quantity as additively distributable in a way that physiological processes do not allow (improper distribution or addition).

sentence: Why do hurricanes announce their landfall days ahead? Wouldn't it catch more people off guard with a sneak attack?
details: The argument assumes as fact that hurricanes deliberately “announce” their landfall and could choose to perform a “sneak attack.” This imputes agency and intention to a natural phenomenon, which is an unfounded assumption and therefore a false premise.

sentence: If C++ evolved from C, why come there is still C?
details: The question rests on an unfounded assumption that evolution of a language necessitates the disappearance of its predecessor, a false premise. It also misapplies the general idea that evolution implies complete replacement to this specific case, illustrating an accident fallacy.

sentence: If microwaves are not part of the visible light spectrum, how come I can see this?
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption that microwaves (which lie outside the visible spectrum) should be visible, leading to a confusion between electromagnetic waves in the microwave band and visible light.

sentence: Shouldn't greasy foods lubricate my arteries instead of clogging them? Why are people so worried?
details: This argument treats arteries like mechanical pipes and assumes dietary fats should work as lubricant (false analogy), rests on the unfounded premise that biological arteries behave like machine parts (false premise), and misuses the term ‘greasy’ by equating mechanical lubrication with physiological effects (equivocation).

sentence: Why does the Sun keep shooting off solar flares? Is it in need of rescue??
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that the Sun is a conscious entity that can ‘need rescue’, which is a false premise. It also implicitly compares solar flares to human distress signals, making a false analogy between astrophysical phenomena and living behavior.

sentence: If computers are so smart how come they can only use 0 and 1?
details: The question assumes without justification that intelligence (being ‘smart’) requires more than two basic states, which is a false premise. It also presents only two possibilities (smart systems must use more than 0 and 1 or they aren’t smart), a false dilemma. Finally it draws an invalid analogy between human-like intelligence and numeric base systems, ignoring that complex behavior can arise from binary encoding.

sentence: If a girl is hotter than me, does that mean I'm cooler than her?
details: The argument equivocates on “hotter” and “cooler,” using them first as measures of attractiveness and then as measures of temperature. Because the terms shift in meaning, the conclusion does not logically follow.

sentence: If Britain uses the metric system, why do they weigh their money in pounds?
details: The argument hinges on the ambiguous use of the word "pounds," conflating the unit of weight with the British currency, thus misleadingly suggesting a conflict with metric usage.

sentence: If humans can grow up to 8 feet, why have I never seen anyone with more than 2?
details: The speaker assumes that if very tall (up to 8 ft) humans exist (A), then they would necessarily have personally seen one (B), and because they have not seen any (¬B), they conclude none exist (¬A). This is the inverse error (assuming A→B implies ¬B→¬A) based on a false premise that existence guarantees personal observation.

sentence: If I continue eating an apple a day, will I never get my PhD?
details: The question presumes a direct causal link between eating an apple daily and the inability to earn a PhD (false cause) based on an unfounded assumption about apples affecting academic achievement (false premise).

sentence: If the Constitution protects us from illegal searches and seizures, can't we eliminate epilepsy by making all seizures illegal?
details: This argument equivocates on the term "seizures" by treating legal seizures of property and medical epileptic seizures as the same, and it falsely analogizes legal prohibition with the ability to eradicate a neurological condition.

sentence: I've had a rash for a couple of weeks now, but I was told never to make rash decisions, what should I do?
details: This sentence uses the word 'rash' in two different senses (a skin irritation vs. hasty actions), leading to an equivocation fallacy by conflating unrelated meanings.

sentence: If we put Xanax in all of the water, would that reduce surface tension?
details: The question rests on an unfounded assumption that Xanax will alter a physical property like surface tension (false premise). It further assumes a direct causal link between adding Xanax and reducing surface tension without evidence (false cause).

sentence: If I connect a 3D printer to my computer, could I print out the cookies stored on my browser? Are they edible?
details: This question relies on an equivocation of the term "cookies," treating browser cookies (digital data) and edible cookies (baked treats) as if they were the same. It also rests on the false premise that digital information can be directly fabricated into edible physical objects via 3D printing.

sentence: Due to the recent cold streak in Colorado, will the next batch of Coors Light be colder than normal?
details: This question assumes that a colder ambient temperature in Colorado will directly make the next batch of Coors Light colder, conflating correlation with causation (false cause) and overlooking the brewery’s controlled brewing and storage processes (false premise).

sentence: My friend told me that a hacker installed a virus into my computer through a backdoor. How is this possible because I lock that door every night and is there a possibility that the virus is Ebola?
details: The argument conflates a software "backdoor" with a physical door (equivocation), interprets a computer virus as a biological pathogen like Ebola (nominal fallacy), and assumes that locking a physical door prevents digital intrusion (false premise).

sentence: Our doctor said that my wife and I are going to have a sun. How can I harness its extensive energy when my wife gives birth?
details: The speaker misinterprets the homophones 'son' and 'sun', treating the doctor's announcement about a baby as if it referred to a star. This is an equivocation on the word 'sun/son' and a nominal fallacy in taking a figurative or homophonic expression literally.

sentence: If one person commits suicide every 40 seconds, why aren't they dead yet?
details: This question rests on a false premise and equivocation: it treats a global average rate (one suicide every 40 seconds across all people) as if it applied repeatedly to the same individual. It thus misattributes a collective statistic to a single person (fallacy of composition) and equivocates on the meaning of "one person."

sentence: A pound of lemons can produce as much electricity as a set of four 1.5v batteries. Why aren't we powering our household devices with lemons, then?
details: The argument assumes without basis that lemons truly match standard batteries in usable electrical output (false premise) and then treats lemons as if they function identically to commercial batteries despite vast differences in current, internal resistance, longevity, and practicality (false analogy).

sentence: Why do we use boiling water to kill bacteria? Wouldn't cold water drown them equally well?
details: The argument assumes that cold water can drown bacteria in the same way it drowns larger organisms, conflating two different mechanisms (false analogy) and rests on the unfounded premise that drowning is an effective method to kill bacteria (false premise).

sentence: If 1 in 5 children diagnosed with cancer don't survive, why don't doctors just stop diagnosing it?
details: The argument assumes that diagnosing cancer causes the deaths rather than the disease itself, committing the false cause fallacy. It also reverses cause and effect (wrong direction) by suggesting stopping diagnosis would prevent deaths. Finally, it rests on the false premise that diagnosis is harmful instead of life-saving.

sentence: My child is double his birth weight, yet has had nothing to eat or drink but milk. Is my kid 50% milk?
details: This argument assumes that because the child has only consumed milk and has doubled in weight, half of the child’s body must be milk. It treats the mass of milk ingested as directly and proportionally constituting the child's composition (fallacy of composition), wrongly equates intake mass with body makeup (false analogy), and improperly sums intake and existing body mass to derive a percentage (improper distribution or addition).

sentence: I heard that Windows Vista freezes often, but what is it's boiling point?
details: The question assumes Windows Vista, a software operating system, has physical properties like a boiling point (false premise). It also relies on the double meaning of 'freezes'—software crashes versus physical freezing—equivocating between computing and thermodynamic contexts.

sentence: Why did water decide to boil and freeze at such conveniently rounded temperatures as 0 and 100?
details: The question anthropomorphizes water by suggesting it 'decided' its phase-change points, treating a figurative expression as literal (nominal fallacy). It also rests on an unfounded assumption that water has agency or choice in setting its boiling and freezing temperatures (false premise).

sentence: How did we get Plutonium if Pluto is so far away and we never been on its surface?
details: The claim rests on the unfounded assumption that plutonium must physically come from the planet Pluto (false premise). It also equivocates on the term "Pluto," treating the planet’s name and the element’s name as indicating a material origin (equivocation), and analogizes shared naming to shared origin without justification (false analogy).

sentence: Why do scientists say Jupiter and Saturn are the largest planets when our moon is clearly bigger?
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption that Earth’s Moon is larger than Jupiter and Saturn. In reality, Jupiter and Saturn have diameters (≈143,000 km and ≈120,000 km) far exceeding the Moon’s (≈3,474 km), so the premise is false and the reasoning invalid.

sentence: Why don't we convert all automobiles to run Linux so they crash less?
details: This argument assumes that because Linux reduces software crashes on computers, it will likewise reduce automobile accidents. That is a false analogy between software reliability and vehicle safety. It also relies on the false premise that car crashes are primarily due to software failures. Furthermore, it equivocates on the word “crash,” conflating software crashes with automobile collisions.

sentence: I gave my cat antihistamines but he's still hissing at me.
details: The speaker assumes without evidence that the cat’s hissing is due to an allergic reaction and that antihistamines would stop it. This is a false premise and falsely attributes a causal link (false cause) between histamine release and defensive hissing.

sentence: Why do scientists drink alcohol in bars when there is never 100% proof available?
details: The question equivocates on the word “proof,” using it to mean both scientific certainty and the alcohol‐content measurement, and rests on a false premise that scientists would only consume alcohol if absolute scientific proof were available.

sentence: If our bodies are 70% water, how much Kool-aid powder do I have to eat to become Kool-aid?
details: The question treats the water in our bodies as if it were free-standing water that could simply be flavored into Kool-Aid by adding powder (false analogy). It also rests on the unfounded assumption that ingesting Kool-Aid powder will convert body water into Kool-Aid (false premise).

sentence: Why do mice keep getting caught into mousetraps that have 'MOUSETRAP' clearly written on them?
details: This question assumes without justification that mice can read and understand written words. Since mice cannot read English, the premise is false and the reasoning invalid.

sentence: They were able to lift 650lbs. with 1 drop of super adhesive on Mythbusters. I just coated my hands with it and I'm still not able to lift 650lbs. What am I doing wrong?
details: The speaker assumes that simply coating their hands in adhesive will replicate the Mythbusters setup without acknowledging other factors (surface contact area, proper fixtures, supportive structure). This is a false analogy (treating two different scenarios as equivalent), a false cause (attributing lifting ability solely to the adhesive), and a false premise (ignoring necessary conditions beyond just adhesive).

sentence: Can I use Office 365 on February 29th?
details: This is a straightforward question about product availability and does not present an argument or rely on any premises, so there are no logical errors or fallacies.

sentence: If scientists use SI units, why do they say humans walk on 'two feet' instead of '0.61 meters'?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that “walk on two feet” uses the non-SI unit “foot” rather than referring to body parts (false premise), and it equivocates between the unit “foot” and literal feet, conflating measurement terminology with ordinary language.

sentence: If more people die per year from taking selfies than shark attacks, would we not be better off just asking sharks to take our pictures instead?
details: This statement hinges on comparing two unrelated activities—human selfie-taking and sharks taking pictures—solely based on mortality statistics. It assumes (without any basis) that sharks could operate cameras, which is a false premise, and then draws an unwarranted analogy between the two activities, making it a false analogy.

sentence: Where do the leaves go? and how do the leaves know which tree to climb back up in the spring?
details: The question is based on the unfounded assumption that leaves have awareness and can decide to climb back to a specific tree; this false premise invalidates the reasoning.

sentence: If Abortion is banned, will space missions become more successful since they won't be allowed to abort?
details: This statement uses the word "abort" in two distinct senses—terminating a pregnancy versus aborting a space mission—creating an equivocation. It also makes a false analogy by assuming that banning one kind of "abort" will impact an entirely unrelated process.

sentence: How did Thomas Eddison come up w/ the idea for the lightbulb if the lightbulb didn't exist to appear above his head
details: The question treats the cartoon metaphor of a lightbulb appearing above someone’s head as if it were a literal event. This is a nominal fallacy—confusing a figurative expression with reality—and also involves equivocation by using the term “lightbulb” ambiguously (the invention versus the symbolic image).

sentence: What's the conversion formula for grams to Instagrams?
details: The question is based on the unfounded assumption that 'Instagrams' is a unit of mass like grams (false premise) and also hinges on the ambiguous use of 'Instagram' to suggest a unit of weight rather than the social media platform (equivocation).

sentence: How do I know whether the windows in my house are 32bit or 64bit?
details: The question equivocates on the term “windows,” confusing the operating system with physical house windows, and rests on the false premise that such windows have a 32-bit or 64-bit architecture.

sentence: If shooting stars grant wishes, could a large asteroid have enough wish granting power to stop itself from hitting earth if everyone on earth wished really hard at the same time as it's about to hit?
details: This argument starts from the unfounded assumption that shooting stars actually grant wishes (false premise). It then illegitimately transfers that magical property to a large asteroid, treating different classes of objects as if they shared the same attributes (false analogy), and further assumes that what might be true for a small meteor must apply equally to a massive asteroid (fallacy of composition).

sentence: If you amplify words loud enough, will they become louder than actions?
details: This question plays on the metaphor ‘actions speak louder than words’ by conflating literal sound volume with figurative influence. It uses the same term ‘louder’ in two senses—physical loudness and metaphorical weight—creating ambiguity through equivocation.

sentence: I know an atom's nucleus is made of protons, but what happens before they go pro? Where are all the amateurons?
details: The question rests on the unfounded assumption that there must be a prior particle called an 'amateuron', making it a false premise, and it equivocates by treating the Greek prefix 'pro-' in 'proton' as if it meant 'professional'.

sentence: The world felt less divided when it was Pangaea. How come our leaders don't work to bring the world back together?
details: The argument treats the geological unity of Pangaea as if it directly translates into modern political unity (false analogy) and assumes leaders could or should physically reassemble continents or that Pangaea’s configuration caused social harmony (false premise), neither of which are reasonable.

sentence: If dogs cannot tell time, please explain how watchdogs evolved.
details: This argument equivocates on the word “watch”: one sense means to tell time and another means to guard. It also relies on the false premise that the term watchdog implies a time‐telling ability rather than a guarding function.

sentence: If a horse can run upto 50 mph, and my car has 300 horsepower, does that mean my car can run upto 15,000 mph?
details: This argument equivocates the term “horse” by conflating the animal’s speed (50 mph) with the unit of power (horsepower). It draws a false analogy that 1 hp equals one horse’s running speed, and rests on the false premise that power can be linearly converted into speed without accounting for factors like mass, drag, and mechanical efficiency.

sentence: If I fart in a Tesla, is it still zero emissions?
details: This question equivocates on the term "emissions" by conflating vehicle tailpipe emissions with human bodily gas emissions, shifting the meaning of the key term and creating a misleading comparison.

sentence: If I gave someone my phone number, why do I still have it?
details: The question assumes without justification that giving someone your phone number means you lose it yourself. In reality, you can share information without transferring exclusive ownership.

sentence: How will the coup in Turkey affect this year's Thanksgiving?
details: The question assumes without evidence that a political event in Turkey will have a direct impact on an unrelated U.S. holiday. This is a false premise (an unfounded assumption) and constitutes a false cause fallacy by inferring causation where none is established.

sentence: If AC/DC break up, will all current music be rectified?
details: The question presumes without justification that AC/DC’s breakup would cause (or ‘rectify’) all current music (false cause) and rests on the unfounded assumption that current music requires correction by AC/DC’s status (false premise).

sentence: I got shot down at a bar last night because 'I wasn't her type.' How did she know I have A Positive blood?
details: The speaker uses the word “type” in two different senses—romantic preference versus blood type—leading to a misleading ambiguity. This is a classic equivocation fallacy.

sentence: Does Cardi B have any of the same health benefits of cardio?
details: This question equivocates on the term “cardio” and Cardi B, treating a person and an exercise as if they share properties. It falsely compares two unrelated things based solely on a superficial similarity in name, making it both an equivocation and a false analogy.

sentence: Why does a rare steak cost the same as a normal steak? Isn't it harder to find?
details: The question equivocates on the word "rare": treating it as both a cooking preference and meaning "scarce," which creates a false premise that rare-cooked steaks are harder to find than other doneness levels.

sentence: A guy just tried to sell me a fire blanket. How can something as warm as a fire need a blanket?
details: The speaker assumes blanket only means a warming cover, equivocating the common use of blankets with the specialized fire blanket (equivocation). This rests on a false premise that all blankets exist solely to warm, ignoring their use to smother fires (false premise). It also misapplies the general rule about blankets warming to a case where smothering is intended (accident fallacy).

sentence: If I am what I eat, how many of iron do I need to eat before I become Iron Man?
details: This statement takes the metaphor "I am what I eat" literally, assuming that consuming iron will transform the eater into Iron Man. It rests on an unfounded premise and treats a figurative expression as a literal fact, making an invalid comparison.

sentence: Why don't we use stop signs to prevent human trafficking?
details: This question assumes without justification that a traffic sign (which regulates vehicle stops) could prevent a complex criminal activity—an unfounded assumption (false premise). It also treats the function of stop signs as directly analogous to law enforcement measures against human trafficking, despite no valid basis for such a comparison (false analogy). Finally, it implies a causal relationship—placing signs will stop traffickers—without evidence (false cause).

sentence: How do so many horses fit into my car engine?
details: The question rests on the false premise that actual horses occupy the engine. It equivocates between the figurative unit “horsepower” and literal horses, misunderstanding the metaphor (nominal fallacy).

sentence: How many energy drinks would I need to drink to have as much energy as the sun?
details: The question equivocates by using the term 'energy' to refer to both the chemical energy in drinks and the nuclear/radiant energy output of the sun. This creates a false analogy by treating two vastly different types and scales of energy as directly comparable, and rests on the false premise that one could ingest or utilize solar-scale energy simply by consuming a beverage.

sentence: How many god particles would we need to make 1 god?
details: The question treats “god particle” (the colloquial name for the Higgs boson) as if it were literally a component for creating a deity. This is a nominal fallacy—taking a metaphorical or informal label as literal—combined with equivocation by shifting the meaning of “god particle” from a physics concept to a divine building block, and it rests on the false premise that such particles could be assembled to form a god.

sentence: If normal glue is made from horse tissue, is superglue made out of the faster horses?
details: This statement equivocates on the term "super"—mistakenly treating it as meaning “faster horses”—and thus commits a false analogy by assuming that sharing a word implies a similar material origin.

sentence: If elephants are facing extinction, why don't they just turn the other way?
details: This question relies on an equivocation of the word “facing,” shifting from meaning “experiencing the threat of” to meaning “physically orienting toward.” It also rests on the false premise that elephants could avoid extinction simply by turning their bodies away from the underlying causes.

sentence: If cooking liquid egg makes it solid, then shouldn't freezing it make it a gas? Instead this happened!
details: The reasoning treats cooking (a chemical denaturation process) and freezing (a physical phase change) as symmetrical opposites, assuming that if heat solidifies egg then cold must gasify it. This is a false analogy and a reversal of cause-and-effect, since freezing does not reverse the chemical changes caused by cooking.

sentence: If you have 2 parents, 4 grandparents, 8 great-grandparents, 16 great-great-grandparents, and so on, doesn't that mean that we each have infinite ancestors if you go all the way back to the beginning, thus disproving the Biblical story of Adam and Eve?
details: The argument rests on the false premise that every ancestor is distinct and that the number doubles without bound. In reality, pedigree collapse (shared ancestors) prevents infinite growth. It also mistakenly applies a part-to-whole inference by treating each generation’s doubling as if it must hold for the entire ancestry without overlap.

sentence: Since time is slowly killing us - what is the most effective way to kill time?
details: The phrase “time is slowly killing us” uses a metaphorical sense of 'killing,' while the follow-up question treats 'killing time' as if time were a literal entity that can be killed. This shift in meaning is equivocation. It also mistakes a figurative expression for a literal fact, which constitutes a nominal fallacy.

sentence: I scored a 10,194 on my pedometer. Should I stay away from children?
details: This argument assumes without basis that a high pedometer score has any bearing on whether one poses a risk to children, which is a false premise. It also incorrectly infers a causal relationship between step count and dangerousness (false cause) and implicitly equates the two unrelated attributes (false analogy). None of these provide valid support for the conclusion.

sentence: If people during the stone age used stone weapons and during the bronze age they used bronze weapons, did people during the ice age use ice weapons?
details: The argument assumes that because the 'stone age' implies stone weapons and the 'bronze age' implies bronze weapons, the 'ice age' must imply ice weapons. This wrongly reverses the naming cause-and-effect (improper transposition) and draws an invalid comparison between technological and climatic epochs (false analogy).

sentence: Einstein didn't know E=MC^2 until his mid-20s. I knew about it since elementary school. How much smarter does that make me compared to Einstein?
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption (false premise) that knowing a particular formula earlier equates to greater overall intelligence. It also implies a direct causal link between early knowledge and higher intelligence (false cause) and infers a global trait (general smartness) from one specific data point (knowing E=MC^2) (fallacy of composition).

sentence: What time is it on the sun?
details: The question assumes without justification that the sun has a local time in the same sense as locations on Earth, which is an unfounded premise and renders the query invalid.

sentence: Is 1st degree murder measured in Celsius, Fahrenheit, or Kelvin?
details: The question conflates the term degree in the legal classification of murder with degrees of temperature. It uses equivocation by shifting the meaning of “degree,” rests on a false premise that a crime can be measured on a temperature scale, and makes a false analogy between legal severity and physical temperature measurement.

sentence: How can fish hold their breath for so long underwater?
details: The question is based on the unfounded assumption that fish 'hold their breath' as air-breathing animals do (false premise). It also takes a figurative expression ('hold their breath') literally when applied to fish (nominal fallacy) and uses the term 'breath' ambiguously between human and fish respiration (equivocation).

sentence: if circles are 360 degrees, then how can I pick up round things and not get burnt?
details: The argument conflates two distinct meanings of “degrees”: the 360° measure of a circle versus degrees of temperature. It falsely assumes that a circle’s angular measure implies heat, leading to the mistaken premise that one would burn when touching any round object.

sentence: A friend accidentally dropped a 20 pound bag of ice on my foot. Do I now still need to keep my foot on ice to keep it from swelling?
details: This is a request for medical or first-aid advice rather than an argument containing a logical error. The question does not rest on a flawed premise or fallacious reasoning—it simply asks whether icing remains appropriate after an injury.

sentence: If I peddle backwards on my exercise bike will I gain weight?
details: This question assumes that reversing the direction of pedaling (the absence of forward pedaling) will invert the effect on body weight. It commits an inverse error (if A→B then ¬A→¬B), relies on a false premise that direction alone determines weight change, and posits a false cause by attributing weight gain to backward pedaling without any causal basis.

sentence: How did people charge their phones before Benjamin Franklin invented electricity?
details: The question is based on the unfounded assumption that Benjamin Franklin invented electricity and that phones existed at that time. Both premises are false, rendering the argument invalid.

sentence: Why is everyone afraid of atomic bombs? Shouldn't we be more worried about the bigger ones?
details: This question frames concern as if it must be either about atomic bombs or about larger bombs, ignoring that one can validly worry about both or other threats. It thus presents a false dichotomy by implying only two exclusive options for what we should fear.

sentence: If heat kills germs, and I am sick can I cook myself?
details: This argument misapplies the general rule that heat kills germs to a situation where heating the entire human body would destroy the host along with any pathogens. It is an accident fallacy (misapplying a generalization to a specific case) and also relies on a false analogy between germ cultures and a living human body.

sentence: If cigarettes are unhealthy and vegetables are healthy, why don't we make cigarettes out of vegetables?
details: This argument assumes that because vegetables are healthy when eaten, a cigarette made from vegetables would also be healthy. It commits a false analogy by treating the healthiness of foods as transferable to a smoking context, and a fallacy of composition by attributing a property of the part (vegetables) to the whole (a cigarette), while ignoring the harmful effects of combustion and inhalation.

sentence: Why are trains still operated by conductors when super conductors logically would be better suited?
details: This question equivocates on the term “conductor,” treating a train operator and a superconducting material as if they were interchangeable because they share a name. It also relies on a false analogy by assuming that properties of superconductors (electrical conductivity at low temperature) could meaningfully replace the human role of a train conductor.

sentence: If I put my contacts in backwards will I be able to see what I'm thinking?
details: This question assumes without justification that reversing contact lenses could grant the ability to visually perceive one’s thoughts (a false premise). It also equates ‘seeing’ with both literal visual perception and metaphorical mental insight, creating an equivocation between physical and mental senses.

sentence: If space is a vacuum, how come earth is so polluted?
details: This argument equivocates on the word “vacuum,” shifting from its technical meaning (an absence of matter) to the colloquial sense of being ‘clean’ or ‘free of contaminants.’ It also rests on a false premise that a physical vacuum should by definition be ‘unpolluted’ in the everyday sense, conflating emptiness with purity.

sentence: Negative times negative is a positive so why don't we just multiply the national debt by more debt and wipe it out with a huge profit?
details: This argument commits a false analogy by applying the arithmetic rule that the product of two negative numbers is positive to the economic concept of national debt. It equivocates on the term "negative", treating debt as if it were simply a negative number on a number line. It also rests on the false premise that multiplying debt could erase it and generate profit, ignoring the real-world economic and legal nature of debt obligations.

sentence: Is it true that 4/3 of Americans have trouble with fractions?
details: This claim asserts that 133% of Americans have difficulty with fractions, exceeding 100% of the population. Such an assertion is based on an unfounded and impossible assumption, making it a false premise.

sentence: Can you kill wind by shooting it? Is it OK to accept when my friend invites me to shoot the breeze, or will we just maim it and make it suffer?
details: This question relies on equivocation by switching between the literal sense of 'shoot' and 'wind' and the idiomatic phrase 'shoot the breeze.' It also treats a figurative expression as if it were a literal statement (nominal fallacy) and assumes an unwarranted premise that wind is a sentient object that can be killed or harmed (false premise).

sentence: I can clearly see how the Titanic took on water and eventually sank. How is it possible the designers missed this fatal flaw?
details: The question rests on an unfounded assumption that the designers must have overlooked a ‘fatal flaw’ that is now allegedly obvious. It presumes without evidence that such a flaw was both present and missed, rather than considering that designers lacked certain information or that the outcome was unforeseeable given the knowledge of the time.

sentence: If I speak latin, which is a dead language, can I talk to dead people?
details: This sentence equivocates the word "dead" in "dead language" (meaning no longer spoken) with "dead people" (deceased individuals), implying a nonsensical causal link. It also rests on the false premise that the status of a language as "dead" confers supernatural communication abilities.

sentence: Mankind has only mined 3.42 olympic pools of gold in history. Why don't we make olympic pools half as big so we have twice the gold? Have I solved global poverty?
details: The argument assumes that redefining the size of the measurement unit (an Olympic pool) will change the actual amount of gold mined. This is a nominal fallacy (treating a change in definition as a change in reality), rests on a false premise that pool size affects total gold, and equivocates between the measurement unit and the physical quantity.

sentence: Why the big fuss over nuclear, gas, or coal energy? Can't we just have power plants that run off of electricity?
details: The claim assumes without justification that electricity—which is itself generated by power plants—could serve as the primary energy input for those same plants (begging the question). It also reverses the true cause-and-effect relationship, treating the effect (electricity) as if it were the cause (wrong direction). Finally, it relies on an unfounded premise that you can run power stations solely on the output they produce (false premise).

sentence: If food only has a certain shelf life, why don't we just set it all on the floor?
details: The argument rests on the unfounded assumption that putting food on the floor is a logical way to deal with its limited shelf life (false premise). It misapplies the general fact that 'food will spoil eventually' to the specific action of 'setting it on the floor,' ignoring hygiene, contamination, and better disposal methods (accident fallacy). It also presents only two options—preserve food or dump it on the floor—when in fact many alternatives exist (false dilemma).

sentence: If I flip a coin 1,000,000 times, what are the odds of me wasting my time?
details: The question improperly links the random outcome of coin flips to the subjective notion of wasting time, attributing a causal relationship where none exists (false cause). It also assumes without basis that flipping a coin a million times equates to wasting time (false premise) and uses “odds” ambiguously, conflating probabilistic odds with a metaphorical judgment of futility (equivocation).

sentence: In America, someone is shot every 15 seconds. How is that person still alive?
details: The argument hinges on the ambiguous use of the word “shot,” conflating being shot with a gun and being shot with a camera. This equivocation leads to confusion: the listener initially interprets “shot” as gun violence, then the punchline relies on the figurative meaning of photography. It also exemplifies the nominal fallacy by treating the figurative phrase as a literal scenario.
